title: Understanding Fractality

analysis.translation: Okay, let's look at a very important topic. Without understanding what we're going to do today, it is impossible, one, to understand the methodology, this methodology, and worst of all, not to understand fractality. Therefore, this is one of the most important concepts. And if you don't master it, we're screwed. It will be impossible to master the methodology. Impossible. Let's see, I'm going to draw here, imagine this is a point of control of a downtrend and here we have its corresponding cycle. I'll also do it with an uptrend movement so you can see that the concept is exactly the same. Imagine this is a point of control, here we have a movement, we have its corresponding retracement, the concept is the same, in both cases as we have a retracement to 38%, we can logically mark their corresponding zones. Let's look at the high zone, low zone, we mark their corresponding arrows. Always sell in high zones, in this downtrend case, 61 downwards, and in this uptrend case, 61 upwards and always buy in the low zones. In any of these cases, all cycles have their break level. In this case, I'll mark it here. I'll take off the fibo now. This is the situation of any cycle from any point of control or even the first cycle of any map. This is the usual structure of any activated cycle. Notice I'm marking the high and low zones in different colors because they are the most important zones for you to understand fractality. That is to say, cycles, or rather fractality, is constantly evolving. The movement does not stop. Therefore, the cycle you have marked right now with each corresponding zone is sure, absolutely sure, that it either breaks or evolves. All the fractals that give you a cycle, all either break or evolve. So we have to understand the breakages well. It's clear that this cycle on the left will break once it has already touched the 38.2 here, once it is activated here. The break is clear because we have its break point perfectly delimited. That's why we mark it in all cycles. Either up or down. Either up or down. Do we understand what we're saying about the break point? Yes. If this price gets here, that cycle is broken or if that price at any moment reaches here, the cycle is broken. If the price gets here, the cycle is broken. If the cycle gets here, the cycle is broken. That is to say, that cycle is worthless. It died, it's over, it broke, and it will never be of use again. Therefore, the concept of breakage is very simple. It's not mystical. The problem comes with evolution. Constant evolution. For that, I want you to always understand that when you have marked a cycle, the measures of the zones of that cycle are given because at some point you measured its impulse. At some point, in this uptrend cycle from that point of control, what you did was measure its impulse to which you waited for its corresponding retracement. Do you agree? Yes. Therefore, what marks the category, let's say, of the cycle is the measure of the impulse. When I say category, I mean if it's bigger or smaller. In the end, what you've measured is from a point of control or from the beginning of a map you have measured an impulse. That's what gives you later that the zones are bigger or smaller. Therefore, you are working with that impulse. That's why we measure it. Simply the retracement is the essential condition for us to define that indeed when there is a retracement of that impulse to 38.2, that's the moment we can mark all its zones. Why do I mark the high and low zones differently? And why don't I take into account the zones of 61? Very easy. If you realize this retracement, the height of that retracement to 38.2 is much smaller than the height you're measuring of the impulse. Therefore, when this movement comes to work 61.8, when this movement comes to work 61.8 within the same cycle, the retracement is still smaller than the impulse. Therefore, there's no problem with that retracement exceeding the impulse measurement distance you had. That's why 61.8 doesn't affect the cycle. We can work it absolutely but it doesn't affect any evolution. Because the evolutions you have to understand the ones that occur. It produces a movement greater than the impulse you are working with. What is the first way to make a retracement of the impulse you are working with that is higher than the impulse itself? Well, the first thing is always when the 61 zone breaks the price crosses it and enters the high part. Or in this case, when the price penetrates the 61 zone and in this case reaches the low part. Here we already have a problem, and it's that the retracement is already bigger than the impulse you were working with. Very important. And what we want when we work with fractality is to always work with the larger fractals. That's why the smaller fractals will lead to larger fractals, and why they are breaking, they are becoming obsolete. If we are working in this case, I insist, the breakage of the 61 zone, in this case the high part, or the breakage of the 61 zone, in this case the low part, it is exactly the same, the same situation simply reversed, we already have this first reason to think that, beware, that the impulse with which I was working is no longer the current largest movement within this cycle. When reaching this case, this specific case, only two things can happen. Only two things can happen. Of course, I need you to understand that when this happens either the cycle is broken, that is, either this happens or this happens, first of all things that can happen. That is, if we are in a high zone or a low zone, in this case buys, in this case sells, that the price does not pay attention at all to the direction of the zone we are working and breaks. First of the options. The other option is that the price reaches 61.8 or does not reach 61.8, I don't care, at some point the price works the low zone. Or in this case, the price works the high zone. Here we have a similar problem. That is, in this case, what is happening is that from that point of control or from this point of control, now the movement being made is greater than the movement you were working with. It is superior to the impulse you were working with. And this is another problem. Look at the blue, the height it has, but now we have a greater impulse. In both cases, just like before, now it may happen that the price ends up breaking the zone too. There is no problem. Broken cycle. That the price ends up breaking. No problem at all. What I need you to understand is high and low zone, we have the risk of breakage, yes, but it also implies the danger of cycle evolution. How is cycle evolution produced? Good. If this new impulse at some point, due to the zone working well, makes a retracement there to 38.2, immediately, from that very moment, the previous cycle is obsolete, and we would have a new cycle with its corresponding new zones. And here we would mark the corresponding measurements of the three zones to the new cycle. There has been an important, important evolution. The smaller fractality is breaking because larger fractals are being formed. I don't want to be left with a smaller fractal. I want to work the zones of the larger fractal and that's why I always have to be controlling the evolutions that it does for me. The same would happen in the opposite case. If this price, instead of going for the high zone or this price, instead of going for the low zone, let's put back the 61 zone, goes to the other side, we have exactly the same problem, identical problem, identical problem. We are running the risk of having an evolution. If this zone works well and the price goes up, from the same point of control, from the same point of control, if now this price works well and makes a downward movement, if this price works well and makes an upward movement, we must always be aware at which moment the evolution occurs, at which moment, from the same point of control, at which moment the price makes that retracement, this retracement, because from that very moment the previous cycle is completely broken and we would have to mark new zones, with new measures. This is constant, constant in the charts, and if I don't evolve well with these characteristics, I'm screwed, because I will be working with fractals that no longer serve, zones that are already dead, cycles that are either broken or evolved. This cannot happen. What I want you to understand very well, now we will see an example, this is a priority, understanding this. If I don't understand this, I'm screwed. I will never understand fractality. Let's say it's the most, not that it's complex, it's getting the technique, and I assure you that everyone controls well high and low parts, but it's training it and seeing it on the charts. What are the basic behaviors you must have every time you have a cycle? Just like that. I don't know what this price is going to do, I don't know if it's going to go to a high part if it's going to go to a low part, I don't know what it's going to do. What I do know is where it breaks, that's for sure. What you have to understand then is that this cycle you have here right now, one of the things that can happen, if this comes, if it's a downcycle, means the movement is downwards. If here you have an upcycle, it's clear that it's an upwards movement. Well, one of the things that can happen is it goes boom boom boom boom, breaks, doesn't even give you work reasons, breaks directly, and that cycle goes to hell. You will already have to be watching the new control points that can be going on in the rise. Another thing that can happen is everything goes to hell and breaks down. That nothing works. Or you can even see the situation that the 61 zone works well and the price continues in the same direction. Well, we break the cycle, we control the new control points, we see it is superior to the previous one, this one is dead, and we would move to the next point which is higher. This is the first thing that can happen. That they break, well, they're going to break a lot. What I need you to understand is the following. The basic, fundamental, elementary rule, the first brand concept you have to have very clear once you have the cycle marked just as I have it here is the following. If at any moment, logically we would have marked level 38 here. Here we would have marked level 38. Okay, full horizontal line. Okay, perfect. Elementary, basic behavior, always the same. If at any moment the price enters a high zone, this 61 zone is obvious it doesn't matter, that 38 is obvious it doesn't matter and this bottom zone is obvious it doesn't matter either. Because once you arrive up here, you either break or evolve. You either break or evolve. Therefore, this 61 mark, its 38 and its opposite zone are of no use at all. Just as if it does this, if at any moment the price works the lower part, the 38 level, the 61 zone and its opposite zone are also worth nothing because you either break or evolve. First thing, eliminate the other cycle marks. Immediately if this happens, off goes the 38, off goes 61, off goes the upper zone and of course the breakage of the upper zone. Only this zone would serve me because either it pulls up and evolves or breaks. I stay with this mark and this mark. The same would happen here, if the price here enters a high zone, this 38, that zone, and the low zone are of no use to me because either break or evolve. I already have no value for this mark or this or this. Opposite case, if you come down, logically the 61 zone would already be broken but neither the 38 nor the opposite zone nor its break serves me. You either break down or shoot and evolve. Concept, it is essential that you do, remove the marks that no longer matter and remember, if the price enters a high zone or enters a low zone, I don't care if the cycle is bullish or bearish, the other zones and the 38 of that cycle are immediately out.

decision_points.condition: Cycle retraces to 38.2%
decision_points.if_true: Mark all corresponding zones
decision_points.if_false: No zones are marked
decision_points.quote_es: Simplemente el retroceso es la condición imprescindible para que definamos que efectivamente cuando hay retroceso de ese impulso al 38.2, ahí es el momento en el que podemos marcar todas sus zonas.

decision_points.condition: Movement exceeds the previous cycle impulse height
decision_points.if_true: Cycle is broken or evolves
decision_points.if_false: Continue within same cycle

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: Cycles and patterns in the market that evolve or break, in constant change.
concepts.relationship: Connected to cycle evolution and point of control concepts.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A reference point used to measure the impulse and corresponding retracement in a cycle.
concepts.relationship: Forms the starting point for measuring cycles and determining fractality.

concepts.name: 38.2% Retracement
concepts.definition: A key level indicating potential zone transitions within a cycle.
concepts.relationship: Used to mark and determine zones within cycles, works with point of control.

concepts.name: 61.8% Level
concepts.definition: A level indicating potential breakage or continuation of the cycle.
concepts.relationship: Signals potential changes in cycle dominance.

rules.rule: If the movement exceeds the previous cycle impulse height, it signifies a cycle break or evolution.
rules.context: Occurs when evaluating ongoing market movements against prior cycles.

rules.rule: Remove all unnecessary zones and levels if the price enters a high or low zone.
rules.context: During an identified cycle when a new breakout or potential evolution is detected.

rules.rule: Mark all corresponding zones when a cycle retraces to 38.2%.
rules.context: While measuring retracement levels after determining the impulse.

analysis.summary: This video covers key concepts in Joaquín Vega's modified Fibonacci methodology, emphasizing the understanding of fractality and the evolution of market cycles. It explains how to use the point of control to measure cycles and determine when a breakdown or evolution in the cycle occurs. Critical retracement levels, such as 38.2% and 61.8%, are used to establish high and low zones, with prices entering these zones signaling possible cycle changes. The methodology stresses the constant observation and adjustment to the fractals forming in the market to ensure accurate trades.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: The idea that patterns repeat at different scales and can be found in any timeframe.
concepts.relationship: Connects to cycle analysis and pattern recognition, uses fractality to identify cycles and control points.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A key level or area where price action is monitored closely for potential changes or validation.
concepts.relationship: Determines high probability zones for cycle evolutions and breaks; works in tandem with fractal cycles.

concepts.name: 61.8% Retracement
concepts.definition: A Fibonacci level used as a key decision point for potential price actions.
concepts.relationship: Evaluated for price breaks and control point validations.

rules.rule: Use past reviewed charts to better understand market nuances.
rules.context: When verifying patterns and structures in historical data, particularly helpful for future price movements.

rules.rule: Monitor established points of control for potential cycle evolutions or breaks.
rules.context: In live trading when identifying valid or invalid trading zones.

rules.rule: In case of a cycle break, redefine control points and refocus on newly established cycle alignments.
rules.context: Any time a major cycle level such as 61 or 38 is invalidated by price action.

analysis.summary: The video by Joaquín Vega discusses the concept of fractality in trading, emphasizing how patterns repeat across different timeframes. Vega introduces a method based on reviewing past market data to understand price behavior through nuanced observation. Key concepts include identifying points of control and using Fibonacci retracement levels like 61.8% to anticipate potential changes. Vega stresses the importance of practice through past reviewed chart analysis, which strengthens real-time trading decisions. The video highlights trading rules and practices that help manage cycle evolutions and breaks efficiently.

title: Many Ways to Win and Lose

analysis.translation: I also wanted to talk to you about another important topic, at least it is for me, which is a misunderstood concept among new traders - the concept of winning and losing trades. I understand that when people come from other educations or have been self-taught, their idea of winning and losing does not match mine. I need you to understand very well my concept of loss and victory. Basically, if we're talking about losing trades, I have what I call complete losers. These are trades where I enter the market here, maybe buy here, set a stop, and place my targets wherever, but I don't have time to do anything before the price goes straight to my stop. A complete losing trade is managed with an amount I have established as the maximum loss in my business plan – as simple as that. I also use a concept called a null losing trade. Imagine I use a risk, and I'm making this up, that my business plan says I have a risk of $50 and my winning trade should make $300. If I lose the complete trade, I lose $50, but to consider a trade a winner, with or without partials, I must make $300. Now, what is a null trade? We've seen that a complete losing trade ends with minus $50, but for a null trade, if the price quickly moves against me and I see it has no inclination to move in my favor, I generally don't keep such trades. So, that trade, which perhaps ends with me exiting, costs me $25 – an amount less than my business plan maximum. Hence, it's not a complete loser. When we discuss winning trades, a complete winner aligns with my business plan: I have made €300, whether through partial, double partial, triple partials – I don't care. The total of all partials and the final must equal $300 to be a complete winner. I also have what I call positive trades – not a winning trade. What is a positive trade? Any trade where the price allows for a partial. For example, I enter here, and my targets are above to make 300, but I might have several partials. A positive trade reaches an initial partial but then takes me out. So instead of making €300, I might make €40 because the price allowed only for a partial before stopping me at break-even. So, it’s not a winning trade, it’s a positive one. These positive trades will never grow my account; they are used to recover a complete losing or a null trade. Finally, there's what I call very winning trades; this is when I let something run beyond €300 and it might reach €500. This is a very winning trade. These are typical trades that suddenly boost your account significantly. I'm aware of five outcome options. My trading isn't about stop-profit. It's much more nuanced. A lot of usage of partials, reduction of loss. Positive trades won't grow your account, so they aren't counted. So, it's more complex. Entering the market like a gamble – hitting a stop or profit without management, doesn't make sense to me. If we're using an extensive ratio, incorporating partial tools, we must acknowledge five aspects when evaluating trade results, heavily relying on management style. Let’s see it in a specific example. Look, this trade from last month has given the necessary partials and final target. By reaching here with its partials and final, it was already a winner. But I always leave a trade to try for a very winning trade. Look at where the price is now. This is a very winning trade, the kind that suddenly boosts your account. When a very winning trade far exceeds your business plan targets, you need to eventually close it. Even with my experience in long-term ratios for trade durations, there’s a point you just don’t want more. We’ll close this trade today and keep the position running from the other day, which I’ll now explain. This other trade, this would be the very winning one. Any losing trades were saved before hitting the stop, no mystery there. For example, this trade comes with several fractional positions. You get a first target here, a second here, by now it’s a winner, fulfilling the €300 target from our earlier example. But I leave one to try for a very winning trade – an extra, a cherry on top, a gift. In short positions, you might get a partial or two, but not reach targets, it’s a null trade. Very winning, winning, null. It doesn’t matter if I make a bit here or there if it doesn’t meet the €300. Therefore, I like this graph as it shows different ways I assess trade outcomes based on my business plan.

decision_points.condition: Price quickly moves against position without showing intention to reverse
decision_points.if_true: Exit position early to minimize loss
decision_points.if_false: Potentially hold but closely monitor for further evaluation
decision_points.quote_es: yo no permito que me saque el stop completo
decision_points.quote_en: I do not allow it to hit my full stop

decision_points.condition: Setup achieves all predefined partial targets
decision_points.if_true: Consider as winning trade by hitting business plan objectives
decision_points.if_false: Evaluate as either positive or null trade based on partials reached
decision_points.quote_es: He sumado 300 euros
decision_points.quote_en: I have made 300 euros

decision_points.condition: Price reaches the very high target exceeding business plan goals
decision_points.if_true: Take profit and close position, recognizing it as a very winning trade
decision_points.if_false: Continue monitoring for further gains
decision_points.quote_es: Por tanto, esto es una operación muy ganadora.
decision_points.quote_en: Therefore, this is a very winning trade.

concepts.name: Complete Losing Trade
concepts.definition: A trade that hits the stop loss set as per the business plan without any adjustment or chance for partial exit.
concepts.relationship: Managed within pre-established maximum loss parameters.

concepts.name: Null Trade
concepts.definition: A trade closed early at a loss smaller than the complete stop, often when price moves negatively with little chance of reversal.
concepts.relationship: Used as a risk management strategy to limit loss.

concepts.name: Positive Trade
concepts.definition: A trade where small profit or partials are realized before being stopped at break-even, used to offset previous losses.
concepts.relationship: Does not count toward account growth, only mitigating losses.

concepts.name: Very Winning Trade
concepts.definition: A trade left to run after achieving set targets, yielding significantly higher profits.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a potential account growth booster beyond planned profits.

concepts.name: Partials
concepts.definition: Trade exits taken at predetermined milestones to secure profits incrementally.
concepts.relationship: Critical to risk/reward management in modified Fibonacci trades.

rules.rule: If a trade quickly moves against you without reversing, exit early and don’t let it reach the full stop.
rules.context: When monitoring trades after initial entry.

rules.rule: To count a trade as a full winner, achieve the total profit target through one or multiple partials.
rules.context: When evaluating if a trade met objectives.

rules.rule: Very winning trades are held beyond standard targets to capitalize on extended market movements.
rules.context: When already achieving and surpassing profit expectations.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega introduces a nuanced trading approach centered on how traders perceive winning and losing trades. He distinguishes complete losing trades against null trades, which are exited early to minimize potential losses. Winning trades are defined by meeting business plan goals irrespective of using partials. Positive trades help recoup losses but don’t contribute to account growth. Very winning trades greatly exceed expectations, contributing substantially when capitalized beyond targets. His methodology involves careful risk management and strategic profit bookings using modified Fibonacci retracement techniques.

title: Must Keep This In Mind

analysis.translation: Let me see if I can explain myself. When you are profitable, when you achieve profitability, and when I talk about profitability, I'm not referring to an exact amount, when you have, I don't know, one, two, three years of being profitable, we know the word profitable is very, very subjective because we're not talking about an exact amount. When you reach this point, you are profitable for different reasons. You've reached that level for various reasons, without a doubt, the first is because you've found the right discipline. I cannot conceive that a person is profitable unless, first of all, regardless of the method used, they have developed discipline. That also means that if you are profitable, you have found the appropriate numbers for you, undoubtedly. If you haven't found the right numbers for yourself, you will never be profitable. Therefore, discipline and numbers, that discipline and those numbers will be applied to a method that you have found and that suits you. Yes, you will have also found assets, a type of asset that fits your discipline, your numbers, and the method. Not all assets behave the same, and without a doubt, you've managed to adjust all operations that these four previous factors demand to your personal condition. Each of you has a different personal condition, a different availability, a different history. It's very important that these five factors, which summarize what I consider, without them, if one fails, you wouldn't be successful. Therefore, you have managed to create a correct mixture of these five factors that led you to profitability. Notice that we already have a cocktail of five factors that is complex, it's already complex to mix them correctly. The dish has to be very well made with the right touch of each one. But notice, there are two of these factors that can throw everything away. The first of them is the assets. That is, when we have that mixture and we think that with the same discipline, with the same numbers, with the same method, the assets will always behave the same way, we start to encounter problems. I can understand that these first three factors, that discipline, those numbers, and that method, will always remain the same, to that extent I agree. But what happens when you realize that the assets you work on do not behave the same? You realize that in that year, two years, three years you've been profitable applying your method to those assets, you start to realize that the assets move differently, things happen. Here we have the first unknown of what will happen to your profitability if this occurs. Normally we practice with very different assets, but in the end, I assure you that the person who is profitable means that they have spent time with the methodology they use and already figured out which assets best suit their methodology and their own condition, this is certain. Any operator eventually ends up making their own selection of a greater or lesser number of assets that are not only better understood but also confirmed that their way of operating fits better. If those assets begin to behave differently, it's the first possible cause where your profitability could be affected. Besides, the other option where your methodology could be totally affected is when your personal conditions change. What does a personal condition mean? It's easy, imagine that during those, I don't know, two years that you have been working well and been profitable to a greater or lesser extent, imagine that you had four hours available to do your trading, four available hours every day, four hours available in a row. Your discipline, your numbers, your method, and your assets in those four consecutive hours allowed you to do profitable trading. Now suppose for whatever reason you can now only do two hours, stop for another two hours because you can't be there for four straight hours, and then return for another two hours. That is, you continue working four hours in your trading, yes, but it's not the same. You had four consecutive hours that perfectly adapted to the asset, the method, the numbers, and the discipline at the schedule you wanted or at the times you wanted. The moment you change to working two, stopping two, and returning two, as you can understand, your trading cannot be the same, it's not possible. Did the method change? No. Did the assets change? No. Did your numbers change? No. Did your discipline change? No. But your trading is different, without a doubt. Not to mention when now instead of having your four available hours, you have 30 minutes now, then you have to stop another 30 minutes, the next 30 minutes you can't, then you return another 30 minutes later, then an hour later you can't, and you return another hour later. This changes everything. When I say everything, I mean everything. How is it possible that applying the same method that made me profitable two years, applying the same numbers, applying the same discipline, and in the same assets, now isn't profitable anymore? It's very simple, because your personal condition is not the same. So notice how a variable personal condition, for whatever reason, can change everything. So what happens? Imagine if besides the personal condition the assets change too. If both factors come together, you have a huge problem. You have a problem of having to adapt everything again, all that time it took you to acquire the discipline, get the numbers, the method, choose the assets, and with that personal condition, it's no longer valid, absolutely no longer valid. Does it mean the method is no longer useful? No, we're not saying the method isn't useful. What we're saying is you can't apply the method in the same way, you can't. Therefore, what will you have to do? You will have to adapt the method to the new conditions, there's no other choice. What happens then? You start again, not from scratch because you already have the discipline. But surely you will have to modify numbers, maybe the entry methods you had in that method, you have to modify them, and maybe you shouldn't work in the same assets because if your personal conditions do not allow you to properly follow through, you will have to modify even possibly the assets. So where am I going with this? I always use the same example, real life. Do not take for granted that because you and your family are well today, you will always be well. Things that alter this will happen, without a doubt, that's life law, things that alter that state, and you will have no choice but to adapt. Well, trading is the same. So what happens? Damn, with what it took me to be with my family in this situation and two years going great without any problem, suddenly for whatever reason, we start seeing things that alter that situation. When we transfer this to trading, what I'm trying to warn you about is that this is one of the parts, just like life itself, very complex, the adaptation to this kind of inconvenience. So never take for granted that when you have a methodology and a winning condition, never take for granted that this will always be so. This is the most complex part of trading, even, in my opinion, it's easier to find the discipline, the numbers, the method, the assets from the start. It's easier, mind you, with all its complexity. The problem arises when you believe you have it, but external performances tell you no, that yes you had it, but it's no longer valid. Depending on the capacity you have to adapt to the new condition, will be your possible future. Past years' results don't imply future years' results, that adaptation you'll have to do when this occurs will take time, that is, it's like a new renewal of, dammit, I have to start adapting all parameters again and that time we don't know how long it is, but if we want to continue in the fight, in the league, in the mud, if we want to keep trading, we're going to have to do it. That's why trading never ends.

decision_points.if_false: Continue with the same strategy until condition changes

decision_points.quote_en: you start to realize that the assets move differently

decision_points.condition: Personal conditions change
decision_points.if_true: Trading will be affected and may no longer be profitable
decision_points.if_false: Continue with the same strategy
decision_points.action: Adapt strategy to new personal conditions
decision_points.quote_es: tu condición personal no es la misma
decision_points.quote_en: your personal condition is not the same

concepts.name: Profitability
concepts.definition: Achieving consistent gains over time, subjective and depends on multiple factors
concepts.relationship: Depends on discipline, numbers, method, assets, and personal conditions

concepts.name: Discipline
concepts.definition: The ability to consistently follow a trading strategy without deviation
concepts.relationship: A foundation for profitability along with suitable numbers

concepts.name: Adaptation
concepts.definition: Adjusting trading strategies based on changes in personal conditions and asset behaviors
concepts.relationship: Essential when external and internal changes affect existing strategies

rules.rule: Profitability requires discipline, suitable numbers, a fitting method, and suitable assets.
rules.context: Achieving and maintaining profitability

rules.rule: Adapt your method when personal conditions or asset behaviors change.
rules.context: When external or internal factors that previously supported strategies no longer apply

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses the complexity of achieving and maintaining profitability in trading, emphasizing the need for discipline, suitable numbers, a method, and appropriate assets. He highlights the crucial role of personal conditions and asset behavior in sustaining profits. If these factors change, traders must adapt their methodology. Realizing that past success doesn't guarantee future results, traders should be prepared for constant adaptation in the face of evolving conditions—in trading and life alike.

title: Setbacks - Enemy of Novice Traders

analysis.translation: So could we say that we have a first fractal here in this drawing? Okay, there's no doubt. Now what I need you to understand, I insist this is something I'm teaching you today is basic trading. I need you to understand that here a retracement is happening, right? Yes. I need you to understand something vital. The duration of retracements. A retracement can be measured in two ways. By duration, time and height or measure. What is time? Very simple. When does a retracement end? We've already seen where a retracement forms. But now, how can I say that the retracement is over? Imagine this retracement now does this. Could I say that this retracement is over? No. Because for the retracement to be over, in order to know that the new impulse of the next fractal is taking place, as I always tell you, the rules are objective. There is no possible interpretation here. To know that the impulse of the next fractal is indeed happening, I need it to meet an objective requirement. That is that the retracement that has occurred, I will measure it with my Fibonacci. The retracement. As long as that price, which is now up there, does not touch our Fibonacci level 130, I cannot consider the retracement concluded. Because what we ask is that it falls below the start of the retracement by a third of its measure. Do we agree? In other words, look at where this retracement is. Here it made a minimum. Okay, we know there is a retracement. Right now the retracement has become deeper and now it has that height. As long as the price doesn’t do this and touch the 130, I cannot say that the retracement has concluded. If the price made that high there and is like this, can I say the retracement is over? No. Moreover, this retracement can continue to rise. Therefore, I'll take my Fibo and measure it again completely. From where the retracement started, I keep measuring with my Fibo. And notice how the 130 changes place. The deeper the retracement becomes, the more the 130 is left behind. I don’t know when this retracement will end. I only know that as long as it doesn’t touch here, I don’t consider it concluded. If the price does this, can I say the retracement is over? No. Absolutely not. If the price does this, can I consider it over? No, absolutely not. If the price does this, can I consider it over? No, neither. Absolutely not. The condition is essential. Either you touch it or I do not consider the retracement finished. Because now the price can do this. The retracement is not over. Even the price can do this. The retracement is not over. Earlier I told you, retracements can be measured in two ways. By time and by height or measurement. Why is this so important? Because retracements, if you are realizing, can last a long time. The price can be in this state for a long time, as long as it wants until it touches the 130. What I want you to understand is that in this process the price can take as long as it wants. It can do this, it can do this, it can do this. Has it touched the 130? No, not at all. Exactly. Well, this type of retracements, and listen well to what I say, because this is what confuses all novice traders, there are two types of retracements when it comes to time. I will give you here the same impulse as before. I will put the same retracement. Notice that I will take the same height of the retracement we were making here. This would be its retracement. I would measure the retracement with my fibo. Same situation, right? Okay, there is the retracement we call fast and there is the retracement we call slow. There are retracements that go directly to 130 and take very little time. This is what we call fast retracements. They make the retracement at whatever height, but quickly generate the new impulse to form the next fractal. But I’ll tell you one thing, fast retracements are very easy to see. Any novice trader sees fast retracements well on a chart. But you need to understand, charts are always manipulated. You are in this business with your little account, someone allows you to participate in this business, someone allows you to start investing from a broker without having any idea, what happens? Well, today anyone can open an account with 50 euros and they don’t ask you to know anything. That is, here they do not do any kind of exam, they do not require you to have half a million euros in your bank account, they ask for nothing. You have to know where you are getting into. You are entering a jungle where you are allowed to enter, you and many others, me for example, you are allowed in with one single intention. What is it? To take your money. Exactly, because if they allowed retail, as it is called, ordinary people to put their money in here it’s because they’re sure of one thing. First, you are all going to leave your money here and second, the charts you work with are managed by them. You put liquidity into the market and the same people always take it. This is not the best business in the world as people believe. No, no, no, no. You are here or they allow you to be here because there are millions of people like you who leave their money here. When we talk about charts, and now I delve into the chart which is what we are seeing now, in this of slow retracements and fast retracements, which is the first example I give you of what you will find, I need you to understand that the charts will not be clean charts, they will not be charts with fast retracements, that clearly show the retracement, a linear retracement that you measure, a retracement without any kind of lines straight, no. They want your money and a very simple way to take your money is that when you see the chart with your system, with your analysis, with the way you have decided to look at the charts, the more confusing it is, the easier you lose it. Forget about this being easy. No, it’s not easy, if it were, they wouldn’t have let you in. If it were easy, they wouldn’t have let you in. What I mean by this is that if we are saying that markets are impulse, retracement, impulse, retracement, impulse, retracement, they will be impulses and retracements with the intention to confuse you as much as possible. Most of the retracements you will find are not fast, they are not pretty, they are not clean to see, they are not easy to analyze, they are not easy to... I hope I make myself understood. Most retracements will be like this, slow, because people here no longer know what they are seeing. Imagine this retracement that started here and now look at what this damn retracement is. Now it comes back here and drops here and now suddenly it goes back up here again and now suddenly it goes back down here. This is still a retracement, what happens is that it is stretched out over time. It is a slow retracement. Has it touched the 130? No, the retracement is not over.

decision_points.if_true: Retracement is still ongoing
decision_points.if_false: Retracement can be considered complete
decision_points.quote_es: Mientras el precio no haga esto y toque el 130, yo no puedo decir que ese retroceso ha concluido.
decision_points.quote_en: As long as the price doesn’t do this and touch the 130, I cannot say that the retracement has concluded.

concepts.name: Fractal
concepts.definition: A series of market movements characterized by a repetitive pattern that can reflect major changes in price behavior.
concepts.relationship: Forms part of a cycle of impulses and retracements; a new fractal often indicates a change in trend.

concepts.name: 130% Fibonacci level
concepts.definition: A custom Fibonacci level used to determine when a retracement is considered complete.
concepts.relationship: Part of measuring retracements to confirm when a price movement has concluded.

concepts.name: Fast and Slow Retracements
concepts.definition: Retracements vary in speed; fast ones quickly reach 130, while slow ones take longer, causing confusion.
concepts.relationship: They challenge traders’ understanding and analysis, often manipulated to trap retail traders.

rules.rule: A retracement is not considered complete until the price touches the 130% Fibonacci level.
rules.context: When analyzing retracements to determine the end of a price movement and the beginning of a new impulse.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the complexity of market retracements and the importance of measuring them accurately using Fibonacci levels. He explains the distinct nature of fast and slow retracements, with fast retracements quickly indicating a new impulse, while slow ones prolong over time creating confusion among traders. Vega warns beginners about the manipulated nature of trading charts used by brokers to exploit inexperienced retail traders. He underscores the key rule that a retracement is incomplete unless the price reaches the 130% Fibonacci level, distinguishing between understanding market trends and falling into traps.

title: Good/Bad Use of Partials

analysis.translation: This type of trading, where I go for very long targets, has a lot of errors. I say this because of the partials issue. And it's very dangerous. Why? Because it's true that when I catch one of these, not only do I recover the mistakes I've made, but I make money. What happens? That when you have a streak where you don't get these, you don't get this winner, in the end what happens is that your account survives based on the partial you got. It certainly won't cause you a huge loss. But keep in mind that while the winner doesn't arrive, I want you to understand something, I'm going to have a huge streak of losers. And when I say losers, I mean break-evens. Whether I take partials earlier or later, this kind of big exit, it's like those partials just help you to maintain the account until your winning streak arrives. Because even though you see that they are very long ratios, there are also winning streaks. The moment you start getting 2, 3, 4, 5 moves, the account goes up a lot. And it compensates you a lot for all that time you have been surviving on partials. I don't look for huge partials. Notice how, for example, I might go to seek this target and my first and only partial is here, in this 61 area with that blue. And notice that I don't take more. Someone might say, heck, you take one there, you take another one here. I don't know, you take another one here. I don't know, you take another one here. No. No, because that unbalances my statistics. Why? Because in the end, yes, you take a very long ride, but since you have been releasing, releasing, releasing, in the end, those 700 pips are not 700 pips. Yes, the final position reaches 700 pips, but the amount of money you have made there with so many partials doesn't give me statistically to compensate for the error. That's why I'm not taking partials, taking partials, taking. Mind you, I'm not saying it's wrong. Normally, the issue of partials, everyone interprets it their way. I simply interpret mine. If someone tells me, well look, I prefer, I am much more conservative than you, here I take partial, here I take partial, here I take partial, here I take partial. In other words, as the price gives me reason, I'm taking, taking, taking. And that's totally correct. But it will depend a lot on your type of statistics. Because in the end, this journey of I don't know how many pips here, you will have gotten what you took here, what you took here, what you took here, here, here. And in the end, it will have given you some money. Because in the end, here, never forget that behind everything you do here are numbers. I'm not saying it's better to apply some numbers than others when it comes to making money. I'm not saying that. But logically, in this movement, you and I, for example, someone who has done partial, partial, partial, partial, partial, partial and in the end, the price actually reached here. That person, compared to me, where in the same movement I only took one partial here and did not take anything for the rest of the movement, well, it is obvious that if you stop to think about it, it's safer, so to speak. It's more reassuring, so to speak. Because in the end, imagine that the price goes from here to both you and me, it's the same movement, you will have taken 1, 2, 3. You in that operation that in the end does this, earn more than I do because I only took one partial. And in the end, my stops will have been triggered, your stops will have been triggered, but since I took one partial and you three, you earn more than I do. Then we have to evaluate what numbers we use, what numbers we have, what error we have, how we add, how we lose. There is no better way. Many ask me about how to use partials. And I always say, if you are a person who does not tolerate that many times you take that partial there and look at the amount of journey you have here, since you take the partial until the end target, look at the amount of journey you have there. Once you and I have taken the same partial in the same place and even though we have the same potential target, let's assume it, imagine it, which is this level, this person is predetermined because they will take different partials. And I say, I don't take more. What happens? That I risk in any part of this journey, which in this example I'm making up is 900 bits, it could be 100, 200, depending on the case, I am making this up, it can turn around. It's not just that it can turn around, it's that in the majority of cases it will turn around. I know it. In any of this space, it can turn around and I am left with the partial already screwed over because the other positions will be protected. So, what happens? That most of the time it turns around. I will try that when it turns around to try to catch it with some coverage, but many times I do not catch coverage. Therefore, I will be left watching. Heck, this price went 200 bits in my favor and now screwed over, boom, it turns around. This happens to me endlessly. That's why I say that most times, while I do not catch the good trades, the account is maintained with small partials. So, of course, you have to be worthy of this. This is a very difficult operation in the mental sense, not numerical. It is simple as heck. Heck, I take a partial and hope it reaches my final target. Technically, it is very simple. It's a technique that when it wins, it wins a lot. When you get the good ones, it wins a lot, but until you catch them, you have to have a strong mental fortitude. This is not the best way to do it. Therefore, another person can tell me, look, I'm going to seek the same goals as you in terms of distance, but I can't do this operation. I take partial, take partial, take partial and let it turn around when it wants, but I take partial each step of I don't know how much because I am much calmer in that operation and because my curve of results is more stable. And I tell you, you are absolutely right. The difference between these ways of taking more partials or fewer partials, of taking partials closer or taking partials further away, what differentiates them are two things. First, the numbers. The numbers must match. And two, you have to withstand it. That is why I insist so much that the option of partials, one partial or 2 or 3 or 4, or taking it earlier or taking it later, is something very, very, very personal. There is no better way than another. If now, at this moment, we all worked with partials and each of us used that concept of partial differently, none of the 10 is right. None of the 10 could say, my way is the best. That does not exist, especially for those starting out. Understand that there is a secret or there is a magic formula for the use of the partial. I always told you that the partial is not designed to make money, it is designed for the operator's peace of mind. So, we are talking about a subjective concept, the operator's peace of mind. Then we will have to see what the operator is like because the 10 operators are going to be different. We are not going to achieve the point of tranquility in the same place. Just as I tell you the bad, in this case of my way, the bad is that I can have very long periods where my targets do not arrive. Now, I also tell you that it is the way to make the most money. It is the way to make the most money because unlike this person who is with partials when I see that the position is going well, not only will I not take partials from the sales, but I will be trying to put more positions to the movement. So, notice how this person, for their mental tranquility, intends for this movement to be done perhaps with, I don't know, 2, 3, 4, 5 partials and indeed reaches the end and will have taken out x money with a terrific operational tranquility for him. However, I do not want to take more initial partials, only one, which is the one that protects me, let's say. And in return, if the movement goes in my favor, I want to put in more. That is, I want to go down as loaded as possible. However, this person, as he goes out, reaches down practically with nothing. So, it is neither better nor worse, they are very different operations. What I do want to tell you is, this is a way of working that gives you much more calm, gives the operator much more calm and more stable numbers. That is, there is a mental calm that this operation produces, however, this operation is much more aggressive. And in the drawback that it is much more aggressive and that the movement does not always occur and that many times, most of the time, it turns around. Now, when you take the complete move from above and have been able to incorporate more positions, this operation that has given me all that is as if this person had done 7 or 8 operations of this type. I earn the same as him in 7 or 8. So you can see that there is a good part and a bad part to any way of trading. The secret is not thinking which one is better, but which one suits you best. I never tire of repeating this to you. Do not focus on how I do it. Do not focus on how the other does it. Focus on the concept that Joaquín tells you, there is a concept called partial, there is a very interesting concept to work with called partial, which serves to relieve pressure at certain moments of a trade and tells you that you should try to find the right point not only in the number of partials you use, but in the moment you use them. And forget about what Joaquín does.

concepts.name: partial profit taking
concepts.definition: A technique where traders take portions of their position off the table to secure small profits, aiming to maintain account stability until more significant winning trades occur.
concepts.relationship: This concept is connected to risk management as it helps relieve pressure and manage emotional responses during trading.

concepts.name: mental fortitude
concepts.definition: The psychological resilience required to maintain composure during noise in the market, especially when trades are prone to turn around.
concepts.relationship: Mental fortitude influences the decision to apply partial profit-taking, as traders must balance emotional comfort with statistical outcomes.

rules.rule: Evaluate the statistical impact of taking multiple partial profits.
rules.context: When planning to execute large target trades with few exits.

rules.rule: Balance risk and emotional comfort based on your trading style.
rules.context: When deciding the use and frequency of partials.

rules.rule: Determine your own optimal strategy for partials based on your trading personality.
rules.context: While developing a personalized trading plan.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses the techniques and mental aspects of trading with partial exits. He explains the balance between securing small profits with partials and holding positions for potentially larger gains. Joaquín emphasizes the importance of personalizing trading strategies to suit individual psychological and statistical needs. He outlines that there is no single best approach to using partials, and traders must find the method that aligns with their personal metrics and comfort. Joaquín also stresses that mental fortitude is crucial when maintaining positions through market fluctuations.

title: Students Preferred Ratios

analysis.translation: The question I've been asked, Joaquín, from all the students who at least don't lose or are already winning, could you tell me or do you have any statistics about the profit ratios and post-entry management that are most commonly used? Yes, I do know. Let me explain it. These are ratios that I always tell you that we need to have certain profit-taking strategies and a post-entry management that makes us comfortable. Without a doubt, without that, we won't be able to repeat it. Regardless of what it can generate, if I don't repeat, there's no income. Therefore, the first thing you need to look for in ratios plus post-entry management is that it is repetitive. If you can't repeat it, no ratio or management will serve you. decision_points.condition: price reaches 1 to 1 or 1 to 2
decision_points.if_true: move stop to half
decision_points.if_false: maintain original stop
decision_points.quote_es: Cuando el precio está en el 1 a 1 o otros en el 1 a 2, colocan el stop a la mitad. Se acabó la gestión.
decision_points.quote_en: When the price is at 1 to 1 or others at 1 to 2, they place the stop at half. That ends the management.

decision_points.condition: price reaches 1 to 1 with fractional entry
decision_points.if_true: take partial profit and move stop to half
decision_points.if_false: continue without partial
decision_points.quote_es: Al 1 a 1 sacan parcial, stop a la mitad.
decision_points.quote_en: They take partial at 1 to 1, stop at half.

concepts.name: 1 to 4 ratio
concepts.definition: A risk-reward ratio where traders aim for four times the initial risk.
concepts.relationship: Connected to entry strategies and how comfortable a trader feels with risk management.

concepts.name: Fractional entry
concepts.definition: Entering the market in parts rather than all at once, typically in two parts.
concepts.relationship: Affects how profit is taken and stops are managed.

concepts.name: Repetition
concepts.definition: The importance of repeating a trading strategy consistently for effectiveness.
concepts.relationship: Linked to psychological comfort and trade management success.

rules.rule: Move stop to half when price reaches 1 to 1 or 1 to 2.
rules.context: Used for both single and fractional entries for risk management.

rules.rule: Use a 1 to 4 risk-reward ratio for comfortable trading.
rules.context: Applies to traders who find it repeatable and suits both single and fractional entries.

rules.rule: It is crucial to find a personal management style that fits the trader.
rules.context: To increase psychological comfort and overall trading success.

analysis.summary: The video explains the importance of finding a comfortable and repeatable trading strategy using a 1 to 4 risk-reward ratio. It highlights the significance of post-entry management and how the choice between single and fractional entries affects traders' psychological comfort. By outlining different management techniques, such as moving stops and taking partial profits, Joaquín Vega emphasizes that personal management styles differ among traders. The video advises against stubbornness in sticking to methods that do not suit one's trading temperament, advocating for personal assessment to find the most fitting approach.

decision_points.condition: Price forms a cycle at 38 and experiences a failure of those highs
decision_points.if_true: Start breaking the lows, any 61.8 is a reason to sell
decision_points.if_false: Price continues its current pattern, no sell action
decision_points.quote_es: a partir de aquí ya cualquier 61.8, esto ya era motivo de venta
decision_points.quote_en: From here any 61.8 was already a reason to sell

decision_points.condition: Price exceeds a 10% floating of current balance
decision_points.if_true: Need to secure profits, close some positions
decision_points.if_false: Let the remaining position run to the final targets
decision_points.quote_es: llevamos más de un 10% siempre os digo en flotante que tenemos que coger beneficios
decision_points.quote_en: When we go over 10% I always tell you in floating that we have to take profits

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A specific price level from which a significant price movement is expected, defining the point from which an impulse and retracement cycle typically begins.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a starting point for identifying potential buy and sell signals based on cycle completion, often followed by monitoring for failure of highs or lows.

concepts.name: 61.8% Retracement
concepts.definition: A critical Fibonacci level at which price retracement often signals a reversal or continuation, and an important level for triggering buy/sell decisions.
concepts.relationship: Identified following the Point of Control and cyclical analysis to confirm entry and exit points for trades.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: The repeating patterns in market movements that allow for predictability; its presence or absence affects trade decisions based on methodology.
concepts.relationship: Links to the overall market conditions, offering clarity on when to apply or refrain from applying certain methodologies.

rules.rule: Any descending movement to 61.8% from a valid structure is a strong reason to sell.
rules.context: Applicable after observing key market structure breakdowns from the Point of Control.

rules.rule: When floating gains exceed 10% of total balance, secure profits by taking partial profits.
rules.context: When an existing trade significantly increases account equity, ensure to solidify gains.

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega discusses the challenges of trading gold using a modified Fibonacci method, emphasizing the importance of fractality and structured market behavior. He details specific conditions, such as reaching a 61.8% retracement, as key decision points for entering and exiting trades. Vega stresses that traders should not focus on macroeconomic reasons but rather on chart-based evidence for decision-making. Additionally, he highlights the necessity of managing both losses and floating profits with strict guidelines, ensuring consistent profitability even during volatile market conditions.

decision_points.condition: Price reaches a small extremity and initiates movement without reaching 25%
decision_points.if_true: The origin of the movement isn't correct and may return to 25%
decision_points.if_false: Price may fall further without reaching 25%
decision_points.quote_es: ¿Esto es un origen de movimiento correcto? No. ¿Por qué no? Porque no ha llegado al 25%.
decision_points.quote_en: Is this a correct movement origin? No. Why not? Because it hasn't reached 25%.

decision_points.condition: Price breaks 161.8% and goes to 200%
decision_points.if_true: Attempt a trade at this level with a buffer for the spike
decision_points.if_false: Consider another strategy if it doesn't arrive
decision_points.quote_es: Si el precio rompe este nivel 161.8 y viene al 200, ¿yo te voy a intentar aquí? Sí.
decision_points.quote_en: If the price breaks this 161.8 and comes to 200, would I try it here? Yes.

decision_points.condition: Price takes out liquidity from stops and maintains movement
decision_points.if_true: Seek trades with the identified context and liquidity levels
decision_points.if_false: Consider alternative strategies or wait for more data
decision_points.quote_es: Lo que quiero son fractales limpios... Esto sí que lo quiero ver. Es objetivo, repetitivo.
decision_points.quote_en: What I want are clean fractals... I do want to see this. It is objective, repetitive.

concepts.name: movement origin correctness
concepts.definition: A movement origin must reach a certain percentage (usually 25%) to be considered correct and potentially return to previous levels.
concepts.relationship: It dictates when a price movement might return to an earlier level, connecting retracement levels and trade potential.

concepts.name: fractal favorability
concepts.definition: The idea that price should create a pattern of lower lows (or higher highs) to confirm movement in a direction.
concepts.relationship: It assists in judging the momentum and direction strength, connected to control points and extensions like 161.8% and 200%.

concepts.name: contextual liquidity levels
concepts.definition: Using historical price points where liquidity is likely stored to predict where price may react.
concepts.relationship: These levels are spotted as key locations for partial trades and are essential for decision-making alongside fractals and extensions.

rules.rule: Don't solely base trades on one direction, consider both longs and shorts.
rules.context: When price is in a selling zone but there are signals of potential for a long direction.

rules.rule: Mark levels based on historical data and use them to inform trade decisions.
rules.context: Always refer to past movements to understand current price actions and potential reactions.

rules.rule: Wait for confirmed breakout of control points before committing to trade further movements.
rules.context: Requires objectively confirming a price move's strength by breaking key levels, using extensions like 38.2%.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses trading the SP500 using a modified Fibonacci methodology focusing on fractal analysis and liquidity levels. He emphasizes observing past and present price actions to construct an objective basis for trading decisions, advocating for awareness of both long and short opportunities depending on the context. Key concepts include ensuring movement origin correctness and utilizing contextual liquidity levels for partial decisions. Moreover, he highlights the importance of verifying momentum through fractal favorability and breaking historical control points before deciding on trade directions. Overall, the trading strategy requires a comprehensive understanding of context and methodical observation.

decision_points.if_false: Re-evaluate strategy based on price behavior.

concepts.name: Pattern 1 and Pattern 2
concepts.definition: Objective measurements to evaluate market zones and price movements.
concepts.relationship: Serve as a basis for forming hypotheses regarding future price movements.

concepts.name: 161.8% and 200% Fibonacci Levels
concepts.definition: Key retracement and extension levels used to set expectations for price targets.
concepts.relationship: Indicators for probable price movements after patterns are established.

concepts.name: Liquidity Zones
concepts.definition: Areas where there’s a concentration of buy/sell orders; entering trades here based on how price interacts.
concepts.relationship: Primary factor considered in conjunction with patterns and price action for trade entry decisions.

rules.rule: If price reaches predetermined zones with a certain pattern setup, expect it to hit the 161.8% or higher.
rules.context: Applies when assessing potential price targets from completed patterns in selling zones.

rules.rule: Do not take action based solely on time noise; focus on pattern completion and zone interactions.
rules.context: When observing price before decisive price action has completed.

rules.rule: Enter trades at liquidity zones where price has confirmed a pattern.
rules.context: When both patterns and liquidity align in trading strategy.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses his modified Fibonacci methodology, focusing on identifying trading opportunities by analyzing patterns and specific price levels like 161.8% and 200%. He emphasizes the importance of observing context, such as liquidity zones, rather than getting distracted by price noise. The video highlights how to measure price movements objectively and structure trading hypotheses based on defined rules. The discussion covers adjusting strategies when market conditions change and reinforces the importance of maintaining consistent patterns in the decision-making process.

concepts.name: Fibonacci Cycle
concepts.definition: A sequence of price movements designated by Fibonacci levels used to predict reversals and entry points.
concepts.relationship: Key levels like 38%, 61.8%, and 200% serve as signal points for buys or sells.

concepts.name: Partial Taking
concepts.definition: Taking profits at certain Fibonacci levels to secure gains during a trend.
concepts.relationship: Used along with key Fibonacci retracements to gradually secure profit from trades.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: The price level with the highest amount of trading activity, used to adjust the trade map.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a reference for identifying potential reversals or continuation points.

rules.rule: Enter sell positions at the 161.8% Fibonacci retracement for cycles.
rules.context: When the price reaches this level and is aligned with the anticipated cycle.

rules.rule: Take partial profits at 38% Fibonacci levels during downtrends.
rules.context: To secure gains at the beginning of potential pullbacks.

rules.rule: Evaluate entry validity by ensuring the price action aligns with cycle projections.
rules.context: Ensure trades are within the expected path of movement based on Fibonacci levels.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega explains his modified Fibonacci trading strategy, emphasizing the importance of identifying key levels like 61.8% and 161.8% retracements to determine trade entries and exits. He discusses the intricacies of managing complex situations involving multiple Fibonacci levels, balancing between ideal entries and potential reversals. Vega highlights the need for trade maps, using the point of control to anticipate price movement accurately. The video teaches a practical approach to using Fibonacci cycles and levels, taking partial profits, and adapting trade strategies dynamically.

concepts.name: 161.8% retracement
concepts.definition: A key level in Fibonacci analysis where price may attempt to retrace repeatedly.
concepts.relationship: Often a precursor to reaching or attempting to reach 200% level.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A level formed in market dynamics where price often consolidates or reverses.
concepts.relationship: Acts as potential entry point for both long and short attempts.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: The characteristic of market movements that allows similar patterns to be observed across different timeframes.
concepts.relationship: Necessitates retracements at key Fibonacci levels to engage effectively.

rules.rule: If on the first attempt the price fails to go down from 161.8, expect the move to continue with failures towards 200.
rules.context: When trading indices or commodities with large distance between levels.

rules.rule: Rely on points of control to enter long trades, especially when anticipating move towards 200 level.
rules.context: When engaging in long trades during potential upside.

rules.rule: Apply trading methods consistent with fractal analysis and confirm entries with minimum 61.8 retracements.
rules.context: During volatile market conditions with vertical movements.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega provides an analysis of trading patterns in the SP500 using a modified Fibonacci methodology, focusing on levels such as 161.8% and 200%. He emphasizes the importance of understanding price behavior within these zones, suggesting that if the 161.8% level does not hold, price may proceed to the 200% level through a series of failures. Vega explains the concept of 'Points of Control' as potential entry points for both long and short trades, while stressing the complexity of entering long positions amidst short fractality movements. He encourages traders to apply methodological consistency and adapt to varying market conditions.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: Describes the consistent and coherent behavior of market cycles typical in the trading framework.
concepts.relationship: Connects to cycle identification and trading strategy, influencing buy and sell decisions.

concepts.name: Control Points
concepts.definition: Key levels used to evaluate and confirm market direction, which are crucial for operational decisions.
concepts.relationship: Utilized alongside Fibonacci levels to determine entry, partial, and exit points in a trade.

concepts.name: 38% Level
concepts.definition: Fibonacci retracement level that initiates buying zones upon touch, indicating a potential trend reversal.
concepts.relationship: Links with the activation of market cycles and coincides with zone convergence for buy decisions.

rules.rule: Activate purchase zones when the price touches the 38% Fibonacci level.
rules.context: Used as a signal to potentially enter a trade in anticipation of a bullish movement.

rules.rule: Take partial profits at key resistance points like the red level.
rules.context: Implemented when a trade reaches a predefined level to reduce risk and secure gains.

rules.rule: Anticipate strong market moves when a significant level is broken.
rules.context: When price approaches key levels repeatedly, prepare for breakout trades due to potential volatility.

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega analyzes price movements in gold using a modified Fibonacci methodology. Emphasizing the importance of fractality and consistent pattern recognition, he highlights how touching certain levels, like the 38% retracement, can activate buying zones. Control points are essential to manage entries and exits, with specific focus on levels such as the 61.8% and critical resistance areas. He underscores the necessity of monitoring concurrent key levels for potential strong breakouts, preparing for any significant price moves. Joaquín consistently advises assessing both buying and selling opportunities, aligning with his methodology of double directional consideration in trading decisions.

concepts.name: failure activation
concepts.definition: A price condition triggering a planned trading response, expected to reach further levels.
concepts.relationship: Initiates the move towards the 200 level, suggesting further price action potential.

concepts.name: partial profit-taking
concepts.definition: Exiting a portion of a position at a profit while letting the rest run.
concepts.relationship: Ensures some profit is locked in, making the remaining position easier to manage psychologically.

concepts.name: liquidity zones
concepts.definition: Areas where orders are clustered, potentially causing rapid price movements when hit.
concepts.relationship: A key stimulus for anticipating further price movement based on liquidity breaks.

rules.rule: Decide on partial take-profit levels at entry to secure the trade.
rules.context: When entering multiple positions in a trade.

rules.rule: Accept that the majority of positions won't be super-winners but stick to the plan for the potential big moves.
rules.context: In strategic decision making for longer-term trades.

analysis.summary: In this trading education video, Joaquín Vega discusses a strategic approach to trading using a modified Fibonacci methodology, focusing on understanding price movements and decision points. He emphasizes the need for setting clear entry, partial profit-taking, and exit points to manage trades psychologically. The video highlights the importance of embracing potential position failures to capture larger price movements. Despite most trades not being super-winners, this disciplined approach captures substantial gains when successful. Liquidity zones and psychological resilience are significant themes, providing insights into enduring market fluctuations.

concepts.name: liquidity grabs
concepts.definition: Using points where liquidity is gathered, often identified by price reversals at key levels, to make trading decisions.
concepts.relationship: Can be used within a strategy to determine entries and exits by aligning with cycles in the reading model.

concepts.name: reading model
concepts.definition: A method for interpreting chart movements independently from specific trading strategies, focusing on understanding potential price directions.
concepts.relationship: Provides the foundation for deciding how and where to deploy strategies such as liquidity grabs.

concepts.name: attack model
concepts.definition: The strategy for executing trades based on the reading of the charts; includes methods for entering and exiting positions.
concepts.relationship: Must be developed after assessing the reading model to ensure coherent and informed trading.

rules.rule: Use a reading model to understand where the price is likely to move.
rules.context: Before deploying any trading strategy or making trading decisions.

rules.rule: Do not rely solely on the YouTube videos for a strategy, they only provide a reading model.
rules.context: While learning trading methodologies and formulating personal trading strategies.

rules.rule: A strategy requires integrating a reading model with risk management and execution plans.
rules.context: When formulating a comprehensive trading approach.

analysis.summary: This video by Joaquín Vega covers a modified Fibonacci methodology with a focus on separating reading models from trading strategies. He emphasizes the importance of understanding a reading model that interprets chart movements without dictating specific strategies. Liquidity grabs are discussed as part of a strategy, aligned with cycle-based readings, as one of many methods to execute trades. Vega clarifies misconceptions about his YouTube content, accentuating the need for individual strategies incorporating personal risk management, entry and exit plans. He advises traders to develop unique strategies that complement their reading models.

title: PRÁCTICA PARA BUSCAR EN TRADING LOS PUNTOS DE CONTROL DE UN GRÁFICO. Joaquín Vega.
