decision_points.condition: Price must surpass the fractal high by at least one third of the retracement height.
decision_points.if_true: This point is considered a valid control point.
decision_points.if_false: The breakout is considered false, and the point is not validated.
decision_points.quote_es: Yo necesito que el precio supere ese nivel, al menos con un tercio de la altura que tiene ese retroceso.
decision_points.quote_en: I need the price to surpass that level, at least by a third of the retracement's height.

decision_points.condition: A new retracement is larger than previous ones.
decision_points.if_true: Previous control points become obsolete if the new retracement validates.
decision_points.if_false: Previous control points remain valid.
decision_points.quote_es: Pero si por delante se produce un retroceso de mayor altura, [...] ese punto de control ya no sirve nunca más.
decision_points.quote_en: But if a retracement of greater height occurs ahead, [...] that point of control will no longer serve at any time.

decision_points.condition: Price surpasses the level by one third of the retracement height.
decision_points.if_true: The point of control is validated and the fractal evolution continues.
decision_points.if_false: The price is considered still within minor fractality.
decision_points.quote_es: Tienes que romper 110 pips. [...] me dices que tú estás validado.
decision_points.quote_en: You have to break 110 pips. [...] you tell me you are validated.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: A series of impulse movements that form a sequence of highs and lows; minor fractals lead to major fractals.
concepts.relationship: Minor movements evolve into major movements, making previous ones obsolete.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: Specific price levels validated by surpassing fractal highs by a third of the retracement height.
concepts.relationship: Used to confirm and transition between minor and major fractals.

concepts.name: 61.8% retracement
concepts.definition: Although not explicitly mentioned, it's implied as a Fibonacci level where price retracement is measured and decisions are made.
concepts.relationship: Part of the Fibonacci methodology to evaluate price movements.

rules.rule: A point of control is validated by surpassing the fractal high by at least a third of the retracement height.
rules.context: When determining the validity of potential control points on a price chart.

rules.rule: If a current retracement is greater than previous ones, and is validated, then previous control points become obsolete.
rules.context: During analysis of ongoing fractality and validation of control points.

rules.rule: Work only with valid points of control and evolved fractals to avoid trading noise.
rules.context: When identifying potential trade entries based on geometric patterns.

analysis.summary: This video explains how to identify and validate points of control in a trading chart using a modified Fibonacci methodology. Joaquin Vega focuses on the concept of fractality, where minor trends lead to major trends, making earlier points obsolete if newer ones are validated. A point of control is established by price surpassing a previous high by one third of the retracement. Traders are encouraged to rely on current validated fractals and control points to create trading opportunities, avoiding past elements that might become noise in analysis.

title: FRACTALIDAD Y ROTURAS DE NIVEL. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: It is very important to understand one thing. When we were in the first fractal or in any of the fractals, when we were in this sideways movement and we didn't know if the price would break up or down, the moment the price actually breaks in the same direction as the impulse of the previous fractal, in this case, the low or high, if it were a bearish case, which the price leaves us, that lowest or highest point, if it were a bearish case, that highest point that the retracement of the fractality leaves us, we call these control points. These control points will be extremely important for us. We will detail them more later. The correct fractality point that remains when the price breaks, in this case, the minimum that was originated by the previous fractality or the maximum that originated the previous fractality. These control points will be explained in detail because, together with the origins of movements, they are the most important points of any sequence, whether bullish or bearish. We’ll detail them much better. But of course, here we face another problem. What is the problem? Look, when I developed all these concepts I tried to make everything as objective as possible. That there would be no doubts about the things we are working on, the concepts I teach you, they couldn't have any kind of subjectivity, but I acknowledge that some things have been very difficult, such as the concept of a break. When I am in this sideways movement, how much does the price have to exceed that previous maximum to say that there really is a break? How long should it stay out? How do we measure whether the break is made or not? It would happen the same here below. How much must the price pass that level to say I have a break either above or below? This is a very subjective concept. No one agrees on this. Some people, the big gurus say that with a pip, with a point that exceeds that level or with a point or a pip that passes this level, the break can already be considered done. But I disagree. And I am going to define very clearly at what moment we will consider that this is a correct break. For example, in this case, we would say that the impulse of the next fractal has already started, we have to have the concept very, very, very clear. Look, when people are looking at this, when people are looking at this fractal, people do not realize they are working in a lateral movement. People are thinking that if the price comes and surpasses that level, I will buy. If the price comes and surpasses this level, I will sell. This is what the public is thinking. The vast majority because in the tests I did with students, this is what they have told me. We are doing this with a simple fractal. If the price exceeds that level, the public will buy. If the price exceeds this level, the public will sell. Therefore, can I say that is a break? The answer is no. Why not? Because there's a magical word called counterpart. If everyone here is going to buy and if I know that everyone here is going to sell, the institutional knows it too. And it means that in each of our fractals there are two zones where the price can be manipulated because they can find the counterpart they need. They know perfectly what the public will do in each fractal. One after another, one after another, one after another, they know. If I were institutional, I know that everyone there will buy. Therefore, I would have the option to sell there because I will find sufficient counterpart. And here, the opposite. If we apply this to the concept of a break, under no circumstances am I going to apply a PIP. If I know they do it in zones, how am I going to consider that a single PIP is enough? Therefore, we will set fundamental rules. We will say that there is an exceedance and therefore a valid control point because the impulse of the next fractal has already been formed, only if the price exceeds that level with at least one third of the height of the retracement that has formed. In this case, the height of this retracement is this. For me to say that there is a break you have had to exceed one third of this height. I’m putting it here for you to see. This is so simple when we are in a chart as to measure that in PIPs, divide by three and from that point, from the maximum that originated the retracement, it should have exceeded at least a third part of that height. Therefore, while you do not exceed that height, I do not say that we have a correct control point here, and therefore we have a correct break and therefore we have initiated the impulse of the next fractal. If you do this, it’s not possible for you to go back in. I remain the same, still in the same sideways. The price can fall. I remain in the same sideways, I will only validate as a control point the lowest point of the sideways and the price may try again. You have to always surpass the point that originated the retracement never take false breaks, you will have a thousand false breaks. I only validate the lowest point, that point is worthless it is false it is manipulation no, I keep sideways still the same and if you do this you have to break a third, and it is possible to make another false break, I still validate the lowest point if you make a lower point that would not be the point I should validate if this now goes up we have a new possible point of validation, the lowest and therefore the height has changed no longer the same number of pips or points that you now have to validate because the degree of the retracement has changed now you have to exceed that new height that no longer counts you will be crushed with slow retracements they will crush you with false breaks over and over and over and over you will have to master this perfectly and we will do it I will always need you to understand the concept first so that later when applying it in practice is easier so always concept first if this goes back again, it's not still the same point you have to break, do not take false breaks they will fool you, your sight will deceive you concept over and over again concept is that the height that is the point that originated all this sideways we remain sideways but with false breaks over and over over only when the price does there can I say that this control point is now correct and that the impulse of the next fractal has been initiated that at some point will give me a new retracement and therefore a new sideways only there all this was a slow retracement with false breaks constant constant constant we have to master this aspect we have to understand that the only valid correct point within these continuous laterals which leave us thousands of points that will confuse us is only correct the lowest point or the highest point in the bearish case for us to use it for any possible analysis we will also use them a lot they are fundamental points everything I could take from here is wrong and what I take from here is wrong always the lowest point always a correct validation control points beware of false breaks that deceive the public because the public buys as soon as the price breaks they deceive you they re-enter positions they deceive you again they re-enter positions and when they have everything in they generate the new impulse we will have to master this perfectly seen in concept I know it's a bit boring without a doubt the next thing we will have to see is in chart, right? we have to fully control these control points we leave it here review this video as many times as necessary because they are very important aspects from all this that we have seen in this video will come out the rest this is or this is the fundamental basis the understanding of why things happen in a chart the thinking like an institutional never like a small investor understanding that everything is premeditated everything is absolutely calculated that they want our money and they will do whatever is necessary to make us leave our accounts they know the public works with very simple very basic rules they know that the public always works the same and they will take advantage we will never work like the masses

decision_points.condition: Price surpasses a previous high or low by at least one-third of the retracement's height
decision_points.if_true: Establishes a valid control point and indicates a correct break
decision_points.if_false: Remains in a lateral movement or faces false breakouts
decision_points.quote_es: Diremos que hay una superación y por tanto un punto de control válido porque ya se ha formado el impulso del siguiente fractal, sólo si el precio supera ese nivel con al menos un tercio de la altura del retroceso que ha formado.
decision_points.quote_en: We will say there is an exceedance and therefore a valid control point because the impulse of the next fractal has already formed, only if the price exceeds that level with at least one-third of the height of the retracement it has formed.

concepts.name: Control Points
concepts.definition: The lowest or highest point left by a retracement of fractality considered vital for identifying a valid break.
concepts.relationship: They are used with the origins of movements to identify significant points in a sequence.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: The recurring pattern or movement, such as retracements or impulses, in different market conditions or price levels.
concepts.relationship: Fractality provides context for control points and market structure changes.

concepts.name: False Breakouts
concepts.definition: Occurrences when price appears to break a key level but fails to confirm the breakout with sufficient movement.
concepts.relationship: Understand false breakouts to avoid misleading signals when interpreting control points.

concepts.name: Concept of Break
concepts.definition: A subjective notion describing when a price level has been sufficiently exceeded to confirm a market breakout.
concepts.relationship: Needs clear definition using control points to objectively identify genuine breaks.

rules.rule: A valid breakout is only confirmed if the price exceeds a level by at least one-third of the retracement height.
rules.context: When identifying a control point and a proper breakout within a fractal framework.

rules.rule: Ignore false breakouts that do not meet the one-third threshold to avoid being misled.
rules.context: During market analysis to prevent falling into traps set by institutional movements.

rules.rule: Always aim to understand the institutional perspective rather than following the simple rules the public uses.
rules.context: To avoid predictable pitfalls and implement more robust trading strategies.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of identifying control points using a fractal and retracement methodology to differentiate between valid and false breakouts. He discusses how institutional traders can manipulate predictable public actions at these points and advises using a one-third exceedance rule to confirm true market moves. He stresses the necessity of understanding market movements from an institutional perspective, advising against the basic approaches adopted by the general public. Various key concepts, such as the subjective nature of breakouts and the significance of control points, form the basis of his teaching to provide clearer trading insights.

title: En trading, POCO SE HABLA DE LA GESTIÓN DEL FALLO. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: If there's a concept or phrase or number that's overwhelmingly talked about, the one you're most likely to hear about, and undoubtedly the one that's most important to people, without a doubt, it's the accuracy percentage. This number or concept is one of the most concerning to people. Not only when I talk to you individually, the accuracy percentage is tremendously important to you all, but I assume that when you're in a chat, have been at an event, or have been with other investors, without a doubt, this is one of the most important concepts. Do you agree with what I just said? When I meet people of this type, I always reflect the same thing. When you talk about accuracy percentage, you forget it's 100% connected to something called failure. 100% related. You cannot talk about success without talking about failure. People talk about accuracy percentage in isolation. It doesn't serve me that you talk to me about accuracy percentage alone. Only about accuracy percentage doesn't serve me. If I apply common sense, I say to myself only failure is going to destroy me. It's that simple. In other words, when I talk with people about my trading, about my operations, people who are very curious, when I go to an event and they meet me and people come and ask me and such, of course, the usual, right? They get to know you, they come, they ask about your operations, what's the accuracy percentage. They always ask the same questions, but no one asks me about the failure percentage. They ask me about execution, those entries that catch the turn, what's your accuracy percentage, and how much do you risk per operation. They ask all kinds of questions, but no one asks me about failure. No one. It has always caught my attention. Always. How is it possible? 200,000 numbers, 200,000 concepts, like the control point, how you get the cycle, the work of the area, I don't know what pattern and how you enter this pattern, no one asks me about this. When the first question I would ask, imagine that I go to the City of London and, for whatever reason, I meet some investors. Imagine that these investors are working at the best investment fund in all of London and I have the ability and chance to meet them and moreover, have the capacity and chance to talk to them about trading. The bloody first question I'd ask them is what's your failure percentage and how do you manage it? I only want to know how you make money managing failure. Look at what I'm telling you. Why? Because if I know how you handle failure and win, that's what I must value from you, that's what I would value from that person. I wouldn’t ask you anything about your methodology at all, but if you teach me how you manage your failure and if you show me a better way than I do to manage failure, I'd leave there learning a hell of a lot. What do you think about what I'm telling you? Strange? Am I such a weirdo? Now put yourselves in the situation. Do you know that operator from the City? Let's imagine any powerful investment fund, any insurance company, any bank, or any institution. Imagine he's a crack and that his business is highly profitable, and he's the one who controls all of this. The last thing you'd ask him is this. Moreover, you wouldn't even ask him. Do you see the different way of how you see it compared to how I see it? Because I know that successful trader, the secret of his success is in how he manages failure. I know it and he knows it, but you wouldn't be going there thinking like this. Most of you would be thinking, damn, what's your method on the chart? How do you enter? How do you analyze? What's your method? I couldn't care less about his method, but how he manages his loss would be gold to me. Before, I was asked, and how should the mindset think? The mindset should think like this.

decision_points.condition: If the accuracy percentage is discussed as an isolated metric
decision_points.if_true: It's considered meaningless without understanding failure
decision_points.if_false: Could focus on naive understanding of success
decision_points.quote_es: La gente habla de porcentaje de acierto de forma aislada.
decision_points.quote_en: People talk about accuracy percentage in isolation.

decision_points.condition: If talking to a successful trader
decision_points.if_true: Ask about failure percentage and management
decision_points.if_false: Persist with questions about their trading methodology
decision_points.quote_es: La puta primera pregunta que yo les haría es ¿qué porcentaje de fallo tienes y cómo lo gestionas?
decision_points.quote_en: The bloody first question I'd ask them is what's your failure percentage and how do you manage it?

concepts.name: Accuracy Percentage
concepts.definition: The measure of successful trades; often seen as the most important metric by traders.
concepts.relationship: Directly related to understanding and managing failure.

concepts.name: Failure Management
concepts.definition: The process of handling losses in trading to ensure overall profitability.
concepts.relationship: Considered more valuable than any trading methodology.

rules.rule: Understand how to manage failure to succeed in trading.
rules.context: When analyzing or asking about a trader's success.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes that the common trader's focus on accuracy percentage is misguided without considering failure management. He highlights that understanding how to handle failures is more crucial than knowing someone's trading methodology. In discussions with successful traders, he would prioritize questions about managing losses over methods or strategies. The video suggests that evaluating how a trader manages failure is key to learning and success.

title: EL TIMING DE ENTRADA, vital para tener buenos ratios en beneficio.

analysis.translation: Good afternoon, good morning. Hello, I'm Joaquín Vega, Monday, March 16. I'm going to show you a setup I've been eager to start, involving crude oil on a 5-minute chart. We were hoping, based on our long-term charts, for the price to retest these levels around $28.2. We're talking about Texas oil. It's a very important zone where, as long as the price doesn't reach the level of $27.36, if the price reaches this level, we could see much more significant falls, even down to levels of $21.90. But, I insist, as long as that doesn't happen, we are in a zone and at a perfect timing to start long positions. One of the possibilities the map we are working with offers is for a very good upward retracement. Notice that we've come to a 5-minute timeframe to find the right timing for entry, but the main map, and I insist again, as long as the price doesn't reach those levels of $27.36, we might see a very significant upward movement. In fact, as you can see here, this would be the potential path for that rise. There you have it. Up to those levels of $71. It's true that the price will encounter two very important levels. In fact, we're going to take a partial from these three positions we have. We're going to take one out, as a partial, with an upward move of about $9, levels around $38 per barrel, $38.70, there we might see new downward turns. We'll take a second final partial, also as a partial, so that the price could climb about $21.5 to reach levels of $50.88 a barrel. And the final target, as I said, would be for the price to reach those $71 levels. Therefore, we are in a very critical zone within the higher maps, in the sense that we could have a very significant upward bounce. Clearly, the price is just starting the move, but we are planning the possibility of entering here from previous levels, like those. Here, long positions were already being entered, this is the interpretation we are making. This is a zone where the institutions are placing very long positions, and we think this level is the last level where they will place their final positions, and from here we will see a significant turn. Logically, we are at the opening, and there is much ahead, but we stick with that first level, those levels of $38.70 as an important initial rise level. We should start to see almost a $10 rise from there, and from there we can start to think that a good rebound of Texas oil is indeed ahead. We'll wait and see if it's true, let's see what happens. Alright, we continue with the movement, it's very important that it surpasses these levels. Surpassing it somehow strongly, something like this. If it wants it to support and go from there. So far so good. I'll also show you DAX. Look, I talked about timing. Timing, as I've said many times, is always important in any setup with or without volatility, but with volatility, I insist again, it is much more important. Ratios can go through the roof. I'm able to sacrifice, as in this case, two failed previous entries. I don't care if I'm within an important zone where I have information that the map indicates it can be significant. I'm going to take some partials. I'm waiting for the SP500, here you have it. We are also buying. I'm waiting for the price to finally reach these levels. We'll also take a partial now. We'll take a little less. I'm not going to take the partial here, although it's a possible rebound zone. We'll stick with 600 instead of 1,000. But I will go for a final target at those levels of 10,275. So that's 1,930 points. We'll see how these behave then. Possibility of rebound. We'll see if it's just a rebound and continue or break down. The DAX always depends on the SP. And oil. We'll see how they behave at that important level. We'll wait a bit more to see how they behave. Well, to wrap up the video. As you see, oil, deep retracement. Normal. We go to SP too. We've got a retracement. And in the DAX, I've just placed the last position of the day. There you have it. Very specific target path. 400 points to those levels of 9,090, 9,095. concepts.name: Timing
concepts.definition: The optimal moment to enter or exit trades, especially important in volatile markets.
concepts.relationship: Determines trade entry points based on volatility analysis and other market conditions.

concepts.name: Partial profit taking
concepts.definition: Exiting part of a position when a predefined price level is reached to secure profits.
concepts.relationship: Used to manage risk and secure gains while allowing the remainder of the position to continue seeking higher targets.

rules.rule: As long as the price does not reach $27.36, long trades are favored with potential for significant upward movement.
rules.context: Applied to trading Texas oil when analyzing retracement patterns and long-term levels.

rules.rule: Sacrificing failed entries is acceptable to achieve perfect timing on significant price zones.
rules.context: When the map suggests potential for strong moves, even after previous unsuccessful attempts.

analysis.summary: In the video, Joaquín Vega discusses a trading strategy for Texas oil, emphasizing the importance of precise timing, especially in volatile markets. He identifies significant price levels for initiating long positions and potential targets. He highlights the technique of partial profit-taking to manage risk while aiming for higher profits. The use of Fibonacci retracement levels plays a crucial role in identifying critical points for entry and exit decisions. The educator underscores that accurate timing in trading setups can provide substantial advantages even if it means encountering some initial loss trades.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: A measure or condition where observed patterns repeat in favor of a trade direction
concepts.relationship: Used to confirm bearish or bullish bias

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A significant price level from which future price movements can be anticipated
concepts.relationship: Can indicate trend continuation or reversal

concepts.name: Pattern 2
concepts.definition: A specific setup within a larger trading map indicating potential transition
concepts.relationship: Helps define expected price actions and identify entry points

concepts.name: Relevant Level
concepts.definition: A prior significant price threshold that affects future price behavior
concepts.relationship: Breaking these can signal new movements or trend changes

rules.rule: Attempt short positions when price reaches imbalance levels if pattern is unrevealed
rules.context: When DAX is reaching a high part within its mapping zone

rules.rule: Identify and confirm fractality to support trend direction
rules.context: Before taking action on a perceived trend

rules.rule: Trend is only considered broken if it breaks the last upward control cycle
rules.context: When deciding whether a trend is ending

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega discusses his approach to trading using a modified Fibonacci methodology with specific emphasis on understanding market patterns and levels of control. He emphasizes the importance of fractality and relevant levels in planning trades and determining trend directions. Vega provides guidance on attempting short positions based on map conditions, highlighting key decision points and the importance of recognizing significant price levels. Techniques on identifying trend breaks beyond relying on trend lines are explained, allowing traders to justify entries and exits based on clear formations and control points.

concepts.name: Hedging
concepts.definition: Using complementary positions (e.g. two long, several short) to minimize risk or potentially profit regardless of market movement.
concepts.relationship: It pairs with partial positions for effective trade management, by absorbing losses through strategic position balance.

concepts.name: Fractional Entry
concepts.definition: Technique of entering positions over a range to manage entry risk and take advantage of market fluctuations.
concepts.relationship: Its effectiveness can amplify or be limited by hedging strategies.

concepts.name: 61% Retracement
concepts.definition: Common Fibonacci level used to predict potential retracement points in price movement.
concepts.relationship: Acts as a decisive area when adjusting trading strategies such as hedge and partial exits.

concepts.name: Point of Control
concepts.definition: A level originating from previous movements where price tends to react or revert.
concepts.relationship: Vital in forecasting reversals or continuations, crucial for hedging and entry points.

rules.rule: When a prior move indicates a strong level, be prepared for potential reversals or continuations.
rules.context: After strong movements, check past price actions to guide current trading decisions.

rules.rule: Always balance excitement in adding positions with the discipline to remove them if conditions change.
rules.context: During dynamic price conditions and when employing a fractional entry strategy.

rules.rule: Utilize hedging as a safety mechanism rather than solely for profit.
rules.context: When an uncertain market situation arises, ensuring potential losses are offset.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega explains how utilizing hedging in trading can simplify management and reduce risks. He emphasizes the importance of understanding and reacting to price movements, particularly at significant Fibonacci levels, like the 61% retracement. He illustrates the power of hedging by using complementary positions to secure gains while offsetting potential losses. Vega advises traders to be disciplined, equally adept at adding and removing positions based on market conditions. Throughout, he insists that clear comprehension of contexts like fractional entry and points of control is crucial for successful trading decisions.

concepts.name: Hedge
concepts.definition: A strategy using multiple positions, minimally two, in opposing directions to ensure profit regardless of market direction.
concepts.relationship: Used to detach from specific zones or directions, ensuring steady account growth.

concepts.name: Multi-Position Strategy
concepts.definition: Allocating multiple positions (at least two or more) in anticipation of market movement.
concepts.relationship: Works with hedging for risk management and profit maximization.

concepts.name: Zone Indifference
concepts.definition: The lack of preference for any buy/sell zones, as market can reverse at any point.
concepts.relationship: Facilitates hedging and ensures decisions are based on market conditions rather than fixed zones.

concepts.name: Potential Move
concepts.definition: A projected price move based on identified zones regardless of market direction.
concepts.relationship: Helps in determining hedge setup and position allocation.

rules.rule: Always hedge with at least two positions.
rules.context: When potential market direction is uncertain and to secure gains in fluctuating markets.

rules.rule: Hedge positions must be opposite the original trade direction.
rules.context: When price is observed reaching critical zones to protect against reversals.

rules.rule: Ensure partial gains on each market movement.
rules.context: To constantly add to account profitability regardless of whether initial targets are met.

analysis.summary: The video by Joaquín Vega focuses on hedging as an essential part of his trading strategy. He emphasizes using multiple positions to hedge, thereby securing gains irrespective of the market's direction. This approach ensures a stable growth in the trading account by executing trades with a flexible mindset, detached from specific market zones or directions. Vega describes using opposing positions meticulously to dissolve automatically when specific conditions are met. Ultimately, he encourages embracing a strategy that ensures consistent profitability through a combination of strategic entries and exits.

_metadata.title: LAS COBERTURAS, PARTE ESENCIAL DE MI TRADING. Joaquín Vega.

title: En trading, EL TAMAÑO DE TU CUENTA, ES RIDÍCULO. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: I haven't talked to you about patterns at all. I'm asking you how you will distribute your operations. Because if you don't know how many trades you're going to do inside or outside, you have a problem. This doesn't depend on the price, it depends on me. I already know how many trades I'll do in each one of them before I get in. I'm not looking for a reason, I'm just telling you, of those three trades I have and based on the type of zones the price will attack, in this case this zone that has 28 and 42, I can tell you which I work here and which I work there. The only way to have control is to never let the price condition you. Never. You command, you distribute, you do the numbers, you do everything. The price will just move up or down. Nothing more. But everything else you have to know before it happens. One thing is the reason you execute, and another is how you distribute inside or outside. You can't give to everything because you'll break. You must have execution criteria more than defined. And this defined execution criteria first goes by knowing how many trades you'll do here, in this zone. Both inside and outside. Whatever happens. Basically what I'm trying to explain to you is the following. You and I have a problem. You and I, I'm included, have a huge problem you have to be super aware of. You have shitty numbers. You and I. Where are you going with three trades a day? And where are you going with 38 pips per stop? Are you aware? I'm including myself as well. If you are aware of the shitty numbers you have because you don't have the capacity for more. Because we have a shitty account. You and I have a shitty account. I don't care if you have 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 thousand. We are absolutely limited. Both in stop sizes and in number of trades. That's what's happening. What do I mean with this? I mean that those few resources you have, you and I with 20, 30, 40, 50 thousand euros, we are the fucking ridiculous. That's why this happens to us. Therefore, we have to be smart when handling these few resources. Very smart. Why? Because if not, the market will crush us. What do I mean by this? That you can't give everything. You have to be a fucking sniper because you don't have a choice. You don't have a machine gun. You don't have the capacity you would have with half a million. No, sorry. Machine guns are not for you and not for me. You go bullet by bullet and listen, you have three. It's not about what you hunt. It's about the bullet you shoot that doesn't come back. You have to be much more selective. Much more selective. What am I trying to convey to you? If I have three shots. What's easier? Covering both inside and outside or covering just outside or just inside? You have to be aware of your enormous limitation. I know it can go one way or the other. Yes, I know. I'm aware. But dude, I have to understand my limitation. I'll tell you my case. My case. But my case doesn't mean it's what you have to do because I have people who do the opposite and it works for them. That is to say, I decide to always work outside. I decide to work all my zones outside. It's easier to work in a unique outside division than inside outside. Now, what happens with this? Of course, it can make sense. Of course, it makes sense. All my shots I take outside and to hell with it. That way I concentrate better what little I have. Okay, but it has a serious problem. Every time the price comes inside and leaves, this is not for you. Now, that it's not for you is easy to understand, but you have to assume it. And here's the problem. And here's where the problem comes in. But beware, it's not a trading problem. It's a problem in the trader's head. How angry it makes me. There's no anger in trading. There is what there is. Common sense and numbers. There's nothing else. You can say, Joaquín, I'd rather split it all inside. I tell you, it's just as fine. If the zone fails and it comes outside, you fail. Same as I do when working outside and it falls from inside. It's called discipline. I want my trades, not all trades. I don't have the capacity. And when I tell you to decide this, I decide now, before anything happens. I'm not conditioned by the shitty price. I'm not conditioned by what I can't control. I decide how I distribute. I decide if I work outside. I decide with how many trades, with what stops. I decide everything. Now, don't ask me to control that price because it's impossible. But even so, that which is impossible to control is what ends up conditioning you. You won't control it. You have to control everything within your possibility to control. That's first, not losing more than I say I'm going to lose. But I also tell you, that's the easiest. But what about winning? And distributing your operation? It's all important. It's a whole. You can't stick to just one thing. Because each thing has its importance. This is a whole. Students who lose well, their account doesn't drop. But it doesn't go up at all. If you have it clear that your account doesn't drop, that you know how to lose, you need to enhance the other. Then, one of the fundamental parts is this. I execute always the same, I understand my limitation and I commit to always doing exactly my operations in these places. Not in others. Whatever the price does. I'm not interested in anything other than what I want. This is essential. That's why I say, when the price is going to enter a zone, I already know what I'm going to do. Whatever it does. Do you understand that I disregard that price? That I have control? I understand that it will elude me many times. And I also tell you something. When I explain this to you, the typical question is what is better, inside or outside? You ask the wrong question. I always say the same thing. You're asking the wrong question. Why? Because I can assure you something. Whatever you choose. As a fundamental choice of your operation, inside or outside. Whatever you choose. This will go in seasons. Sometimes the inside ones will constantly work and you're waiting outside like an idiot. And sometimes the outside ones will constantly work and the inside ones will constantly fail. This isn't about which is better. It's about which one you feel better with, disregarding the other completely. That's the thing. Neither is better. It goes in seasons. But you marry one and center your operation on one. Come what may and whatever happens. And if you're two weeks without any going outside, too bad. Don't worry, your two weeks where all go outside will come. Don't worry. So, this is the mental support you have to establish. This is what I say I'm going to do and this is what I do. I understand what's going to happen. The one I disregard will act many times. But you understand, and this is the phrase I always say, I only want mine. I don't want someone else's. This, that seems so simple to say, isn't easy to do. Why? Because what you call anger comes in. I'm never angry. I simply say, that's not mine.

concepts.name: Distribution of Operations
concepts.definition: Determines where and how many trades will be executed based on the user's own plan rather than price movements.
concepts.relationship: Foundational to maintaining control over trading strategy irrespective of market conditions.

concepts.name: Execution Criteria
concepts.definition: Clearly defined criteria that specify how many trades to execute in a given zone.
concepts.relationship: Directly impacts how well resources can be managed given account limitations.

concepts.name: Mental Game
concepts.definition: The psychological aspect of trading, focusing on discipline and commitment to one's plan without being swayed by market emotions.
concepts.relationship: Essential for maintaining discipline and sticking to predefined trading methods.

rules.rule: Decide your number of trades before entering any position.
rules.context: Knowing the number of trades helps maintain control over your operations.

rules.rule: Focus on executing your trades exactly as planned and ignore unsolicited price movements.
rules.context: Essential to avoid emotional trading based on price fluctuations.

rules.rule: Operate either inside or outside, not both, and commit to your choice.
rules.context: Helps in resource management and maintaining trading focus.

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of distributing trading operations carefully, independent of price movements. He argues that with limited account sizes, traders must be selective, acting like snipers rather than using a scattergun approach. Vega discusses the importance of having a predefined plan for how many trades you'll execute, whether operating within or outside of planned zones. He strongly advocates for discipline and sticking to a trading strategy, highlighting that it is not about predicting market movements but managing and understanding one's limitations. This approach also requires a strong mental game to avoid being swayed by temporary market conditions.

How is this possible? Look at where the account is. 17, 9, 3, 9. And now watch, if these stops are triggered, the account will grow. Let's see if it happens. Let's see what the heck it wants to do. Of course, I have coverage. I'm still with two from below, and I've set the target for one of them right when the stops are triggered. That's why the account will grow. It's possible that I'll be taken out. Look at the loss levels I have in those positions that are there. Do you see the amount of loss? But if you look at oil, each of the ones I have down there is gaining over 300. So here, as it is an important first attempt where I'm putting in everything, it's a good place to set a new upward target. That means it will take out eight positions and one from below. And that will make this grow. The coverage is brutal, man. Let's see if it happens. So you realize the power this has. Watch. If they are triggered, the account will increase. And if it respects it now and falls, I'll go with eight. I'm going with eight. So, do you think I'm worried about what it will do? If it rises and triggers, I win. If it doesn't trigger or fall, I also win. I hope it falls because I'm going with eight, buddy. I'm all in. They are taking it from my hands, gentlemen. Cheap all-in. How good it is, huh? No way. HELLO! Has it risen or not? It has risen, right? Screw the all-in, that bastard has eaten it.

concepts.name: stops

concepts.relationship: Used strategically to manage risk and secure profits.

analysis.summary: In this trading video, Joaquín Vega explains how he uses a modified Fibonacci methodology to manage risks and optimize profits. Through strategic use of stops and coverage, he demonstrates how triggering certain conditions can lead to significant account growth. By setting upward targets and maintaining positions in both directions, he showcases how to remain profitable irrespective of market movements. The video emphasizes using all available tools to ensure the best outcomes in unpredictable trading environments.

title: In trading, the concept of hedging can yield very good results. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Good morning, good afternoon. Hello, I'm Joaquín Vega. Monday, December 5th. Today I want to talk to you about a concept many of you ask me about, which is called hedging, a concept I use. Everyone has their idea of what hedging is. I'll try to explain in a simple way, let's say, with a practical example of how I use hedging. Look, it all starts with the idea that there is an origin of movement. An origin of movement that, logically, we try to capture and that has a potential range, as was the case in our recent videos with the S&P 500, where we've been entering long positions from these levels. When I carry out this operation, the chart suggests there is potential to rise to those levels. Perfect. Therefore, I begin the trade with multiple positions, two, three, four positions. When I initiate this movement, I already know that at this potential target we could start contrary positions. That means we're buying. At that level, I take profits because we're trying to introduce contrary positions. What does this mean? It means that from these positions, two, three, four positions, I will take different levels of partials as targets, and one of them will also serve as a final target at that level where I will try to enter short, contrary positions. But one of them, at least one, I will always maintain because I assume it's lost, relatively speaking. What does it mean that I assume it's lost? It means that if I'm here trying to enter short positions, contrary to the long position, logically, I might be wrong. If this area indeed fails and the price continues to rise, I keep earning from the position I have in the original movement. On the other hand, if in these short positions, just like we introduced here, with this group of positions, if the price indeed falls, I consider this operation lost. Right now, we're trying to start a new downtrend movement, which in this case has potential to fall to 3,770. Well, if the price falls, it will take away the last long position I have here, but logically, when the price falls, I will take profits from the contrary positions. Therefore, when the price reaches this level, having taken different levels of partials, including the final movement until there, if the price continues upwards, I keep gaining, and if it falls, I forsake the remaining long position, but take profits from the short position. Therefore, in this margin where I'm hedging, it's a win-win. Understand? It's a win-win. If the price proves me right, I win either way. I don't mind profiting from the long position or the short one. This is the general idea, very briefly, of what I manage with hedging. If we see what's happening now, I keep one of the positions from this origin of movement, and we're bringing in six positions. I'll take this opportunity to tell you what I'm expecting here. We're going to take three of the positions we currently have as partials, around those levels of 3950-55. These positions are going to serve as partials, just as we did with the long movement. They're going to serve as partials. Notice how I'm positioning that group of partials. There they are. The price might fall a little more to those levels of 3895, to take out all the stops underneath and seek, as we've discussed in previous videos, liquidity. We could have a direct move to 3895 or a pause in this partial level to go up and then down again. Ultimately, this is the general picture I'm expecting. In the kit, around 3895 there might be a high rebound possibility, but the final target, as you see, two of them will remain at those targets of 3780 because I'm going to attempt long positions there once again playing with the concept of hedging. If the price falls here and gives me these partial and final targets, here I'll try to enter long positions, maintaining one short position, therefore if the price keeps falling it'll take me out of the long positions, but I'll continue profiting from the short position. It's a way to seek win or win. Of course, the price has to give me the movement, alright? Let's wait and see if we can take those first partial levels. Well, folks, I've raised those initial levels a bit higher because this is a rebound area, it's a bit broad. Let's aim for an average decline of those three positions of around 100 points, and from here, with high probability, before the price breaks the stops below, we might have this movement. Let's see if it's true. What we're going to do is keep the three initial positions, those two targets, and we'll also leave one as a hedge for the buying possibilities we'll make below. Well, I always tell you it's a very useful tool, a very useful concept and one of the concepts I always tell you is why I like CFDs a bit, as I've mentioned many times. By the way, before ending the video, do you see any kind of cachopo for you in this turn? Nothing more, regards.

concepts.name: Hedging
concepts.definition: Taking positions in both directions to protect against price movements.
concepts.relationship: It provides a safety net, allowing profit regardless of price movement, maintaining a win-win situation.

concepts.name: Origin of Movement
concepts.definition: The starting point of a significant price movement.
concepts.relationship: Used to identify potential profitable entry points for trades.

concepts.name: Partials
concepts.definition: Partially taking profits at predetermined levels.
concepts.relationship: Helps manage risk and secure profits in stages, tied to both long and short strategies.

rules.rule: Use hedging to profit from both upward and downward movements.
rules.context: When the initial analysis of movement direction remains uncertain or contentious.

rules.rule: Set partials to secure profits and manage risk if the market changes direction.
rules.context: In volatile markets where price targets are approximate and movement is unpredictable.

rules.rule: Always maintain one position to cover potential errors in original analysis.
rules.context: Acts as a fail-safe measure if the breakout or rebound does not go as planned.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses hedging strategies in trading, highlighting its potential for win-win outcomes across market movements. He emphasizes understanding the 'origin of movement' to set an appropriate entry point and utilizing 'partials' for risk management and profit-taking in stages. By maintaining positions in both directions, traders can mitigate losses if trends reverse unexpectedly, ensuring profitability either way. The video suggests using CFDs due to their flexibility in implementing this strategy effectively. Technical levels such as 3895 and 3770 are analyzed for potential trades.

concepts.name: Coverage (Cobertura)
concepts.definition: Using positions to balance and reduce risk by hedging trades against each other.
concepts.relationship: It connects to keeping a balanced risk exposure when trading multiple indices or assets.

concepts.name: Floating Profit (Flotante)
concepts.definition: The unrealized profit or loss of open positions.
concepts.relationship: It determines the immediate gains or losses in positions before they are closed.

rules.rule: Balance your open positions to prevent excessive risk.
rules.context: When holding multiple buy and sell positions in the market.

rules.rule: Regularly adjust stops and positions to maintain a healthy account.
rules.context: During a review of existing trades to ensure appropriate risk management.

analysis.summary: This video by Joaquín Vega teaches the importance of balancing trading positions to manage risk effectively, especially when using CFDs for hedging. Vega demonstrates closing and adjusting positions in various markets like the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and DAX to maintain equal distribution and manage floating profits. He emphasizes the methodology of using smaller time-frame maps to analyze markets and correct trading strategies for better outcomes. The video also stresses the need to correct poor decisions and enhance results through disciplined trading practice.

title: En trading, SOLO DEBES AÑADIR POSICIONES si el precio te da la razón. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Good morning, good afternoon. Hello, I am Joaquín Vega, Monday, April 25th. Working on SP500, hourly chart, we find the price in a very important decision zone around the levels of 4,200 points. We start with the first of at least three long positions that I want to enter to look for the targets you see there. We start entering positions, we start placing stops. As the price continues to validate my premise, we will add at least two more positions. First partial levels, levels at 4,390 points. Final objectives, levels at 4,575, 80 points. We expect the price to validate us. A lot of buying power should enter, therefore, the movement should be relatively quick. This would give us options to add two or three more positions. We wait and execute. Okay, we have the perfect situation, four positions. We start placing target levels. First partial levels, levels at 4,385, a rise of around 170 points, and we will exit with two of the positions as a partial. We continue with a third one looking for an upward target of around 360 points, levels at 4,567, and we'll let one position run up to higher levels. Today's tip, always try to work in zones, always try to work with divided positions, that is, if we want to enter a position, structure it in two, three, four entries, and as the price continues to validate us, we add gradually until completing the full entry. I always use this same technique. Never add positions when we have an existing position going against us. Always add when with positions in our favor. There should be a clear entry of money, a very powerful initial movement. Let's see if we can reach these first target levels. We wait. Well, we move on to Tuesday, April 26th. There we have the powerful movement. If we see this on a smaller chart, 15-minute chart, I want to show you a bit what happened here. What happened is an accumulation process you see here. The process starts with false breakouts, false breakouts, accumulations, false breakouts, accumulations, false breakouts, accumulations, false breakouts, accumulations. We also see how they accumulated above to keep pushing the price down. They accumulated to keep pushing the price down, and in the end, what they've done is a failure at 161.8. Therefore, the process has been perfect. We have complete manipulation with a failure at 161.8, which is where we started working. Therefore, the process has been very nice, very nice. If the price now made some kind of interesting retracement, we would add more positions. With the buys protected, we already look on the general map at those first target levels. We wait. Here we have the retracement. So far, nothing unexpected. I'll show you what's happening on the five-minute chart. Notice what happened there. We are going to make a very, very, very specific operation, very, very intraday. We will wait for the price to retest those levels of 4,295. We will enter a short position with a very specific exit also at levels of 4,261. Let's wait for the price to reach that level and we'll enter a position with a very short exit. We wait and execute that position. About to enter those sales, what I'm going to do is take out one of these positions we had higher up. We will take it here. We will gain around 78 points. If we see it on a five-minute chart, it looks like this. There we will be trying to enter the short. We adjust that first exit to those levels. We wait for the price around this little zone. We wait. Perfect. We release the long position, take profit, attack the short position. We go for the target. In this case, we get about 30 points, okay? We wait to see what happens. It could make a new high and then drop. That wouldn't surprise me, but it shouldn't hit my stop. Come on, we wait. Well, about to take profits. Let's see if it reaches those levels. Notice how the general map looks a bit. There you have it. Always, always, always a mindset of dual direction. As you see here on the general map, long swing movement, short intraday movement. Therefore, they are entirely compatible, the mindset of dual direction. Nothing else. The price is behaving well. Entertaining session yesterday and today. And we take a bit of profit. Nothing more, guys. Greetings.

concepts.name: Decision Zone
concepts.definition: Critical price level where potential market movement can be assessed.
concepts.relationship: Helps determine when to initiate or add positions based on market conditions.

concepts.name: Stepwise Position Addition
concepts.definition: Adding positions gradually as the market confirms the original trading premise.
concepts.relationship: Used in conjunction with decision zones to manage risk incrementally.

concepts.name: Dual Direction Mindset
concepts.definition: Strategy of maintaining the possibility of both long and short trades based on different timeframes.
concepts.relationship: Allows traders to profit from both upward and downward market movements simultaneously.

concepts.name: Fibonacci Failure at 161.8
concepts.definition: Recognizing when a Fibonacci extension fails, indicating a potential reversal.
concepts.relationship: Used as a signal to reassess or adjust positions when patterns break expected norms.

rules.rule: Never add positions when a previous position is going against you.
rules.context: When considering increasing position sizes in a given trade.

rules.rule: Work with divided positions, adding gradually as the market confirms your strategy.
rules.context: When strategizing entries and managing risk.

rules.rule: Maintain a mindset of dual directionality, ready to trade both long and short.
rules.context: In volatile or uncertain market conditions.

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega explains a modified Fibonacci and stepwise trading strategy focused on the SP500 hourly chart. Vega underscores the significance of decision zones around key price levels and emphasizes adding to positions only as the market confirms the original trading hypothesis. He elaborates on a dual-direction mindset, enabling traders to be prepared for both long and short opportunities across different timeframes. By utilizing processes like broken Fibonacci extensions and stepwise position addition, traders can effectively manage risk and optimize profits. The approach encourages strategic accumulation and divestment of positions based on market movements.

_metadata.title: En trading, SOLO DEBES AÑADIR POSICIONES si el precio te da la razón. Joaquín Vega.

title: En trading, haciendo COBERTURAS CONSTANTES. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Good morning, good afternoon. Hello, I am Joaquín Vega, Tuesday, July 20th. Based on the previous video, we continue working on the SP500, 30-minute chart. After having worked on this decline, yesterday we tried to make the new turn around these levels, we failed, we did it again in a subsequent area, lower. There we took three positions again and we continue with the map. We said that in this area it was very likely for the price to return to historical highs and that at these levels of 4,330 points we could again have a downward movement. This is exactly what we are going to want to capture. For now, we will take one of these three positions and make a rise as a partial around 87 points, with two of the three positions we carry upwards. Let's not forget that we also still have a hedge in a sell mode. Therefore, we will attempt to complete that hedge of the sale with a purchase. We will take those two partials and start some short position here. In that little area we will try to sell with a position to capture a drop of this kind. A drop of around 65 points, alright? Therefore, we will wait for the price to enter that little area, there, and we will start some short position after taking those profits. Alright, we wait. Well, guys, we take about 170 points and we are now left with a clean hedge. Short position, long position. You ask me a lot about these hedges. Look, what I intend with the hedges, analysts, you know, always try to deduce or see a bit which are the trends, the most probable movement, the most probable direction. Look, I do not function like that, I do not follow trends, the only thing I follow is fractality. When I try to see or try to locate through our maps areas of possible turn, which is the only thing I'm constantly searching for, I try to capture the start of the fractality and try to capture the end of the fractality. As you see, and since yesterday, here we put in three positions, we have taken out two, here we have put in three more, we have taken out two, therefore, from both the selling movement and the buying movement we have already taken some movement out, therefore I do not care which way the market goes, what I want is to always go with it. In fact, right now we have the price enclosed in this distance, therefore, whether it goes up or down, everything I do inside will first come out for free and if the price breaks above I will go with the purchase, if the price breaks below I will go with the sale. Logically, if the price comes here and reaches the selling positions, I will take out half of the long position and continue with the ongoing position. If the price goes the opposite way, down, I will take out half of the sale and continue with the lower price. As you see, I always have a double direction mindset, therefore, I do not care where the price goes, I want to always go with it, with more or less contract volume, but always want to go with it. This way, I take away the worry of knowing trends and constantly thinking about where the price will go, I only have to search on maps areas of possible turn and try to constantly capture what will never change on a chart, which is the fractality. We reach an area of possible sales, here we will try to place some short position since we could have some downward movement. Nothing more, regards.

concepts.name: Coberturas constantes (Constant Hedging)
concepts.definition: Continuously holding both long and short positions to capitalize on moves in either direction.
concepts.relationship: Reduces concerns about market trends by focusing on movement capture.

concepts.name: Fractalidad (Fractality)
concepts.definition: Identifying and exploiting repeating patterns in price movements without following trends.
concepts.relationship: Used to define entry and exit points regardless of market direction.

concepts.name: Mapas de Giro (Turn Maps)
concepts.definition: Tools to locate potential reversal areas in price charts.
concepts.relationship: Help in deciding when to enter or exit positions based on fractal analysis.

rules.rule: Always enter trades in both directions to stay with the market moves.
rules.context: When analyzing potential movements without concern for trends.

rules.rule: Take profits partially to reduce risk and capture market movement.
rules.context: When reaching key price areas or after market moves.

rules.rule: If price hits predefined levels in the map, adjust positions accordingly.
rules.context: To maintain a balanced hedged stance.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega demonstrates his approach of constant hedging by using both long and short positions simultaneously on the SP500. His methodology emphasizes fractality over trend following, aiming to capture the start and end of fractal movements through specific turn maps. Vega educates on positioning based on key price levels, allowing traders to stay aligned with market movements. The video discusses strategies for managing trades by taking partial profits to reduce risk while emphasizing the use of hedging to eliminate trend concerns.

_metadata.title: En trading, haciendo COBERTURAS CONSTANTES. Joaquín Vega.

title: Ejemplo de cobertura en SP500. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Good morning, good afternoon. Hello, I'm Joaquín Vega, Monday, December 21st. We are working on the SP500 hourly chart. This zone is at 3,600 to 3,610 points, where we might see this type of movement. Therefore, I will enter two positions, one of them to hedge the short position and another aiming for a very specific upward move up to 3,710 points. Therefore, all we need to do is wait for the price to reach this zone and we will enter a couple of positions. We wait and execute. Well, we attack the price and now we go with two. We will take one up by about 93 points and as we said, the next position will hedge the short sale. We wait. Well, here we go with one more. Let's aim for about 65 more points with a new position. We keep waiting. Come on. Well, due to the time, we slightly modify the objectives. We will settle for around 52 and about 80, okay? It has the objective and potential to rise up to here, even to make new highs, but given the time we have, we are going to close positions and take profits at these levels. Let's wait.

concepts.name: Reversal Zone
concepts.definition: A potential price level where a reversal in price direction is expected.
concepts.relationship: It is used to determine entry points for trades, in this case defining a zone for potential upward reversal.

concepts.name: Hedging
concepts.definition: Entering trades opposite to an existing position to reduce risk.
concepts.relationship: One of the positions entered is used to hedge the existing short position, thus managing risk.

concepts.name: Profit-taking
concepts.definition: Closing a position in whole or in part to realize profits.
concepts.relationship: It occurs after price moves favorably, defined by specific price targets.

rules.rule: Enter positions at identified reversal zones.
rules.context: When price approaches significant reversal areas.

rules.rule: Modify objectives based on current market conditions and timing.
rules.context: When market conditions change or time of day limits potential movement.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega discusses his trading strategy for the SP500, focusing on a potential upward reversal zone between 3,600 to 3,610 points. He plans to hedge his existing short position and aims to profit from a subsequent upward movement up to 3,710 points. The video emphasizes the importance of adapting targets and taking profits according to market conditions and time constraints. Overall, it showcases a balance between risk management through hedging and targeting specific profit levels.

title: En trading, DEBES TENER TAMAÑOS DE STOPS MÍNIMOS. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Imagine that you have pattern X, whatever it may be, and you are measuring a pattern and working in the zone of deception. Perfect. That pattern gives you an entry. One of the typical questions you ask me is, 'What happens if when I enter the market with any pattern, whatever it may be, it doesn't matter which one? What happens when that operation requires a stop here below, very small, because when we have stops of 5 or 6 pips, I have to tell you that if you are working with a pattern with those types of stops, you are working on very small charts. So, be careful with that first reflection. Second, the problem with working with 6-point or 6-pip stops, which is the huge problem they have in futures, as we have discussed many times, is that when I have to put these 6 pips, automatically, once I enter the market, I have to go with my tracking fibo, what we do by placing 6 pips is that if the price does this, we have to manage. That is, if the price falls 3 or 4 pips, we have to manage those 3 or 4 pips. What's the huge problem? With working futures and consequently working with these tiny stops, we won't have time. In most cases, we won't have time, because the price can move those 3 or 4 pips in a blink. What does that mean? On one hand, we won't have time to manage in protection. Most times. But also, besides having too small a stop that probably won't allow us to manage well in protection if the trade goes wrong, the added problem is that if we enter with leverage according to those 6 pips, there is a high probability that that trade will fail and, moreover, we are over-leveraged because we only put 6 pips and if we entered according to the 6 pips, we are over-leveraged. Why do I tell you that you should always have minimum and maximum stops? I always tell you, in Forex, you cannot work with less than 12 pips of stop. Why? Because even if I have an entry, like the one we had here that requires 6 pips, I will never put 6 pips. If I work on very small charts and see a trade that, by pattern, requires 6 pips, I will put 12. Why do I put 12? First rule. Because I never enter the Forex market with leverage with stops below 12 pips. That means my lower leverage is always justified with 12 pips. I never calculate entries below 12 pips. It is the minimum leverage with which I always enter. Not only that, but also, whatever the pattern, I know that pattern I am entering and whose correct stop would be here, I am clear, I will make another type of pattern, a deep entry. For example, we are waiting for a calm. And we are waiting for the price to come here. And I know that when the price comes here, right after entering, it requires 6 pips. I will always put 12. Rule number 1. I never enter with leverage that is not in accordance with at least 12 pips. I will not apply more entry due to having less stop. No. 12 pips is my minimum leverage. On one hand, I already enter with leverage, I am making a very short-term trade where I know, in both cases, that if the price comes here, the pattern for which I entered breaks. And if the price comes here, the pattern for which I entered breaks. In both cases, if the price does this or the price does this, the reason for the entries is worthless. What do I do when this happens? Automatically, as I go with a minimum lot management based on 12 pips, I risk less money than someone entering with 6 pips, because the one going with 6 pips usually enters more leveraged. There is a very bad belief, very bad, very bad, very bad. And that is we are going to try to work with the smallest possible stops to enter with the maximum possible leverage. That is horrible. That is the worst. That belief of since I want to earn a lot, I want to leverage a lot. And since I want to leverage a lot, I enter with short stops. That is the worst. The belief of wanting to earn quickly, that's why I enter with a lot. The worst. In other words, the operator who entered with 6 pips enters more leveraged than I do. It's very likely that there won't be time to manage when losing the 61 of the fibo from that movement. Very likely. Therefore, it is highly probable that if the price finally fails the trade, that operator gets taken out quickly without an option to manage and with leverage of 6 pips. Higher than mine. Exactly the same here. When entering, you have to manage half of it there. When you're talking about 2-3 pips for it to do this, there's not enough time to do proper management. Therefore, it will take you out as well. That 6-pip operator will get taken out. With excessive leverage for the risk management he is doing. However, when I see this, the price has entered there, we are both inside, but I go with 12 pips. I am very clear also that if the price comes back to that minimum or comes back to this minimum, the reason for the entry is broken. Therefore, when I go with these types of stops, I say, if the price comes here or the price comes here, I exit with everything. That trade is not valid. I leave with everything. I have enough time to manage. What is the huge difference between the 6-pip operator failing and me failing? Well, that operator who entered with higher leverage than me, we are failing the same trade but he loses more money than I do. He loses more money than I because I lose those 4-5 pips but with leverage of 12. That other person loses the 6 pips with leverage of 6. Therefore, in this type of very short-term trades, where it's very difficult to manage well in protection, that person will always lose more than I do. That's why I always keep the rule that you must have minimum stops. You can't work without them. And be careful, I insist again on comparing with futures. In futures, they are compelled to do this. They are compelled to work with 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 pips. Because of high costs. They are compelled. They can't do it otherwise. Except, I always tell you that to work with futures you must have an account of at least 50,000. Because working with less is exactly what will happen to you. As you have little capital, you can't afford to put 12 pips. So you have to work to the millimeter. And working to the millimeter you're telling the price I don't let you even breathe. I can't do proper management in protection. That is the huge problem with futures. And since this is not futures, we can afford much greater management solvency. Among other things, instead of putting those 6, 5, 4 pips, I put 12. Because I am financially covered. Because I can reduce the lot size as much as I want. So be very careful. Firstly, we are already working on very short time frames. Because working with 6 pips of stop. Very short time frames. Very dangerous. We're going to fail many trades. Many trades. And if we are going to fail many trades and I can't manage protection well, the final result won't be good. You have to have minimum stops for each of your assets. In Forex, you can have minimum stops for any currency pair. But if you work gold, minimum stops in gold. I always tell you mine. Three-point minimum stop in gold. SP500. Three-point minimum stop in SP500. DAX. Ten-point minimum stop. Those are my minimums. Because they are the minimums that allow me to manage. No matter how short-term I work. Reasonable. And always knowing that by working with stops. The minimum stops in those assets. I am working in short time frames. I will fail many trades. Therefore, protection management there must be perfect. If working in medium and long-term, protection management must be perfect. Not to say when we work in such short time frames. In such precise movements. The management in protection and risk management must be perfect. Because we are going to fail many trades. So be careful with these types of things.
