concepts.name: minimum stop size
concepts.definition: The smallest stop-loss value deemed sensible to allow for better management of trades.
concepts.relationship: It protects against volatility and allows for effective management, differing from short-term aggressive strategies.

concepts.name: over-leveraging
concepts.definition: Using high leverage due to small stops, which increases risk and potential losses.
concepts.relationship: Related to minimum stops because smaller stops tend to lead to higher leveraging, which is risky.

concepts.name: protection management
concepts.definition: The act of managing a trade to minimize losses and protect capital.
concepts.relationship: Effective protection management is tied to using reasonable stop sizes, particularly during short-term trades.

concepts.name: deep entry pattern
concepts.definition: A trading pattern anticipating a market pullback and placing larger-than-typical stops.
concepts.relationship: It involves entering trades at optimal points with sufficient stop distance to allow for market retesting.

concepts.name: volatile timeframes
concepts.definition: Short-term trading periods where price movements are rapid and unpredictable.
concepts.relationship: Demands minimum stop sizes to allow traders to manage positions effectively.

rules.rule: Never use a stop loss lower than 12 pips in Forex.
rules.context: When trading in Forex to ensure enough room for managing trades.

rules.rule: Ensure stops are specific to asset requirements.
rules.context: Managing different asset classes like Forex, gold, and indices.

rules.rule: Avoid over-leveraging with small stops.
rules.context: Managing risk and protecting capital in volatile markets.

rules.rule: Exit trades immediately if the price invalidates the entry pattern.
rules.context: When the entry reason is no longer valid.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of setting minimum stop-loss levels in trading, particularly in Forex, suggesting a base of 12 pips to allow adequate margin for trade management. He warns against the common mistake of using tight stops to leverage bigger positions, which can lead to insufficient time for protective adjustments and potential losses. The video underscores the difference in leverage management between different markets, such as Forex versus futures, and recommends specific minimum stop sizes for different assets. By setting appropriate stop sizes, traders can achieve better risk management even in high-volatility short-term scenarios.

_metadata.title: En trading, DEBES TENER TAMAÑOS DE STOPS MÍNIMOS. Joaquín Vega.

title: En mi trading, UTILIZO ESTE PATRÓN DE ENGAÑO. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: What is a fractal? A thrust with a twist and a retracement. Okay. What we are looking for is for that twist to break the thrust that brought it, so that it ceases to be a retracement and becomes a new thrust. Yes. This price is going up. For it to turn, something has to happen. What has to happen? I think your mind thinks of Matrix, buddy. Wow, Matrix, okay. What you see is one thing and what it is, is another. Imbalance between supply and demand. That's it, damn. In short, let's write it down. You told me flag pattern. When? People are... Think about Matrix. Think about Matrix. People are going crazy, crazy, crazy buying because it is having a magnificent rally and they are buying, buying, buying. The big players are taking advantage of this to distribute, to sell, sell, sell, sell. Let's see. If this price is going to fall, the first thing that has to happen, what is it? Stop. Stop. It's that simple. Yes. If you are driving and want to make a U-turn, the first thing you need to do, what is it? Brake. Stop. Step number one. Brake. For something to stop rising, there has to be something to stop it, right? Yes. What is it? The only way to stop something that is rising and something that is falling is to have something going against it. What we are saying, then, is that there must be something going down and something going up here. Notice that I'm telling you something. It doesn't matter what it is, yes. I don't care what it is. It's obvious they are contrary positions. Once it stops, what is step number two? Start turning. Okay. Damn. Okay. Why does it turn? It not only stops, but it turns. It starts to turn around, of course. Okay. Therefore, when there is a turn, there is a triggering of stops of contrary movements plus selling. Conversely, the counterpart of buying is given by the stops of those selling plus the buying. Then the turn will be larger or smaller. But if there is a turn, it's because there has been that. Always counterpart. And always triggering stops. Where can I find this and where can I find this? Where? In my working zones. At what moment can I sense that there may be that which I am looking for, which is stop, buy and stops? Because without that, there is no turn. Place this figure in your brain. But if I were you, María, get a tattoo. Why am I telling you this? Why do I say that this is a tremendous figure? What is happening in that figure? Because many things are happening. This comes from above, from wherever it comes. This comes from below, from wherever it comes. How many things are happening there? Look, notice. For you to understand the figure, let's go step by step. Let's go with this. This is the figure. But for that figure to form, things happen first. The price was falling, it stopped, turned, and began to reverse the movement. There were people falling, and from there, the movement starts to turn around on them. They have stops somewhere, but depending on where they come from, they will have them closer or farther away. And right now, also, as the turn begins to occur, there will be people deciding to enter the buy and placing the stop-loss right below that peak. More precisely or less precisely. Perfect. Good. Will it rise where it has to rise? Yes. What happens when this happens? All who had been encouraged to get into the bullish movement are now out. They have been stopped out. What is commanding here, selling or buying? Selling. Right. Why is there more selling here? All those orders. Those who have bought here? Yes. Now... stops are sales. They are sales, yes. Right. Therefore, even through the stops, there are already sales entering? Yes. Right. What else is happening here? There are more people. Apart from the stops being activated to increase sales, because there are also people who are encouraged to see this movement, they are entering too. Right. Therefore, not only are there sales due to stops, but there are also sales from new operations. Yes. In other words, what is happening at this moment? There is a lot of counterpart for you to buy. Yes. Good. The stop-loss zone of buyers who did this or who have joined here is a small zone...not an exact point, but a small zone. People adjust the stops very closely. Right. But, what happens? New sellers are joining, and these sellers do not join just any way. They do not all join in the same spot because sellers, some see that it is breaking this low and just when the low breaks, they join, because they already consider it a level break. Yes. But others will wait for the price to drop a little more and others a little more. Here it depends a bit on each one's rule as to what constitutes a break. Yes, even if it’s the pullback or whatever. That is why our counterparty zone not only includes the stop level, the small zone of stops but also gives a margin for the later sellers to join, up to the one who joins here. That is why I give a margin to 161.8. I allow them to join in the break even up to 161.8. Then, I conclude, that is why this is our deception pattern; I conclude that all those who have not already joined in selling, at the break, above 161.8 will not join. If they haven't joined yet, they won't join. So, I need if indeed someone, anyone, is taking advantage of the counterpart of the stops of the last buyers and is taking advantage of those entering the sale, if someone is trying to take advantage, from here it has to rise. Of course. Because if it doesn’t rise, I assume they don’t intend to take advantage of that counterpart. And that those who sold will continue to ride. And those who have sold keep gaining, but I'm not looking to join the movement's direction. I want them to take the counterpart because that's exactly where I want to enter. Therefore, if I see that it indeed respects that 161 and starts to rise, I already have all the ingredients to be able to think that I have stops, buy, and stop. From that moment on, I sense that there is an option they are using the counterpart we have described. Yes. Then I don't know if they will do it or not, but I have the conditions. Yes. Do you understand what the first deception pattern is? Yes. As you well know, there is a second and third deception pattern. It is when they are linking. What I realized is that if I have 100 contracts to enter, here I only have 50. I will absorb them, yes, but I need to generate 50 more. I make a new figure, and poof. Of course. That's why there is a second deception pattern. Hey, no. I had 150. Here I have 50 in the second. I have 50, but I'm missing 50 more. Another same figure. Because, in the end, it's the same. Yes. Sure. That's how it is, you know? Uh-huh.

decision_points.condition: Price reaches 161.8% retracement level
decision_points.if_true: Price should rise as it's assumed they've taken advantage of counterpart orders
decision_points.if_false: Assume lack of intent in exploiting counterpart opportunities
decision_points.quote_es: Si de verdad alguien, quien sea, está aprovechando la contrapartida... a partir de aquí tienes que subir.
decision_points.quote_en: If indeed someone, anyone, is taking advantage of the counterpart... from here it has to rise.

concepts.name: Fractal
concepts.definition: A thrust with a twist and retracement; a turning point that breaks its original thrust to become a new one.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a foundation for identifying twist and retracement patterns.

concepts.name: Deception Pattern
concepts.definition: A pattern where price indicates a false break, drawing in traders only for the price to reverse.
concepts.relationship: Used to exploit imbalances and anticipate counterpart actions.

concepts.name: 161.8% Fibonacci Level
concepts.definition: A critical price level where the price action tendency is assessed, and potential reversals are anticipated.
concepts.relationship: Part of the methodology to determine entry points in deception patterns.

rules.rule: For a price to reverse, it must first stop and then turn.
rules.context: Applies when identifying potential reversals in the market.

rules.rule: If price respects the 161.8% level, anticipate a reversal.
rules.context: When evaluating whether counterpart trades are being utilized.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega teaches a trading strategy using the concept of deception patterns within a modified Fibonacci methodology. He explains the notion of a fractal, a market condition defined by a thrust, twist, and a retracement, which becomes a new impulse by breaking its original trend. The video underscores the importance of the 161.8% Fibonacci level as a critical decision point where traders assess whether imbalances between supply and demand will lead to reversals. Vega emphasizes understanding trader behavior during market rallies and utilizing counterpart actions as opportunities for entry.

analysis.translation: Only a third group is missing because he opens the restaurant to make money. My question is, with the numbers he has here, does he know how much each winning trade should make? Does he know how much he has to charge for each table served? He doesn't know the minimum success rate. He doesn't know how many people will come in, but he needs to make sure that each time someone sits at a table, it compensates him. The question is, how much should he charge per table? What type of profits should he use? He knows the risk per table, in goods, is 5 euros. But now, how much should he charge? We have to have an idea or should he set the price arbitrarily? It's clear he should earn more than 5, right? But how much more? Let's see, look at what I have here. Remember he's going to make 4 trades a day. If he's going to make 4 trades a day, the only sequences that can occur are these. He makes the first one, it fails. Makes the second, it fails. Makes the third, it fails. And makes the fourth, it fails. He fails everything. Fails 3, succeeds 1. I don't care about the order. I don't care about the order. When there are winners and losers, I don't care about the order. He's going to make 4. Wins 2, succeeds 2. Sorry, wins 2, fails 2. Fails 1, succeeds 3. Sorry, or succeeds in all. There's no other sequence, or yes, there is another sequence that can occur each day. Each day he can face this, per day, because he has committed to making 4 a day. My question is, can any other sequence occur in his operations? Do you see any other possibility? Fails everything, succeeds 1, succeeds 2, succeeds 3, or succeeds 4. Okay, let's do the math. The risk he will assume per trade is 5 euros. That's what we have established in the plan. Okay, what would happen the first day he makes this sequence if we were at a 1 to 1 ratio? 5, 10, 15, 20. No doubt. Here he loses minus 20 euros. Everything failed. At 5 euros per 4, minus 20. Next sequence, at 1 to 1, how much would he fail or what would be the final result? Failing 3 and succeeding 1, minus 10. Third sequence, fails 2, succeeds 2, final result, 0. Good. Fourth sequence, succeeds 3, fails 1, final result, plus 10. Succeeds everything. 5 by 4, 20. Plus 20. Perfect. But let's see with 1 to 3. I fail everything. I still lose the same. Minus 20. Second sequence, fail 3, succeed 1. Here I win based on plus 10. Here I win based on plus 15. Okay, final result, 0. Perfect. Third sequence, win 2, fail 2. Plus 20. Fourth sequence, succeed 3, fail 1. 40. Last sequence, win everything. Plus 60. Let's go with a new sequence. Let's put an example at 1, 4. Now you win based on 4, win based on plus 20. 5 by 4, 20, because the risk remains the same. Come on, first sequence, I always lose the same. Second sequence, plus 5. Good. Third sequence, 2 and 2. Plus 30. Fourth sequence, win 3, fail 1. 55. Last sequence, I win everything. Plus 80. And let's do the last example with 1 to 5. Each time I win, I win based on 25. Risk remains the same. First sequence, I fail everything, minus 20. Second sequence, fail 3, win 1. Plus 10. Third sequence, 2 and 2. Plus 40. Fourth sequence, win 3, fail 1. Plus 70. Good. Last sequence, succeed everything. Plus 100. Basically, what Pepe is deciding here is how much he wants to charge for each table. The goods for each of his tables cost him 5 euros. That is, what is served at each table will cost him 5 euros. He has the option of charging the same as he risks, what he pays. He has the option of charging double. He has the option of charging triple. 4 times more, 5 times more, 6 times more, 7 times more, 8 times more, whatever he wants. What is the difference or what is the problem or virtue of charging more or less? Of going for a higher or lower ratio? What are the advantages and disadvantages? You have them in these numbers and sequences. What do you think? Which should he choose and why? Advantages and disadvantages. Let's not think about charts, let's not think about trading, think about the restaurant. The cheaper he charges, the more people he has. The more expensive he charges, the fewer people can afford it. If he charges 1 to 1, if he charges the same as he risks, he will surely have a lot of people every day. Surely. But if he charges 5 times more, not everyone will be able to afford it, it will be a somewhat expensive restaurant. It is true that those who come will leave him more money per table, but it will not be full surely. So here Pepe has to decide, what do I want? Do I prefer to always have the restaurant full even if I only earn very little or nothing despite having the restaurant full? That helps me mentally to think that my business works. But be careful because when you do the math, Pepe, mentally you say, my business is doing great. But when you do the billing at the end of the month and deduct what you've been charged for goods, be careful with the surprise you may get. You have mentally kept the restaurant full, and you say, darn, I'm doing well. But be careful when you do the billing at the end of the month. Be careful, eh. Everything can come crashing down. On the contrary, if you charge 5 times more than what it costs you, the restaurant will daily have very few people. But it's possible that when you do the billing, you will have earned more than having it full. Therefore, Pepe, you are the one who will be in the restaurant every day. Keep in mind that you are there to make money. But remember, you are the one who will have to live with whether your restaurant has people or not. That will mentally disappoint you. Because what matters to you is the billing. But, as you can see, billing can be done in many different ways. How much do you want to charge per table? There will be business owners who want to have lots of people despite earning very little. And there will be other business owners who set their gourmet restaurant, and who only want customers to leave 5 times more each time they enter. Which one does it better? In trading, it's the same. Because it is no different from any other darn business. The question is, how do you want to charge the table? With the pros and cons it has. All can be good, but if you make a mistake, if you say, no, no, no, I want my restaurant each time people come 5 times more. But when you see only 2 come in a day, don’t get agitated. Don’t get agitated because then you’re making a mistake. Or if you take short billing, I will charge almost the same. When you do the billing, don’t get let down. Here you can’t go wrong, because you will despair if you make a mistake. And as you see, we can have many ways to do it. Which is the right one? You have to handle it. Weigh the pros and cons and how you charge. Evaluate it before starting. Don’t stress out in the middle of the month. Either because you have a lot of people and then earn little, or because you have very few people and want to earn more. Be careful how you do it because this mistake can cause your work to break down. When we translate this to trading, where we know we are going to make four trades a day and there are only five sequences that can happen daily. Either I fail all, succeed one, succeed two, succeed three, or succeed all four. Don’t twist it more, there are no other options. Therefore, each day you face a chart, you already know that these exist. What happens? I always tell you, let’s try to have a daily positive numerical hope towards us. And I want you to understand what it means for me, I repeat, for me, to have positive numerical hope for you daily. If I have five possible sequences, what do you want? The largest amount of sequences to your favor. Surely, that any of these sequences, most cause me money, generate money for me. Be it more or less, but that it doesn’t generate loss. Let's go with case number one. At one-to-one, five possible sequences. I only win with two of them. Negative numerical sequence. I lose everything, I lose. If I succeed one, I lose. And if I succeed two, I stay the same. I’m not interested. Simple. Out of five, only two interest me, it’s going to be a no. One-to-one, no. Let's go to the next one. In this case, I win in one, I win in two, and I win in three. In this case, with one-to-two, positive. Let's go to the third. How many do I win? I win in one, I win in two, I win in three. Positive. The fourth. I win in one, I win in two, I win in three. I have plus three here, plus three here, plus four here and plus four here. And I have plus two here. Okay. Can you draw the conclusion? If I have five sequences every day, I want the most possible on my side. In other words, four trades a day and five possible sequences, I want four on my side. Meaning that only in one of the sequences, it causes me a loss, which is failing everything. In the rest of the options, I sum. I don’t know about you, but I do. Do you understand the importance of numbers? We are not inventing anything. I do not want to work at one-to-two. I do not want to work at one-to-three. Can it be done? Yes. But I am clear that I face each day with four sequences in my favor and one against. And that gives me peace. Not only are we saying that with one-to-four, I have four of the sequences in my favor. From one-to-four forward, I have the four sequences out of five in my favor. But as you see, from plus four onward, all are in my favor for four of the sequences. But that person, Pepe, the minimum they should charge is one-to-four, at 20. Therefore, if we have determined the most important thing, which is the minimum, now Pepe must decide if he stops there, ensuring that the minimum he earns in the worst sequence is 5, 30, 55, 80, or he gives it one more point and says, no, 10, 40, 70, 100. We already know that the four sequences are in our favor. But now see the amount. Which do you want? You know the minimum. But the numerical amount of each sequence, which do you want? Because I can go one-to-six, one-to-seven, one-to-eight, and the numerical amounts of each sequence will keep growing. How do you charge the dishes? What do you want it to be? A little gourmet or very gourmet? Or do you want it to be a Michelin star? How do you want it? If it’s a Michelin star, the more Michelin it is, the more expensive. And fewer people will enter. Be careful. It will take you longer to enter people with much less frequency. You will win trades with much less frequency. Where do you set your limit? How do you feel better? Remember you are in the restaurant every day. If today nobody enters because you’ve charged it, at one-to-eight, eight times more than what it costs you, don’t complain. Don’t have set it so high. Here is where the individually determining part lies. Don’t forget that it's paid for by those who come in. The more expensive, the fewer come in. The cheaper, the more frequently they come in. Now you decide. Because all can be good, and all can be terrible if you make a mistake. Don’t complain if only four people come in all month. Don’t complain if you succeed in four trades in a month. That you have set the dish and the price. Don’t come saying later that my business is not going. No, it doesn’t work because you have set it too high. And you want people to come every day on top of it. That can’t be. One or the other. You can’t have it both ways. What you can’t have is to have it at 120 and have the restaurant full every day the first year you open it. Forget it. We’ll see later. But now no. Nobody knows you, you’re new. Look at how you charge the dish. Because every day you will have to fulfill it. What you can’t do is charge 120 today, 60 tomorrow, 40 the next day, because they will think you are ridiculous. And in the end nobody will come in. What a lousy restaurant. We don't know how much they are going to charge for the food today. This is what happens to you. You stand in front of the graph and don’t know how much you are going to charge for the dish. Depending on how the day looks. That’s what cannot be. What do you think of this? The food can be wonderful. The restaurant can be beautiful. But there is a person who manages it. And if the person who manages it is not good, no nice restaurant, nice food, or anything else will matter. Because this is what happens to you. The operation can be wonderful. But if the person who manages the operation doesn’t know how to run the restaurant, no matter what you do. It’s the same. Why would we act differently in trading than in a restaurant? Would you do that? Would you change prices every day in a restaurant if you opened one? Would you do that? Then why here yes? Here you allow everything. Do you know why you allow everything here? Because the main difference between the restaurant and trading is that when the restaurant messes up, people see it. And it would make your business fail. But when you are trading, you are alone. There are no people entering your establishment. You are alone. So you deceive yourself. I change the menu every day because as nobody sees me, who cares. And if it goes wrong and I lose money, nobody sees me. I deceive myself. But when you are in the restaurant in front of the public or when you are managing someone else's money account, there you have it tough. I just want you to think, if I gave each of you 100,000 euros to invest for me, I would be watching that menu. If one day you want to work with someone else's money, you will have to respect the menu. But if you are deceiving yourself alone every day because nobody sees you, the day you want to do that, how will you do it? If you have learned to deceive yourself. You will never do it, you won’t be able to, you won’t know how. That’s why it makes me laugh a lot when people go looking for funded accounts and when they go to seek other people’s money. And most of you are not even capable of controlling yourselves. How do you want to control someone else’s money that they will be watching you? They will take the money away from you immediately when they see you are changing the menu. It’s continual self-deception. I change prices when I want. I change dishes when I want. I change risks when I want. The business numerically does not work, impossible. And then we blame, no, it was the product. It's just that they sold me fish that wasn’t good. No, bastard, no. It's not that it was the price, that it didn’t follow me. No, bastard, no, no. Don’t deceive yourself, stop deceiving yourself already once and for all. The numbers are simple, they are what they are. And the ways to do it are what they are. Commit to one and stick to it. Therefore, what we are establishing, and in this case what we are going to do, is establish that Pepe’s minimum gain is 1 to 4. In other words, each time he wins, it will be 20 euros in profits. We could set 1 to 4, 1 to 5, 1 to 6, 1 to 7, 1 to 8, 1 to 9, 1 to 10, 1 to 50,000. In this case, Pepe is satisfied with that 1 to 4 for having 4 consequences in his favor.

decision_points.condition: If he charges a ratio of 1:4 or higher for his trades.
decision_points.if_true: He maximizes his win to rate potential by ensuring most trade sequences yield profits.
decision_points.if_false: He risks more frequent losses or break-even scenarios with lower ratios.
decision_points.action: Buy (when favorable market condition as per ratio).
decision_points.quote_es: Por tanto, lo que estamos estableciendo, y en este caso lo que vamos a hacer, es establecer que Pepe la ganancia mínima es 1 a 4.
decision_points.quote_en: Therefore, what we are establishing, and in this case what we are going to do, is establish that Pepe's minimum gain is 1 to 4.

decision_points.condition: If he wants guaranteed profitability over time.
decision_points.if_true: He needs to consistently trade at a higher risk-reward ratio, such as 1:5 or greater.
decision_points.if_false: He might face more operational challenges with inconsistent results.
decision_points.action: Wait for favorable conditions that allow higher ratio trades.
decision_points.quote_es: Podríamos poner 1 a 4, 1 a 5, 1 a 6...
decision_points.quote_en: We could set 1 to 4, 1 to 5, 1 to 6...

concepts.name: Risk-Reward Ratio
concepts.definition: Determines the ratio of potential profit versus risk per trade. In this video, it illustrates charging different times over cost to ensure profitability.
concepts.relationship: Used alongside trade frequency and sequence to maximize positive expectancy.

concepts.name: Trade Sequencing
concepts.definition: The possible winning and losing outcomes from a set number of trades per day, focusing on the importance of ratio balance to achieve positive sequences.
concepts.relationship: Directly linked with risk-reward ratios to identify profitable outcomes.

concepts.name: Positive Numerical Expectancy
concepts.definition: Having more winning than losing sequences to ensure net profitability over time.
concepts.relationship: Relies on risk-reward ratios and the selection of favorable trade sequences.

rules.rule: Establish a minimum risk-reward ratio for profitability.
rules.context: To ensure your trading results stay positive over time.

rules.rule: Avoid changing your trading 'menu'—stay consistent with your strategy.
rules.context: To prevent self-deception and ensure long-term success, similar to managing a business.

rules.rule: Aim for maximum sequence favorability; have more winning than losing sequences.
rules.context: When setting daily trade goals and evaluating trading strategy effectiveness.

analysis.summary: In this video, Joaquín Vega illustrates the trading concept by comparing it to running a restaurant, using this analogy to emphasize the importance of risk-reward ratios. He advocates for setting a consistent trading strategy that resembles charging a specific price for a restaurant meal to ensure profitability and sustainable success. He outlines the potential sequences of wins and losses in trading, stressing the need to have more favorable sequences to achieve positive numerical expectancy. The main takeaway is that trading, like running a restaurant, requires a stable 'menu' of strategies to avoid self-deception and ensure lasting profitability.

_metadata.title: CREA UN PLAN DE NEGOCIO CORRECTO para tu trading ( 3 de 3 ). Joaquín Vega.

title: En trading, SI TU CURVA DE RESULTADOS CAE MUCHO, ES POR TU CULPA. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: You know that I'm all about numbers and to me numbers are everything, but of course, it's not enough, it's not enough, it's not enough. We have to be more intelligent for certain things. Look, there's something called context. There's something that's vital that you understand, apply, assimilate, and engrave in yourself. Let's see. It's the before and after when you're working. What is the before and after? Notice I put context up there. Look, I'll give you an example. Today I made three attempts on gold, the first two failed, and now I'm on a third attempt. If we get stuck in the mindset of I must always do it the same way, if we get stuck there, and it's true, you have to always do it the same way, but if we stay there without understanding what context means, we're missing something. Should I always do the same thing? Yes, but I must always do the same thing in a generic way, okay? But this generic form can be altered by the context of the situation we have. When I talk about context, I'm not just talking about the context that happens in a chart, but the context of the day I'm having or even the week I'm having. That generic concept, depending on the context we are living in or immersed in, should be made a base mother generic concept if we must have a certain flexibility. It's like, for example, the case with gold today, in my case. Look, if we stick to the generic context, that is, the generic part, purely generic, you usually have a way of analyzing, in that analysis, some work zones appear, you're clear in those zones if you've decided some execution forms. We have all this clear, and we decide all this beforehand. Before facing any chart, I have all these concepts parametrized. I have numbers, of course, that execution is based on numbers. It is essential to have this generic part, no doubt, we all must have it and also balanced. Both the analysis, the zones, the execution, and the numbers must be balanced. That is something that is the foundation of everything, yes, without a doubt. But of course, there are two different contexts. The moment we click and we're already in the market, many things come into play. I need you to understand that here, the generic part is no longer valid, once you're with the order in the market. There's nothing you can do to make that price do what you want or not. That damn price will do whatever it wants. If that price does what it wants, you have to act with it. You can't stay stuck in the damn generic part. Guys, you need to understand that now the price is what conditions everything. To make you understand, look, every time I make a trade, I'm thinking about my results curve. I can perfectly apply the analysis, the zone, the execution, the numbers, everything, but when I make the click here, the results curve. This is what comes to my mind. What do I mean by this? I might get the trade right or not, it no longer depends on me, but in my damn head, I have that this curve doesn't fall. If I said I entered here and I put my stops here, I've executed different... you know I enter fractionally, for example, it's decided beforehand. I apply what I said before. So I will apply what I said before, but notice, here a thousand things already come into play. Hey, how's my day going? Is it going well? Is it going poorly? Is it going average? Because look, imagine I have my first partials here, according to the before. Also imagine that I have my finals here, but now there are different contexts playing, which is how my damn day is going. How's my week going? I won't go further. Every time I open a position, I'm very clear in my head what the context of the day and the week is, without a doubt. Then, first context, context 1, my results curve situation. Because I assure you one thing, I don't care about winning the trade or not winning it, but I don't want to fall. So, what happens? What happens if I've already taken positions in my favor? What happens if that day I'm in profit? For example, the context is different. Why? Because I know my results curve is in favor. So, my way of acting is not the same as if it's against, damn it. It’s not the same for me to have a good day as to have a bad day. I'll give you the gold example. Three attempts today, the first two fail. When I say they fail, I mean they don't give me partials. It doesn’t mean they've caused me much of a loss. If I know today that gold has thrown me off twice, for as little loss as it may have generated, it's a loss. And my obsession is the damn results curve. It's one of the factors that burst in my head. So, I set up mechanisms. The results curve will do what I say, it will fall if I want it to fall. It's that simple, guys. That curve falls as much as I let it fall, not what the market wants. And I need you to understand this. The curve falls as I want it to fall, no matter how much I fail. Let's see, let's go to the specific trade. The price starts to move. Context. Two failed trades. I make the third attempt. Do you think I’m going to act on the third attempt as in the previous two? No. No, because the context is what it is, damn it. If my priority is the results curve, I'm right now with a small loss. Let's suppose I'm with a small loss. X, small, small. When I open this third position, the first thing my head thinks is, ok, how much did I lose in the previous two? Because, you know something? I know perfectly well how my day is going. I know perfectly well how much I'm losing now or how much I'm gaining now. It's my damn job. Knowing what's happening with my trading today and yesterday and the day before yesterday. So, I know perfectly well how I’m doing. Let's imagine that in the two previous losses they caused me a loss of 100 euros. I’m going with minus 100. X percentage with respect to my account. I'm inventing everything. When I’m making this third one, my top priority, one, is not to win the damn trade. It’s not for the price to come to my partial here, which is what the generic side says, and for my final to come here. No, sir. The first thing I’m going to do is, at what point in this movement if it falls in my favor? I recover 100, at least if I've put in three positions here, as if I have to take out two that add up to 100. If the generic partial is here, imagine I've put in three and here the sum of two of them gives me plus 100, to hell with the generic partial. My curve doesn't fall. Therefore, when the price comes here, if it does, two go out. Damn, Joaquín, then you’re changing the methodology. Dude, I'm changing the methodology due to the context I have and I won't even tell you if I have two bad days. I started the week, Monday and Tuesday, minus 200. When Wednesday starts, my damn obsession is to recover those 200. I'm not thinking about more as priority one. My account falls what I say it falls, I've said.

decision_points.condition: Trading in a favorable results context
decision_points.if_true: Act differently because results curve is favorable
decision_points.if_false: Trade cautiously as the results curve is against you
decision_points.quote_es: Os aseguro una cosa, me da igual ganar la operación que no ganarla, pero no quiero caer.
decision_points.quote_en: I assure you one thing, I don't care about winning the trade or not, but I don't want to fall.

decision_points.condition: Third trade on gold after two failures
decision_points.if_true: Alter strategy to protect results curve
decision_points.if_false: Continue with generic strategy
decision_points.quote_es: ¿Vosotros pensáis que con un tercer intento voy a actuar como en los dos anteriores? No.
decision_points.quote_en: Do you think I’m going to act on the third attempt as in the previous two? No.

concepts.name: Context
concepts.definition: The situational factors affecting how a set strategy should be executed; includes the daily and weekly context of trading results.
concepts.relationship: It overrides or adjusts the generic method depending on current performance or linked trading events.

concepts.name: Results Curve
concepts.definition: A representation of cumulative trading results, determining how strategy adjustments are made based on profitability and loss.
concepts.relationship: It's the primary driver that influences changing the execution of trades based on the context.

concepts.name: Generic Methodology
concepts.definition: The standard set methodology for analysis, zones, and execution that is balanced and number-based.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a baseline which requires flexibility in accordance to context.

rules.rule: Always be aware of your current results curve status.
rules.context: For deciding whether to continue riskily or conservatively.

rules.rule: Adapt your trade strategy according to the context you are currently in.
rules.context: When encountering multiple failed trades or unusual daily/weekly results.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of adapting generic trading methodologies to the context of current performance. He highlights understanding 'context' as vital in trading, both in terms of daily/weekly outcomes and individual trade actions. This involves being aware of the 'results curve' and adjusting strategies accordingly, especially when dealing with consecutive trade failures. Even with a structured plan in place, traders must be flexible and ready to modify their approach based on their results to prevent adverse impacts on their trading accounts.

_metadata.title: En trading, SI TU CURVA DE RESULTADOS CAE MUCHO, ES POR TU CULPA. Joaquín Vega.

title: UN MÉTODO DE TRADING, NO ES LO QUE TE HAN CONTADO. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Well, let's see. The other day I met a person, not a student, a businessman, and I explained to him how he should approach, in which phases I would tell him he should pass to be able to do this trading thing. We went to a talk, I was introduced to him, and such, and I spent some time, and I’m going to tell you a bit about what I told him because you know I am very, for some things, when I do group sessions there are certain topics that I always touch on, always, no matter what the sessions are about, there are certain topics that I always touch on because, through repetition, it's the only way I can drill them down, through repetition and repeat, always trying to do it in different ways, or at least explain it in different ways. Today is going to be one of those sessions. Look, I’m going to tell you what I told this man. I explained to him that in this there are five phases. I'm going to tell you exactly how I explained it to him, not only did I write it on a piece of paper and everything. He asked me to write it down on a piece of paper. The first phase you have to train, and now I am studying by themes, subjects, which have nothing to do with each other, theme one, theme two, theme three, and also it's thematic content that is correlated, you should not move on to theme two if you do not know theme one, you shouldn’t go to three if you haven’t understood two, because in the end, it forms a whole and if you miss part of the information, you reach five and you have no clue, you reach theme five and you have no clue because everything is hierarchical, in trading, it’s exactly the same. And if the correct order isn't followed, we're going to have a problem with theme five. If we reach theme five without having studied the previous four properly, then unfortunately, we've wasted our time. Yes, we're on theme five, but it hasn't served any purpose. So let's see if by explaining it as I explained it to this man, I can give you one more point to have a clear idea. It seems that many of you reach theme five, but do not have the previous four right. Therefore, it seems that we are very advanced in five, but no, we are far behind. And this is the problem: the phases we have studied have not been done well. The first phase of any trader should be, let me summarize, working very well with very adequate lot sizes that utilize stop sizes, which means this union of lot sizes and stop sizes, ultimately means risk management, this is what we're talking about, you must have such absolute risk control that is entirely based and controlled against the pain that the sequence of losses will cause you, which yes or yes, you’re going to have. This is theme number one, meaning if I do not have this clear, all I do afterward doesn't matter at all, zero. Learn to walk, ultimately, what risk should I use so that no kind of pain affects me in the sequence of losers. Here, you should spend all the necessary time practicing this, so that when you face any system, this is 100% under control. Notice what I'm telling you, I don't care if you spend a month, two months, three months, six months, or 23 months, you should never move on to lesson number two without this, because if you move on to lesson number two without this, you are wasting your time. The control of risk which is absolutely linked to some lot sizes and stop sizes. It is the cornerstone of everything. The base, one step forward, then the other. I need, when I begin to walk in trading, to be sure I never fall. This is the cornerstone, this is the key piece. To practice this, I do not need any system. I've told you a thousand times how to practice this. You should do hundreds and hundreds and hundreds and hundreds of tests. Logically, this is entirely linked to a business plan. Obviously, you should change and test enough business plans with chart tests, with random entries enough to be completely sure that there’s nothing in a chart that could affect me. What's the worst? We always say it, the sequence of losing trades. You must know what sequence of losing trades you tolerate without any problem, and for that, this sequence of losing trades will logically be related to some stop sizes and some lot sizes. I don't care the reason for the entry. If I do not have this, you will not be successful in trading in your life. Never. Ever. Impossible. It cannot be done. It is not possible. Essential condition. I don’t know how to say it. Without this, you do not win. You play, but you don't win. You can think you are trading, but you don't win. Once you have this, however long it takes to know this, lesson number two would be the other piece missing to the operation, which is to know absolutely the exit, the profit, that meets exactly the same requirement. What size of exit profit is completely balanced to my pain? What exit do I support? How am I going to know the essential complement of risk? If I already know the risk, now I need to do tests again to know not the exit I want, but the exit I endure. In the end, we are talking about pains, as always, once more. Risk pain, exit pain. Forget what you want. I have always told you. It is not valid. The way to win is two, lesson number two. In order for me to move on to lesson two, I must know 100% exactly how I manage risk. If I do not know how I manage loss, how am I going to know how I manage exit? And here again, hundreds and hundreds of trades. And I test with 1-1, and I test with 1-2, and I test with 1-3, and I test with 1-4, with the risk I have already learned from lesson number one, with the lot sizes I have learned from lesson number one, with the stop sizes I have learned from lesson number one. Random entries and a new profit, and hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds. If I have the two lessons done right, if I already know how to lose comfortably, never going beyond my pain, if I already know how to win comfortably, accepting what I bear, I am able to use a method, whatever it is. But I can't look for a method if I don’t have lesson one and lesson two, which we think is a method. How do you establish the basis so that nothing on a chart affects you? How do you establish the bases for an operation to be indifferent about losing or winning it? How is this established? Only in this way. Nothing can alter me in front of a chart. Test, error, test, error, test, error, test, error, hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds, and hundreds. But when I go live, I have to be 100% certain. Once I have lesson number one and lesson number two, which have already made me a rock, where there can be a psychological aspect that affects me? There isn't. There isn't. The third step, lesson number three, would be what are my actions post-entry? When I enter the market, however it might be, with whatever method it might be, with however analysis it might be, once I enter, where I have absolutely controlled stops, therefore even if the stop hits, it won't affect me, and where I have absolutely controlled profit sizes that won't affect me, what conditions of action am I going to put on a post-entry after entering? I put them. Should we put them? It is not mandatory, but it is highly recommended. For me, it is vital. Not only does it not condition me to loss, not only does it not condition me to exit, because I know I handle it well, but I will not even let the price command me, I command it. Meaning, I command the price, not in what it will do, but in my response to what it does. I command my risk pain, I command my loss pain, I command my profit pain. I am the boss of the chart. The boss. Now yes, rules have to be set. Strict ones. Test, error, test, error, test, error. Once again. Test, error, test, error. I put this, I am comfortable, I put this, I am comfortable, I put this, I am comfortable, I put this, I am comfortable. Again. Test, error, test, error, test, error. Time, time, time, time. The fourth is a consequence of the three previous lessons. All the practice you have done, all that work you have done, for each of those lessons, without wanting to, if you have done that work properly, without wanting to, you have been training a fundamental piece, which is the discipline of execution, without wanting to. You have done it so many times that you have generated, you have cultivated the discipline, guys, without intention. Because to know the risks, you have had to execute that repetition with discipline. And another one, and another one, and another one. Unknown sequences. I test with this, and now I test with the other. It is supposed that you are repeating, repeating, repeating. For the profit, the same. You are generating discipline. When making these strict rules, having tested them so many times, you have generated discipline again. You have discipline in the three areas. Without intending to. To who. Time, time, time. Test, error, test, error, test, error. And finally, the last phase. I am going to look for an analysis method. Plus entry. The last thing. Repeat, the last. Do you all remember when I always tell you, give me the method you want, and give me the entry you want? I set the rest. And I make it win. Why do I tell you that? Because of the four previous phases. I have them so entrenched, that with little adjustments to the four preceding phases, with a small adjustment of the risk, with a small adjustment of the profit, with small adjustments of the post-entry rules, I make it win with the analysis method you give me. Any you want. Let me perform enough trades and I make it win. But it is based on the four previous phases, because they are the essence. And now, of course, the usual. Where do you spend 95% of the time? In phase 5. What’s the problem? That four previous ones are lacking, dude. You’re screwed. The typical ones and those so many, many, many, many hours of that entry and analysis method, you should have dedicated to the previous four. When you reach 5 without the previous four solid, well what happens is that you are in theme 5, you have wasted your time. You are wasting your time. You’ll have to go back to phase 1 at some point, if you want to win. Because to solve the problem of 5, you have to have reviewed the previous four. So, the worst that can happen to you is to be in 5 not knowing the previous four. Because the only solution there is not to keep wasting time is, at some given moment, stop and go back to 1. Let’s say that when you are new, when you start, phase 1 takes a long time by itself. Phase 2 takes a long time by itself. Phase 3, a long time. That is to say, when you start, each of them takes a very long time. Now, once you have gone through all that learning, you already know where you are failing. You know if the profit is failing you. You know if a little bit of risk is failing you. You know if that adjustment you made to post-entry rules is too strict. I mean, you notice right away once you have experience. But once you have gone through all that path, it is tiny, it is like if you give me now an analysis method. I can start from lot sizes, stops, a risk. I mean, I would start from these four previous factors to test that analysis method and that entry you are offering me, that I have not even tested. When I try 100 trades or 50 trades, I already know what adjustments I have to make to it. Here I have to put longer stops and I have to reduce the lot size, or I have to put it a longer or shorter profit, or these entry rules are not valid for this way you are telling me. I mean, it is noted. But it is because of the so much test-error you have done. If you have done it right. If you have done it right. This is the typical sequence where I used to say that each of these things I tested in sequence of 300 trades. 300 trades, 300 trades, 300 trades, 300 trades, 300 trades. Are you aware of the background that gives you? That is why you come now to me with a way to analyze the market. You give me a form of entry and I tell you, okay, let me 500 trades minimum. Let me 500 trades to find the point. Sure I find it. I am not saying that I win a lot or little. I am saying that I make it win in a sufficient number of trades. I make it win. I don't know if a lot or little. It will also depend a lot on the form of entry you are telling me. In the end, I want you to understand something. This combination of four is the method. And let us say that five is the trigger. But the method itself is the first four. You have a wrong thought and it is very common, very common when we talk or think about a trading method, we are constantly thinking about the analysis and entry method. As if that were the base, like that's the power, as if that were the solid part. How solid is your method, right? The analysis method with which you analyze and the one with which you enter, that is the entry point. What I am trying to convey is that this is only the trigger, that this is not the method. That has nothing to do with a method. It may be a method of analysis, okay? But when we talk about a consistent method of doing trading, we are not talking about entry methods. This was the first thing I noticed with this man. That trading method you have, what I saw you with the videos and such, you have a trading method based on cycles and based on entries and deception. My trading method is really solid. The thing is, you have the thought that the trading method is what is seen with the cycles, that this is a trigger, that the real power is not in the cycles, that it is not in any analysis method, that it is not in any entry method, that I need you to understand this. Then, I think it's very good that when you are, when you are a novice you think like that. This man, for example, had never done trading. Well, I can understand that he thinks that way. Especially, every time he looks at something on YouTube, basically it is spoken that way, the analysis method and entry method. No, dude, the power is not there, but neither in my method nor in any. It is a simple trigger, it is a simple shot. The power is in the first four and in the base you have more solid or less solid when applying the first four. Let us say this is like an iceberg. This is the tip that is seen, but the real iceberg is here. This is what is not seen. This is what is not seen. And this is what people do not understand. So many of you continue to think like that. You see the tip, what is seen, but what is behind? What is below the water? That is the true key. Then, if we do not change the way of thinking, we cannot do this. If what we are thinking is that the power of trading is in the analysis and in the entry, we are focusing on the tip of the iceberg. It is a huge mistake. It is already a matter of mentality. For you to see that way, that analysis form, those cycles, those zones, that method you want, to see those moments where you enter and after 500 trades you are in positive or after 1,000 trades you are in positive, there is a huge work underwater, which is the one that makes that damn iceberg firm. So, we cannot focus on what is posted in YouTube entries or that absurd mentality, that novice mentality of thinking that the power is there. They are here in each of these four points. Without this base, that little tip of iceberg you see, yours, submerges into the water, disappears. That is why a consistent trader has a very powerful base. That is why he is consistent. But of course, the work behind is huge. Then, the question you have to ask yourself is, these four phases? How solid am I? Am I sure of the lot sizes I use and the stop sizes or do I use the ones I please? Have I really checked that these are mine? Have I verified that the risks I use withstand any losing sequence? Have I checked it? Answer yourselves. That profit exit, am I using the one I like, the one I desire? That thing of letting run to the opposite zones and what the map says and all the roll, is it really what suits me? Is it what makes me win? Is it what makes me calm? Do I take that exit well without any problem? Have I tested different ones? Have I tested several? Or did I get stuck with this? Or did I test one a little bit and stay with this because it's the one, I don’t know? Have you tested that you hold that exit without pain? Are you sure? The post-entry actions? If I don’t use them, and what happens if I use them? Hey, I'm not used to placing post-entry, post-entry actions. What if I used them? Okay, and if I use them, which ones do I use? Because when I enter the market, what's creating insecurity for me? Hey, and should those rules be to move the stop, to take partial, what the hell should it be? To enter with split-entry? How should it be? Because I assure you that in each of these factors there is a detail that is the one that suits you best, but if you don’t find it, you don’t know it. It's about that. I have tested so many things that I know what works well and what doesn't. That is the key. That is, I don’t use something because I know it doesn't work well for me. When I decide to work with some risks, I decide to work with that risk, with those lot sizes and with those stops because I know they are the correct ones for me. Because I have tested other options and I know that for some reason they do not work for me. Either for a mental issue, either because I am unable to repeat it, or because it bothers me, for whatever reason. But when we talk about lot sizes, there is one that is yours. When we talk about stop sizes, there is one that is yours. When we talk about risks to protect against the sequences, there is a risk that is yours. It combines lot sizes, stops, and pain. Combine everything. You must know what it is because you have it. And it's individual, it's personal, it doesn't work for anyone else, but it works for you. How long to test it? As much as necessary. But you must know it, the profit. I assure you that profit is a very delicate thing, but it is as delicate as risks. Because if I do risks right and I don’t do the exit right, I'm screwed just the same. They cannot be separated. They are part of the same operation, they go together, they are indivisible. It is like hit percentage, fail percentage. It cannot be separated. You cannot do one thing right and the other wrong. Or both right or it goes wrong. Therefore, it is the same work, as much for risk as for profit. And here we are not talking about what you like, I always tell you. There is an ideal profit for each one of you. How is it possible that I don’t know what my ideal profit is? Over and over, over and over, over and over. I cannot feel the slightest pain, neither for the risks, nor for the profits. It cannot be. I do not care if it takes a long time to reach my profit, I bear it. I do not care if risks give me 28 losing trades, I bear it. I am a damn rock. I do not care, however bad the entry is, I bear everything, but everything. However lousy streak I have, because the market does not fit my method, I don’t care, I am a damn rock. And that, many times you say, it’s that, damn, I make these entries, they don’t reach the target and I lose confidence. Damn it. Do this I just told you. You will see how you have confidence. The confidence of saying, I don’t care, I know nothing happens. That is confidence. Not that they don’t reach. But how is it that they don’t reach? Well, let them not reach, they will reach. But I have the confidence that what I am doing is precisely what I should do. Point. Because I have verified it. And of course, you can't have discipline if you don't have confidence. And when I talk about confidence, it's not the confidence that I open this trade, and it's going to hit target. I don't know if it's going to hit target or not. I have the confidence that if I do this with discipline, I make money. And if you want, I put it another way. I have the confidence that if I do this with discipline, if I lose, I lose little. Put it whichever way you want. But you can't have discipline if you don't have confidence. It is impossible. Repetition, another fundamental part, repetition discipline to have repetition of action. A repetition of action doing actions that I know exactly which are mine, that I know exists a exits that are mine and that I know which is the lot sizes I should apply. I have the confidence to repeat that with discipline. This is what takes time. And here is where the juice is. When we are spending all the time on the tip, you are wasting time, folks. And there is nothing that bothers me more than you wasting time. Because this is very easy to understand. And all of you now that I am telling you, explaining this, you all know that it is so. But do you know what the problem is? That one of the things that torments you all the most, in general, is time. Giving time to the boring, because this is all very boring, what is fun is on the chart. That is what is fun in the analysis method, hitting the operation at the entry point. That waste of time, in quotes, that you believe is doing all this, as it is not attractive, as it is not suggestive, as it is not visible, as it is not seen on the chart, boom, I hit the operation, as this is a dirty work, you do not do it. You do not do it. I am fed up with doing the dirty work. But it cannot be done in another way. When I did this, with trading, the 1, the 2, the 3, and the 4, I was fed up with making entries, testing risks, testing profits, testing rules after entering. I was fed up. But for the trader certificate, you either do it or you do the dirty work, or there's no title. You can call yourself a trader, but you’re not a trader. You play trading, but there is no dirty work behind.

decision_points.condition: If you master risk management, balancing lot sizes and stop sizes
decision_points.if_true: Proceed to the next lesson, knowing risk is under control
decision_points.if_false: Do not proceed without complete risk management control
decision_points.quote_es: El control del riesgo que es absolutamente unido a unos lotajes y unos tamaños de esto.
decision_points.quote_en: The control of risk which is absolutely linked to some lot sizes and stop sizes.

decision_points.condition: If you can comfortably lose without exceeding your pain threshold
decision_points.if_true: Begin focusing on profit targets without stress
decision_points.if_false: Do not establish profit targets without managing loss first
decision_points.quote_es: Si ya sé perder de forma cómoda, jamás pasándome de mi dolor.
decision_points.quote_en: If I already know how to lose comfortably, never going beyond my pain.

decision_points.condition: If post-entry strategies are clearly defined and controlled
decision_points.if_true: Have psychological peace and control over the trade
decision_points.if_false: Implement and test different post-entry rules
decision_points.quote_es: Ahora sí, aquí hay que poner reglas. Estrictas.
decision_points.quote_en: Now yes, here rules have to be set. Strict ones.

concepts.name: Risk Management
concepts.definition: The process of balancing lot sizes and stop sizes to control risk painlessly during losing streaks.
concepts.relationship: Foundation of a trading strategy, precursor to profit strategy.

concepts.name: Profit Management
concepts.definition: Setting profit targets without exceeding the psychological pain threshold.
concepts.relationship: Follows and complements risk management.

concepts.name: Post-Entry Strategy
concepts.definition: Actions defined by the trader post-entry to control and manage trade outcomes.
concepts.relationship: Enhances risk and profit management by minimizing emotional impact during trades.

concepts.name: Discipline Through Repetition
concepts.definition: Building trading discipline by repeating risk and profit experiments to discover personal strategies.
concepts.relationship: An outcome of thorough practice of the first three concepts.

concepts.name: Trading Methods as Triggers
concepts.definition: Viewing traditional entry analysis and methods as mere triggers, not the core method.
concepts.relationship: Emphasizes the importance of foundational risk/profit management over entry/exit timing.

rules.rule: Do not proceed to the next lesson without mastering the current phase.
rules.context: Applies to each phase of trading education, particularly risk management.

rules.rule: Set tight risk controls by practicing with different lot sizes and stops.
rules.context: During initial phases to ensure psychological comfort during losses.

rules.rule: Invest time in defining post-entry actions to dictate market behavior.
rules.context: After ensuring risk and profit controls; controls trader’s response to market movements.

rules.rule: Test all strategies extensively before relying on them.
rules.context: Applies to both risk and profit strategies to ensure minimal psychological impact.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the significance of mastering foundational trading phases before engaging in trading methodologies. He identifies five key phases, with risk management being the cornerstone, followed by controlled profit management, and establishing strict post-entry strategies. Each phase requires thorough practice and an understanding of personal pain thresholds to ensure psychological resilience. Rather than focusing solely on entry methods, traders should develop a deep base of disciplined practice across a multitude of trades, making the traditional method of analysis just a trigger in a larger strategy.

_metadata.title: UN MÉTODO DE TRADING, NO ES LO QUE TE HAN CONTADO. Joaquín Vega.

title: Debate entre traders SOBRE EL DRAWDOWN EN TRADING. Joaquín Vega, Pablo Ortiz y Víctor Gómez ( 1/3 ).

analysis.translation: Hello guys, today we've gathered here with some colleagues because we wanted to discuss a topic with you once again that we find super interesting. What better than being here with people who are educating others, students, especially on this topic where they surely emphasize a lot, we'd like to talk a bit about this. Trying to give the guys here, Pablo Ortiz, Víctor Gómez, how are you guys? Very good. Very good, Joaquín, very good. Very good, Pablo, how are you? What do you guys think we should talk about? Well, I think we should delve into the drawdown, which brought up a lot of questions. Important topic, right? Yes, yes. How could we approach the topic of drawdown to tackle it intensely, Pablo? Well, I think by perhaps looking at a couple of different aspects, if you want, we can start. Is there a magic number where we should stop? Is there a magic percentage, or does it not matter, or does it depend on the moment? What do you guys think? 30. I'll start. The 30? Why, Víctor? Because when you reach that amount, at least with my style of trading, you've traded so poorly, or things haven’t gone well enough that turning it around, I mean recovering, is tremendously complicated. In other words, you should never get that far, no way. But, everything depends on the system. You can have a system that gives you a very large drawdown but also when you win, you win a lot. However, systems that fluctuate so much are usually complicated and I think emotionally even more difficult. Therefore, since I trade with a lot of leverage, doing scalping, I have no choice but to work with very tight stops because I can't allow a trade to eat 10-15% of my account and reach that in two trades. Since I go with a lot of leverage, I have to work with very small stops because otherwise, four or five good trades could come, but when two or three bad ones come, you can't lift the account. With my way of trading or the way I face the market with funded or very small personal accounts, small I mean perhaps $5,000-$7,000 and trading with two contracts on Nasdaq, which is quite leveraged. If you fall there, forget it. In fact, you might not even have guarantees to recover. And what do you think, Joaquín? I think to tackle this topic, we should go to the beginning. The beginning is based on the fact that the person who enters trading, or this industry rather than trading, has to understand that everyone wants their money. That's to start with. If you enter the chart and start trading on the platform, you have the banks that will want your money, the investment funds will want your money, and the brokers will want your money. If you step outside the platform and we go out of that context, you will have people wanting to sell you courses, and even if you don't pay them, you'll generate money for them, like for example, our YouTube channels. That clear. What does this mean? When you enter here, everyone wants your money. Thousands of people are after your money. Therefore, if you get into this story, you have to understand this. Everyone is after you. It's like you want to reach the river, and you have to cross a jungle. There are lions, tigers, buffaloes, and cobras, and what you want. Before reaching the river, the first thing is you have to survive. Therefore, this is where the enormous importance of drawdown comes from. This is where it comes from. Because your survival depends on it. There's nothing else that will make you survive in this jungle. Because this is a jungle. A pure jungle. Therefore, the preservation of your money is the only thing that will get you to the river. The only thing. Thus, I consider and am of the opinion that the less drawdown you have, the better for you. But I differentiate drawdown above the capital account, your capital money, and below your capital money. I make two differentiations that we can talk about later if you want. But if we talk below your initial capital, you can never exceed 20%. If pushed, 15. At least personally, I'm in at 15. If I reach 15, it's the end. Okay, we will see what end means because it's not the same to stop at 15 and go to demo. The next question would be, when do we return? What we’ve calculated is, I’ve calculated 22.5% for mathematical reasons. Basically, in a normal system, you have a mathematical expectation of 15€ on an average 10,000€ account. It's called not automatic. In a trend-following system, you have a superior mathematical expectation of 30€ per entry, and in a scalping system, you have a lower mathematical expectation of 8€. So I calculated, at 22.5%, we need 43 more winning trades to get back to the break-even point. I said, hell, 43 has to happen. That could occur in 5 months or 6. Meaning, the more drawdown we assume, the longer the recovery time will be. And if the recovery becomes a year, then it's unfeasible. Because emotionally, being a year suffering what we call the ulcer index, which is the time spent in drawdown multiplied by the depth. Sure, a year at 20 below zero, as they say, imagine. I don't know if you've skied. I have been at 20 below zero in the Pyrenees and Switzerland, skiing. It's harsh, huh? Don't know if you guys have been at 20 below zero. I've slept at 20 below zero. Oh, man, yours is hardcore then. In Gredos. And thought why wasn't I on my sofa at home. Well, imagine 20 below zero one day, right? But 20 below zero for six months, it's tough, right? I think it's important for me to put depth and time in relation because it's not the same falling into a 15 and recovering quickly. There I might agree with Victor, because in a scalping system, it is easy to recover when it goes well. And perhaps in a trend-following system, if you are in drawdown, the market is not favorable to you. I don't know how Joaqin sees it. Then maybe it should be differentiated by system type. I don't have, for example, a linear operation. There are people who are at plus one, operate the same as if they are at minus one, or minus three, or plus seven, or plus twelve. There are people who operate linearly and it doesn't affect them and they don't change their way of operating. I operate by segments. I completely operate by segments. I mark my segments, like to give you an idea, when I initiate an account, I open a range of a first plus five and minus five. In that range, I can be, because also when you open an account, it's the most critical moment. Therefore, I can be there oscillating between plus five, minus five, but if I reach minus five, there's an alert. There’s an alert, and I have to change something because when I'm oscillating at that moment, I'm thinking of making money, but when I'm at minus five, I'm thinking of recovering it. They're different things. The attitude you have when facing, am I in the condition to make money, should I recover this to make money later? They're very different things. Therefore the operation and mental conditions are entirely different. This is why I believe that linear operation can't be done. There should be segments and changes in the operation. This is fundamental to me. I completely agree with what Joaquín says, and actually, the first thing he mentioned about the drawdown, it is indeed true that the smaller it is, the better, and indeed, in this industry, the normal thing is to lose money. Often someone comes to me, Víctor, I want to learn how much you think I can earn, what is your profitability? I say, this is my profitability and even if you were to operate, not even by copying would you do the same as me, not even by copying because you will take three stops, the fourth and the fifth you won't do because you are scared, and that's just the way it is. And it's true that the more demanding you are with your drawdown, the better because as normal as it is to lose, if you start losing and losing, the sooner you stop, the easier or not that you will recover, but if you start working to change those circumstances. If you move away too much, as mentioned, a 30, me doing scalping, it's okay, but if you get in there, forget it, you're already dead on the way long before. And above all because the attitude, as Joaquín comments more, it is not the same when you are winning as when you are losing, it's not the same. And I, when five positive trades come, I do the sixth trade, I don’t behave the same. I don't have the same confidence, not aggression, confidence upon operating when I get five stoppages. I could be winning for six months, five bad trades come and the sixth, my hand trembles to press a button. My behavior is different. So yes, you have to change. Yes, sometimes you lower leverage and start trading again well, but you have to change your way of facing the market because what you were doing at that moment does not work either because of the market or because you are not applying the system correctly. I have a system, and it’s not the system’s profitability, it's the profitability I get with it because with the system, I might spend a month thinking, I always look at my statistics when I lose money, saying, let's see what's failing here. I end up watching trades and thinking, how are you trading so poorly? You shouldn't have entered because the price didn't go in favor, it's not even that the operation met the conditions nor is it the setup. Could it be that type of operation? Because of anxiety, because of fear, or sometimes because of overconfidence, but these are those moments you have to stop and decide, let's see, and let's see how we recover. And you were asking earlier, Pablo, going back to the simulator? By all means, you actually have to be trading to make money, and when you're not making money, you lower leverage or go back to the simulator, which doesn’t mean anything at all. I think there's an interesting fact. Once speaking with a manager from the City, Smile, a manager, he said he wanted to talk with us to bring things over there. He says, your robots will go through my servers. He says when you reach a 30% drawdown, I will stop all your operations, and the relationship ends. I asked, why? He said, because in London, we sign a notarial power with the clients and by law, when it's greater than 30%, I go to jail. And I said, just like Spain, man. So, there's a consensus that 30% is like the absolute minimum. I think it would be interesting, perhaps, if the nuance from 30 to 20 is important, or do you think it depends on the operation or depends on the psychology, or how do you see it? It's personal, it's absolutely personal. And each must know their tolerance. When I talk about very low drawdowns, money is the least of it. The important thing is the state you find yourself in when you are there. Because most likely, you're going to get worse. So, what point for each person? Because there is no generic figure. It’s impossible. We could all agree, for example, more than a 30 is madness. But defining a 20, a 15, a 10, it's already a bit more personal. But, I'll tell you something. What Víctor says, for example, about going back to DEMO, I don't want to see the DEMO, not even in painting. Not even in painting because it's useless. What I propose and what I recommend and what I myself did and do is, you have to stop. That's clear, you have to stop. You will set the first level of alert, and at my first level of alert, it's a minus 5, you have to stop. I have to review exactly what has happened there. If it was the market if it was me, if it was, I don't know, whatever it was. I have to review. I have to review and correct because sure you find, logically, when you review, you find. But once you find and learn what you don't have to do, I continue in real. I continue in real because... But do you lower monetary management? The question I have for both of you is, do you lower monetary management when you're entering the pit? For example, you entered with 0.2 lots or two contracts, whatever, above, at the initial capital? And vice versa? When you've accumulated capital, do you increase? Because this would also affect your drawdown. How do you manage it? If Víctor wants to go first or Joaquín. Víctor, Víctor. As you want, I'll go. Joaquín, Joaquín. Let's see... I agree with Joaquín. I'm going to talk about a couple of topics that Joaquín and you have commented on. It's true that the simulated... that winning in simulated doesn't guarantee anything at all. And when you know how to trade... Let's see... Personally, lower leverage. What happens is... I do this with students because I think it's like this. I think it's like this, you know? See, when, for instance, I have a student who wants to start learning trading, it has to be in demo. Why? Because in real, the pressure you have doesn't allow you to learn or develop the skill since, in the end... You learn a setup, but when you're live in the market in real-time, hindsight you say, I should have entered here. But in real-time, gosh, for me, it's not like driving, but you have to catch that point. And why am I going to try doing it losing money? That I'm scared and in the end, you end up entering with eight contracts in reverse. And you're doing precisely the opposite, of what you have to learn or to develop that skill. Then, simulated. It is true that... I don't pass any student to real until they win for two months in simulated. And also, when they move to real, I tell them, or with a funded account because you're going to risk 80 euros, or with your account if you want, of 100 euros. The smallest you can afford because normality will be losing it. That's it, once someone is already real sometimes, we often discover things they weren't doing in the simulated stage. It means they have learned, they have shown to win. Not with my system. Sometimes they modify things that seem good to me because not with the system. The system is the least important. They're winning, showing that understanding the market always makes money, and they start in reality, and they are not doing the same thing anymore. But it's not that they don't do the same thing, but maybe there's an upward trend day, and maybe they start looking for shorts. And you say, why? Because you can find a long, and the market turns and hits your stop. Or they remove the stop. Things they didn’t do in simulated, they do because they are playing with money, and it affects them emotionally, and there you know what I do. Going back to the simulated to work the necessary habits to continue doing the same thing and be profitable. Be careful, and they won't almost ever make it the first time.
