But yes, I mean, I have students who can make eight trades a day, or I do. But I, for example, I am incapable of letting the price run. I try, and the price goes with plus 30 and comes back leveraging, or with my leverage or a euro, for me it affects me emotionally. And if that makes me three times, I end up removing the stop and end up blowing an account. Me, so what do I do? Go back to the simulated, what do I do? But close in zones. Now, that's it, if I close with five points, I can't put a stop of 15. That's it. At least by my stats. Adjust that trading plan or that system to me and then back to real again. Now, it's true that if you're operating in real and say no, now a season simulated, no, the simulated you will show again that you know how to do things, but where you have to learn to control is in real. That's it. There is a transition period, but indeed, real is the real. And you may as well be the god of simulated that it won't serve you at all in real. That's it, the first point Joaquín was commenting on. And the question you've asked me, Pablo, was... We were with whether you operate the same in monetary management. If you're in the pit, do you modify your charge? I always operate in mini. And well, I work with several funded accounts. You guys know, they are companies where you fund and have their pros and cons. So, I have several accounts. I operate with the mini. I have a week because as I operate live, well, I operate live with students, but on Twitch, I don't know why, emotionally, it's like I have to justify more, as showing more of what I do and mess up. But hey, I get over it more or less. What happened was that I lowered the leverage and operated better and won every day. Less, but less by four accounts. In the end, it's the same as when I operated with one account. It's all here because the points I make are the same points, but of course, instead of going to 40, I go to 4 dollars, but for 3 or 4 accounts. In the end, what happens? It seems silly, but from losing, losing, losing, what can you come with? Gosh, that I win every day. Why? Because losing 8 or 15 dollars in one account, I don't care, as Joaquín says, it's going to be the risk aversion that we each have that will affect us. And you take and win every day. Yes, I have earned 30, but 30 times 4 is 120. 30 times 4 is 120 dollars. A daily income stream of 120 dollars isn't bad for anyone, right? And if you're with the mini, watch out, with the mini, it's doing well, but it is true, this year I won in January, February, March, in April I lost, and in May, if I didn’t change, I wasn't going to make money. So yes, the leverage matters a lot and in the end, maybe sound like hot air or, right? Everything is in the head. Hot air sellers, hot air sellers. Hot air. When you know what you have to do and you don't do it. Air sellers, air sellers. That's it, that's it. I mean, but that's something, there you only learn by getting your... immersing yourself with your feet inside the market and hitting it. Sure. I, for example... The robots are always in demo. I have there the servers and always operate in demo. What happens is there is one more distinction. I don't think it's the same if you trade for yourself particularly as suddenly you’re operating to generate a track record, which is, I mean, if you're generating a track record for anything or such, you operate a little more nicely or care more that it's looking nice than if it's for yourself, it doesn't matter, you do your thing, you know how far you can go. I think there's an important distinction. It's very, very different, huh? Very different. Because it's your money and it's for you, and you don't have to, well, you operate with management, I'm not saying different, but you don't take as much care of the niceness of drawdown and such. If you'd like to say if you go to simulated or to demo, do you set a minimum time, or it’s an emotional topic until you’re okay or how long or if you lower lots, Joaquín? Do you set a minimum? We do it. I mean, we set minimum dates. If you touch a 22.5%, to me, the number is six months. I know it's a little bestial, but something very, very serious has happened when you've reached a 22, 23%, for small accounts, for big accounts, we go to a 15. Careful. The bigger, the less drawdown. Less drawdown. I mean, in a large account, a 15. So, for me, it's six months. I don't know if for you, it's also an interesting subject. I mean, when you hit when the red alert goes off, for us, it's like a color alert system. I liked what Joaquín said, if you want to delve into about the trams later. For me, a five is like yellow, and a 15 is intensely red, and a 20 is black. Four colors, right? Of course. When the black alert goes off, for me, it's six months. I tell you I always go by segments because I consider, I believe that the mental aspect goes by segments. It goes by segments according to where your account is. So if I reach minus five, like I said earlier, I stop, and the way, my first thought is to get back to the initial point because if not, I cannot be thinking about earning money. So, I resort, I go for very long objectives, you know too Pablo, I go for very long-term goals. So what I do is an operation with less bold entries, let's say, more conservative and lesser ratio. I lower the ratio a lot because what it touches is to recover, not earn money; it’s to recover. Then I base it like this until I return to the starting point and start again with the predefined, let's say, start. And the watermark because you're working on watermark, do you increase, for example, if you've gained a 10% account, do you leave it at the 10%, or do you count the watermark at zero, your initial capital? I mean, do you accumulate the capital and say if I fall below the 110, I consider the zero again or... Look, this is an issue that maybe I do it special or something odd. I, for instance, when I tell you that below I have those alarms below, and I have to change my operation because the condition, both mine and the operation, requires it; I also tell you that when I have a five percent cushion, I always want to be free in the market. I mean, my obsession is having a cushion that I know whatever I do is free, and to me that cushion is 5%. But when I have that cushion, just like when I have a minus five, I change; when I have a plus five, I also change. And I mean, I have the necessary resources to be a little more aggressive. Do you understand? I mean, I work with very little lotage that you know, too, if I put 0.10% shot, it is the moment to put 0.20%. Okay. And I have a cushion there. Double. You double. I double. And I maintain, let's say, a flat rate. I mean, if I enter with 0.20% of capital, I maintain a flat rate until, for example, I reach a 15% cushion. But a moment comes that I no longer put more in. It's already a flat rate forever. Each time I earn money, I don't increase lotage because have my comfort there. Do you understand? A time comes that, just like Víctor can maybe put two contracts, his comfort might be working with 3 contracts. So, even though I make more money, I won't put more in because I don’t want to leave my comfort zone. Clear. So, there are segments for everything. To be more aggressive and to reduce aggression and control and understand that you have to recover. I think this is common sense, and a linear operation should not be done. We are working, Víctor and I, in Artificial Intelligence to precisely make a segments model. I found this curious, never talked about it, and I find it curious. So, Víctor, how do you see the segments’ topic? See, as we don't all behave the same way, I put my particular case. I operate with the Mini. If it goes well, I have a little program with several Ninja accounts open at once, and for example, last year, which was going very well operationally, I’d operate the Mini, and what did I do? Another two accounts replicate. Why? Because as everything comes out almost, there are no issues. This year, as I had trading accounts or funding accounts with very big distinct conditions, I couldn’t operate an account where I could win or lose and then I move to another. Right? But for example, here now it has a little bad streak this month that things aren’t being good or because the system isn’t, the market isn’t in the necessary conditions for the system because I work with this five points and maybe because there is more volatility, and it jumps, and it jumps, then it goes in favor or because it tends to generate anxiety, and in the end, you end up joining or skip some parameter. What have I done? I’ve lost every day but... well, one day... No, the day before yesterday, I lost a little, but a little. But, well, that practically I have changed the circumstances, meaning you lose, lose, win, lose, lose, win a little, win a little, but I win every day, and as I always say, confidence is in winning. If you don't win, I don’t care; you won’t trust what you do, no way. So currently, what do I have? I've lowered the amount of accounts I have. I know it's all about the numbers, but I told myself, I'm having so much fun operating in front of you guys and enjoying it and winning that what I'm going to do is grab another account that replicates with low leverage and think of an account that could be 2,000 dollars, and I'm operating 4 dollars the point, and I do scalping going for 6 points or losing 5. How many negative operations must I come wrong to blow the account? A bunch. What I'm thinking almost is to get more accounts and keep adding them, which in the end, what I'm doing is having a bigger account and operating with lower leverage. This is a little more spread out, thanks to this system is working better at the moment. That there are moments in which with that more beautiful could come out and you say, damn, it's better to increase leverage and win. But do you know what happens? Very often, when you desire more than what you can do, you get in, you no longer do the same, and hit big bumps. So, at the moment, if it is true that depending on how it goes, how the market is, the system is, and particularly, it is reflected, you have to be playing there with the risk and what you do. Okay, that's it. Should we move over to my channel and continue over there? Do you pay something? Let's go. Come on, let's go. Okay.

decision_points.condition: A trader reaches a drawdown of 30%
decision_points.if_true: It indicates poor trading performance, and recovering from it becomes tremendously complicated.
decision_points.if_false: The system may allow for a larger drawdown because it also offers high returns.
decision_points.quote_es: Porque cuando llegas a esa cantidad, al menos con mi forma de operar, has operado tan mal o no han ido tan bien las cosas que darle la vuelta a esa cantidad, o sea recuperar, es tremendamente complicado.
decision_points.quote_en: Because when you reach that amount, at least with my style of trading, you've traded so poorly or things haven’t gone well enough that turning it around, I mean recovering, is tremendously complicated.

decision_points.condition: A trader's drawdown reaches 15% below initial capital
decision_points.if_true: Stop trading and analyze the situation, potentially return to demo mode.
decision_points.if_false: Continue trading but possibly reduce the level of aggressiveness.
decision_points.quote_es: Pero si hablamos por debajo de tu capital inicial, jamás puedes pasarte de un 20%. Y si me apuras, un 15.
decision_points.quote_en: But if we talk below your initial capital, you can never exceed 20%. If pushed, 15.

decision_points.condition: The total drawdown hits 22.5%
decision_points.if_true: A prolonged period is needed for recovery; suggest a break in trading for 6 months.
decision_points.if_false: Maintain trading with strong caution; adjust the trading strategy.
decision_points.quote_es: En el 22,5% necesitamos 43 operaciones más ganadoras para volver al punto de equilibrio.
decision_points.quote_en: At 22.5%, we need 43 more winning trades to get back to the break-even point.

decision_points.condition: Trader has a 5% gain cushion
decision_points.if_true: Adjust the trading strategy to be more aggressive.
decision_points.if_false: Maintain conservative trading strategies with lower lot sizes.
decision_points.quote_es: Mi obsesión es tener un colchón que sepa que lo que haga es gratis y para mí ese colchón es el 5%.
decision_points.quote_en: My obsession is having a cushion that I know whatever I do is free and to me that cushion is 5%.

concepts.name: Drawdown
concepts.definition: The decline from a peak in the capital to the lowest trough in a trading account. It's suggested never to exceed 30% in total or 15% from the initial capital.
concepts.relationship: Relates to risk management, survivability in trading, and psychological state handling.

concepts.name: Scalping
concepts.definition: A high-frequency trading strategy focusing on very short-term gains with very tight stops.
concepts.relationship: Requires low drawdown tolerance and careful position management.

concepts.name: Risk Management
concepts.definition: The process of identifying, assessing, and controlling financial risk.
concepts.relationship: Involves setting drawdown limits, monitoring market conditions, and adjusting trading strategies.

concepts.name: Demo Trading
concepts.definition: Trading in a simulated environment with virtual capital to practice strategies safely.
concepts.relationship: Used to develop skills but not emotionally equivalent to live trading.

concepts.name: Segment Trading
concepts.definition: An approach where trading actions are changed based on specific segments of account performance.
concepts.relationship: Contrasts with linear trading; aligns trading choices with current account states.

rules.rule: Never allow drawdown to exceed 15% from your initial capital.
rules.context: When trading below your capital to ensure account sustainability.

rules.rule: Stop trading and reflect if drawdown breaches 22.5%.
rules.context: Once significant drawdown is incurred to reassess strategies and potential systemic flaws.

rules.rule: Adjust aggressiveness based on a 5% gain cushion.
rules.context: Allows a trader to take calculated risks when enough profit cushion is established.

rules.rule: Return to demo mode or reduce leverage in the face of significant losses.
rules.context: Used as a corrective measure when strategies fail or emotions alter trading actions.

analysis.summary: This video addresses the importance of managing drawdown in trading, emphasizing that keeping it lower ensures better survivability in the volatile trading market. Joaquín Vega stresses the need to understand the psychological impact of losses and encourages traders to set clear percentage limits, like 15% from capital, as part of their risk management. When in severe drawdown, it's crucial to reassess the trading strategy, possibly reducing leverage or returning to a simulated demo environment to recalibrate. Vega also underscores the need for adapting trading strategies based on account performance segments, allowing both conservative and aggressive strategies where appropriate. The discussion also illustrates the risks of linear trading and advocates for variable approaches under different market conditions.

_metadata.title: Debate entre traders SOBRE EL DRAWDOWN EN TRADING. Joaquín Vega, Pablo Ortiz y Víctor Gómez ( 1/3 ).

title: En trading, NO QUIERO TENER MUCHO ACIERTO, QUIERO GANAR MUCHO DINERO. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: The first thing I want you to understand is why I use the concept of hedging. Understand that I always work with a dual direction. When I talk to analysts about this topic, I tell them that for me, trends don't exist. I know they do, as we see them on charts; a trend is a succession of similar moves in the same direction, yes. But it doesn't make me work in one direction. My mind thinks in a constant dual direction because there's absolute certainty: the price goes up and down. I don't commit to any direction, so I don't have directional pressure. Those who work with charts feel pressured about which direction to take. Choose whichever direction you want. If I don't catch you going up, I'll catch you going down. Do you understand my way of thinking? This way of thinking, when facing a chart without a direction obsession, means I only work according to what the chart says under my objective methodology. It doesn't matter whether you go up or down, liberating me when viewing a chart. I earn equally if you go up or down. So I try in the long term and the short term, because it doesn't matter. This dual direction thinking is why I use hedges. Basically, I'm constantly trying to go with the price. I always want to be with it. I will try. If you rise and fall, remember it's fractal? Absolutely certain? Well, I want to be with you as much as possible. For all the attempts I'll make—up or down—some will catch a trend, a fractal consequence in my favor, and give me profit. I know this, but it doesn't matter whether it's up or down. Therefore, I need to try double. But I always want to be with you, as long as possible. Are bullish trends forming? I want to be. Bearish? I want to be there. Whichever you want, you decide. But I will try to catch you at the start, because it'll give me more movement. If I know the market is fractal, either up or down, we've said there are constant turns. There will be constant turns. Fine, I always want one of these because they will happen. Maybe I'll mistake the timing. Many times, I will be wrong, no doubt. No problem, it's part of the business plan. When I catch you and form a trend, whether longer or shorter, you'll give me movement. Therefore, I'll try to capture you. I forget about direction. I work with the essence of charts, the fractality, the turns, which result in trends that give me profit. When people try to get into the trend, I've been in it for a quarter of an hour. When people are entering, I'm already taking partials. But it doesn't end here. Do you know what happens? What's the problem? Trends end. Another contrary will form. But do you know what happens? When a trend forms, whether it be in whatever timeframe you prefer, and I'm trying to catch this turn, I don't know if it will continue up. When I'm doing this, trying to enter in some of these points, or lower cycle points, for example, I don't know if this will continue or do the opposite. If I got in here at the trend's origin, I don't know how far it will go. But when you turn, I want to be there. Not only do I want to be there, when you turn in this first attempt that I caught you at—if it's here, or here, or here—at the trend's origin or whichever timeframe, I must be alive to have taken some money before you turn. I must be alive for the exit. Of course, if I capture some money, the long position is already a winner. But I have no idea how far that's going to go. I don't know when it will turn. But I know the long position is winning. I don't have a clue if the price here will continue up or turn now. What does this mean? That I must keep a live position as an essential requirement. For several reasons. You might continue much further. And if you continue, I want to go. I'll have a limit to how long I can hold out. Of course, we all have exit limits. I do too. But I'll try to prolong as much as possible. Without dynamic stop nonsense. Because if you turn, I'll attempt flipping attempts. I might try here and fail. No problem. Maybe I tried here and failed. No problem. I keep earning. But when you fall and I catch you, I'll have a live one. But when I'm positioned in a sale, is it going to fall or keep rising? Do whatever you want. Why? Remember, I already have this in my portfolio. It's already mine, already earned it. And I still maintain a live position of X lot size. One or two or three. Depending on how I entered here, if I came with a heavy load, I might still have two or three. And when I position here and the price is here, I don't know what you're going to do. Because I don't care about direction obsession. I don't care about trend obsession. Feel free to take me out. I'll still keep winning with what I have alive. These losses are covered. The losses are free. Yeah, sure. Joaquin messes up a lot. Yeah, whatever. He has crappy accuracy percentages. But they’re free. So I won't quit. Until I catch it, I won't quit. Therefore, these sales are paid. So, what happens when I catch you? That's when the real hedging concept comes in. If I have three positions where I already took two positively out, or three—it could be different—or I entered with three and took out one. It mainly depends on the number of positions put at the start. If I have three alive, three live positions, which ultimately is one minimum, I want to go here with the same. And if I can, with two more. Or one more. With a few more. But minimum, minimum, minimum, I must carry what I have. Therefore, when I'm here, and now this happens—I just placed that new position here—now I'm selling. I'm going with three plus two. The price is in my favor. These positions are already covered. Want to take another? Take it out! I keep winning. Now, want to turn? Turn. What I’m losing on this rise, I'm winning with this, but with more two. I cover the three below, cover the three above, and have two to play with in partials. At a certain partial amount, bam! More two. So, I caught this rise with more two, and I caught this part with more two. I continue with three, and I continue with three. And once I've taken partials in one place and another place, where these positions are already covered below, and these positions are already covered above, I no longer know what direction it will continue. I already won on the rise and on the fall. Perfect! But now what are you going to do? If you fall, I keep winning. Because if it goes back, it will take these three. But when these three trigger, here I still take out two. And I continue holding one, in case you keep dropping lower. I said it, if you go up, I want to go with you. If you fall down, I want to go with you. And below, I’ll want to put more cover again at some point. I always want to go with you. Rise, fall, do what you want. Therefore, I want to, for example, be with oil constantly. I want to be with gold constantly, until maybe at some point I am no longer interested for whatever reason, retain the hedge, cash in profits of what’s there and forget about it, like we did yesterday. And start again. But I will start over with the same system. So since I want to be with you, it doesn’t matter if you move up or down, the moment I catch you, I will be looking for hedging. The moment I catch one, that gives me trajectory, and I can do this with the first position, constantly looking for hedging. At some point, they will close. Obviously. And start again. And start again. And start again. It doesn’t bother me how many trades it takes to catch the turn. Logically, those turns are sought through work zones, through processes, through thousands of ways you can try to find those turns. Turning zones. I’m not looking for turns without reason. I'm looking for places that might be of interest to find those turns. If there's synchrony of reasons, all the more reason. I’m not constantly looking for this anywhere. I have a map for this. This frees me completely from direction, which is one of the obsessions you all have. What’s it going to do? I don’t know; let it do whatever. The price is going up. Buy, then? No. How is buying mandatory? Either it goes up or down, I say again. You work with hedging in one asset. Seriously will be much simpler. I’m amazed at how complicated people make things. If at some point that rises and falls, heck. If you want to work with hedging, work it in the same chart, because it’s the essence of it for me. It’s not about direction obsession. If you don’t catch it now, you may catch it later. When you free yourself from directional thinking, your thought is always dual direction. The pressure you work with is absolutely different. You're not waiting on what you'll do. Whatever rises will sooner or later fall, man. Absolutely. We don’t know when, we don’t know where, but we have certain zones to try. If I have well-distributed all the attempts I make in a good business plan, it doesn’t matter. Because I have subdivided the risk so well that I don’t mind failing 3, 4, 5, 6 times. That’s why I enter with small lot size. But when I catch you with five steaks, it’s noticeable. Therefore, the loss or sequences of losses don’t affect me. The account doesn’t fall excessively. It can be maintained, falling gently. But when I catch five, it rises. That's it, it’s as simple as that. Now, is this for everyone? No. Why not? Because, as you're seeing, the first thing to keep in mind, I don’t go for a fixed ratio. I know I need to take an average when I win that's around 1-10. But I’m always going over by letting it run above 1-10. That’s why I’m not worried. When working on a fixed ratio, it’s more complex. Can you mentally support this operation? If not, you can’t do it, no matter how nice it seems. Because I can spend days and days and days and days. This month, those who’ve started with me on the account have been waiting for two weeks, watching it come, and I miss it, and miss it, and miss it, and miss it, and fail, and fail, and fail. Until the market aligns with me, which is what I’m waiting for. Align at some attempt. Then you’ll give it all at once. This is what we did yesterday, taking profits. I'm not after daily profits. I don’t want daily market winnings. I just want whatever it gives. If I must wait three weeks, I wait. Don’t worry. But I know it will give it. I’m going to catch it. Total control of losses, but it’ll give in. Whether you want to or not, it’ll give it. What you don’t know is when. I don’t need to get it right. I don’t want to be right. I want money. I don’t want to be highly accurate. I want to win big. Therefore, those who want to be accurate, enjoy your accuracy. I know what I need. A little. Now, those streaks will be very long. Watching the chart how it takes me out, managing, managing, managing, managing, managing. That’s why not everyone can do this. Let’s think it coldly. Mental stress. The person constantly thinking about accuracy feels stressed because when he sees five failures, the obsession with being right kicks in. Who has more stress? That person or I? The one obsessed with being right? Or the one who lives with failure? Who carries more pressure? When you coexist with the chart and failure, there's no stress. High accuracy is not essential for winning. When one understands this mentally, there is no stress. It doesn’t exist. Accuracy doesn’t guarantee money. Thoughts from the dark side. What can influence me on a chart? So when I face a chart, there’s no stress. What happens with this is that you need time. You need perfect management. You must do perfect risk management and perfect exit management. That’s not a problem. It's easy. It’s about dividing the positions you enter. The more trades you make, the less you risk. Easy as hell. Alright. Assume it will take time to catch yours. You need to know exactly what management to do. Lot size and exits. Then get to trading. Who has stress? What’s more, I’m looking at the chart, and it doesn’t bother me whether it rises or falls. Look at my stress level. You have to buy an uptrend. Relax. Downtrend. Relax. I'll catch you. Obsession with direction and accuracy. If you don’t know the direction, you won’t win anything. If you don’t hit the direction, you won’t gain anything. If you don’t have a 50% hit rate, you won’t gain anything. 18% hit rate. Doubling accounts. Explain that to yourself. Money can be made in many ways. Many ways. Winning a lot can earn you money. Sure. Winning a little can too. It all depends on how you approach it. What you need. Neither is better nor worse. If you achieve a 52% hit rate and reach your goal, bravo. If you need a 38% hit rate to reach your goal, bravo. But remember, bravo to me who needs 18%. The ways of working to seek a 38% hit, 50%, or 18% are absolutely different. Both in risks and benefits. All are good. And all can fail. I never recommend you start with hedging right away. Why not? Because when I do hedges, I know I can let them run. To reach the point where I am now, and can say I can let positions run a lot without it affecting me, I had to start small. I had to start with 1.3 at first. Then 1.4. Then 1.5. Then thinking I’m stuck. Damn, it’s hard to go beyond 1.5. Then beyond to 1.6. So all this stretches over time. But you have to recognize, know what your exit limits are. Because if you don’t know your exit limits, you will never let the profits run a lot. If you can’t handle a fixed 1.5 ratio well, how do you expect to chase a 1.10? It can't be. It will turn out terribly.

concepts.name: Hedging
concepts.definition: Using positions to cover both potential directions of the market to mitigate risk and capitalize on trends.
concepts.relationship: Integral to Joaquin's methodology of not being attached to a single market direction.

concepts.name: Fractality
concepts.definition: The concept that the market moves in constant patterns, allowing the trader to capture movement in both directions.
concepts.relationship: Fractality ensures there's consistent opportunity within dual directional thinking.

concepts.name: Dual Direction Thinking
concepts.definition: Trading mindset that does not commit to solely upward or downward trends, allowing flexibility.
concepts.relationship: Supports hedging strategy by providing mental readiness for either market movement.

concepts.name: Coverage in Trading
concepts.definition: Strategically creating positions that safeguard during directional changes.
concepts.relationship: Executed through dual direction thinking and fractality.

rules.rule: Use hedging to simultaneously engage with both market directions.
rules.context: Always works with dual-directional thinking to avoid being caught off-guard by market reversals.

rules.rule: Always attempt to catch trends at the beginning for maximum movement.
rules.context: Executing entry points at potential trend origins ensures a better risk-to-reward ratio.

rules.rule: Do not obsess over accuracy; focus on maintaining profitable trades.
rules.context: A high accuracy percentage is less important than maintaining strategies that ensure profitability.

rules.rule: Let positions run to maximize gains.
rules.context: Allowing profitable trades to develop fully rather than limiting potential through premature exits.

analysis.summary: In his video, Joaquín Vega advocates for a trading strategy that forgoes trend-following in favor of a hedging approach. He emphasizes the importance of dual-directional thinking, whereby traders maintain positions to capture both upward and downward market movements. Joaquin highlights the significance of fractality, noting that traders should aim to catch trends early for greater potential. The video stresses the importance of focusing on profit rather than accuracy, suggesting that traders should maintain trades as long as they remain advantageous, even amid market oscillations. Overall, his methodology is designed to reduce stress and ensure profitability through comprehensive risk management, rather than through high accuracy rates.

_metadata.title: En trading, NO QUIERO TENER MUCHO ACIERTO, QUIERO GANAR MUCHO DINERO. Joaquín Vega.

title: En trading, EL CONTEXTO, SIEMPRE MANDA. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: The issue with context, I can't stop emphasizing it because you lack this concept. Many of you lack this concept. It's not the same to enter based on this pattern of a deception than this. Imagine the price comes, has done this, made a first deception, everything's great, everything's wonderful, that deception fails, and I'm working on a second deception. The price works well with the second deception and also gives me an entry. Perfect. It's not the same entry as this one. Are they correct patterns? Yes. But it's not the same to work on an evolution of a pattern as a first pattern that enters an area. They are different contexts. Damn, they're both correct patterns. One is first and one is second. Yes, yes, I know they are correct, but the context of the situation of one entry is not the same as the other. I always tell you, you have to evaluate good, regular, weak contexts. It can't be any other way, folks. It can't be any other way. It's not the same a second work in an area than a first one. No, because here you already have a deficiency; here the price already told you there’s a weakness. It's not the same. Therefore, this pattern happening here has a much better context than this operation. Well, regular or weak. You have to know how to evaluate the context of the entry we are making. This is very important. Why is it so important? Because in each context, if I know to evaluate the context, I can regulate. In a good context I will use one volume. In a regular context, I will use a smaller volume. And in a weak context, I will use even less. Every time you make or are about to make an entry where you see many doubts, evaluate those doubts between many doubts, which would be weak contexts, or a few doubts, regular contexts. Damn, that should tell you with what amount of lotage to enter. This is fundamental. I don't care whether the entries are aggressive or calm. Always evaluate the context. What does this mean? If I'm making an entry here and I go with a good context, I go with more lotage. The amount I decided to use in good contexts. What does that mean? That if this moves, as I already go with a good lotage, in my following fibs, I don't add more. As long as I don’t take a partial on my initial position, which goes with good lotage because the context is good, I’m not going to add more money here. Because I’d be overdoing it. If I use a good lotage on good context and I’m going to add even more, I’m making a mistake. I’m already there with sufficient lotage. I only want this area to manage. I don’t want it for adding when I entered with a good context and when I entered, supposedly, with my maximum lotages in an operation. Another thing is if I have, let's say, a regular context. What can be a regular context? This is. There’s an evolution and I know there's an evolution, I know there’s a previous pattern that failed. Here there's already a first sign of weakness. I have to know that. Which means my regular lotage will be smaller than if it were a good context. Perfect. I enter with that lesser lotage. Good. From that moment I also go with my following fib. Regular context. So far my tracking area helps me protect myself. In no case am I thinking of adding more volume yet. If it's a regular context, for me to add or think of adding slightly more, since I entered with a regular context and entered with less lotage than usual, I need the price to show me things. What things? At least, break important highs. Because as long as you don't break them, I already evaluated it was a regular context. Because if the price does this and moves slightly, I won’t be thinking of adding more volume. Of course not. If when I entered it was a regular context, what happens? Has it now become a good context because the price moved a little? Absolutely not. I'm not thinking of adding more either here. Here because I’m already with the complete lotage. And what I’d be doing is doubling positions. Adding more capital than my good context wants. And here, because I still don’t have anything the price tells me, I’m already fine, it’s no longer a regular context, it’s good. No. Another thing is if the price keeps moving, and does things I like, breaks highs and I see strength, now I might consider adding slightly more. Because the context has changed. That's why it’s so important. It bothers me a lot when I see people who seem to think all operations are alike. Folks, there aren't two identical operations. Because context always commands. We work the same patterns? Always, yes. But how are we working them? What happened in that place? Have you assessed the context of what's happening? And once you've entered, at least you've regulated the volume with good, regular, or weak, what's the price doing? Is it doing what you want? Because if it's doing this, for now, it’s not yet doing what I want. I'm not thinking of adding here, right? I set rules and tell it, for me to add position because I can, because I have excess, and because when you entered the market, you entered with a regular volume, can I add more? I need to see things from you. Bam! From that moment the context has changed. Then I can consider adding a bit more. Not before. Imagine now, I'll put another case, when I see many doubts in an operation, or even, you know I’m very aggressive working, imagine you have a second deception and the price goes plop! Let’s see. What context do I have? It's not that we’re working an extreme deception, but hey, are all extreme deceptions alike? Is this extreme deception the same as this one? Is it the same that the price comes with a lot of force, does nothing inside the area, goes out of the area, and here that the price has been working and that’s failed two operations in a row? Is it the same context? Is it the same pattern? But is it the same context? Of course not! Absolutely not! Because this would be my first work in area. Good context! But this would be a weak context. They have nothing to do with each other. And they are exactly the same pattern. Therefore, never interpret that it's an extreme deception and it's an extreme deception. Do I work all extreme deceptions the same? Absolutely not. This means that the moment the price leaves the area, people who do this and believe any extreme deception is the same, what that person is telling me is that everything that happened here is as if it didn't exist. All those symptoms of weakness that happened here the person doesn't take into account. Therefore, they will enter with the same lotage here as here. Huge mistake. We are ignoring something fundamental. What truly makes the difference between a good and bad trader. Differentiate contexts to differentiate entry lotages. This is crucial. No matter the patterns presented to us. No matter what happens in the area. I always say to you, I don't care if operations fail. I don't care about entering three consecutive operations in an area. I’m staggering my entry sizes because I’m staggering the contexts occurring. Here I’ll enter with more, in the second I’ll enter with less, and in the third, I’ll enter with less. Okay, you entered with less. I see here a weak context. Perfect. What percentage do I have of operations? With a weak context. X, whichever it is, I enter. I don’t care about failing the previous two, as if I failed 50. I am protected with my business plan and my context assessment. What do I care about failing seven previous ones? I don’t care, my account doesn't suffer. Perfect. I go with the weak. What does it mean? That you have to change my context. I go with very little lotage. The smallest I use because I’ve seen it’s a complicated operation. For X reason, complicated. I go with the smallest of my lotages. For me to change the context of what I’m seeing, you’re going to have to prove things to me. I’m excessive with the lotage. I’m excessive. I go with very little volume and the price starts to move. Followed fib. Am I going to be thinking of adding more here? No. But if the context hasn’t changed, what do I want to see in the price if I’m bought? Break highs. Which high is more important? This one? Or this one? Let's see, which high is more important? Let each one decide the confirmation they want to ask. Some would say, look, the moment the price surpasses the first high, that area that served me to protect until now, now not only serves to protect but to add a little more. Okay, perfect. Man, the context is beginning to change. Now yes, but when the price hadn't even surpassed a previous high, the context remained just as bad. One wants to validate their, let’s say, change of scenario, because these are still scenarios. As we are assessing a context, we can have 27,000 different types of scenarios. That’s why all operations are different and I must always act the same in good, regular, and weak contexts.

concepts.name: Context
concepts.definition: The evaluation of external price conditions in trading to adjust trading strategies.
concepts.relationship: Determines the appropriate volume of lotage according to whether contexts are good, regular, or weak.

concepts.name: Deception Pattern
concepts.definition: A price pattern indicating an initial false move followed by correction.
concepts.relationship: Used differently depending on whether it’s the first or second instance due to the implied context.

concepts.name: Followed Fibonacci
concepts.definition: Subsequent price levels used for tracking movement for performance evaluation.
concepts.relationship: Serves as a reference in good contexts to decide against adding more volume unnecessarily.

rules.rule: Adjust volume based on context quality (good, regular, weak).
rules.context: When determining the amount of lotage to use in an entry.

rules.rule: Reevaluate volume addition only when price movement substantially changes context.
rules.context: During a trade setup and as ongoing decisions about position scaling are made.

rules.rule: Do not treat all pattern setups as equal; context differences necessitate different approaches.
rules.context: When analyzing deception patterns or similar indicators in distinct market conditions.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of context when deciding trading strategies. He clarifies that entry decisions should not solely rely on pattern recognition but need to consider the surrounding context to determine the appropriate action and lotage volume. Different contexts (good, regular, weak) require varying trading adjustments, such as the lotage to leverage or whether to increase investment. Vega illustrates his point using deception patterns, elucidating how repeated patterns under different conditions necessitate different approaches. The ultimate lesson is to consistently evaluate the context to effectively manage trading risks and optimize returns.

_metadata.title: En trading, EL CONTEXTO, SIEMPRE MANDA. Joaquín Vega.

title: Un día de TRADING INTRADÍA en SP500. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Good morning, good afternoon. Hello, I’m Joaquín Vega. Friday, December 3rd. We continue working once again on SP500, this time on a short-term chart, a 15-minute chart. I’m going to show you a bit of what I'm expecting the price to do so I can go back to work. Well, right now we have these two short positions, sold, and I will set the targets in this zone, around 4,565. Let's set these two goals there because we have the option that the price makes that pattern you see there. I am waiting for it to make a short-term drop to this area of 4,560-65 points, to then head to a much more important zone, starting from 4,625. It is a broad zone, about 20-25 points, where we should see more significant declines. We will be trying to put in short positions there. Later I will show you the longer-term map, but let's say that now, in the short term, this is what I'm trying to achieve. We are also going to put long positions here. We are going to buy here. There is a range to this area, this range that I would like to capture. Let's see if we are able to do it. First, give us those shorts, then we buy and then sell. Well, the perfect movement. We're going with the two long positions. We’ve taken the shorts and already took a partial here. Well, let's remove one of the positions at this level that seems quite dangerous to me. We are going to take about 35 points, even though I think the price will come to these levels that we mentioned at the beginning. Be careful with this level, it could give us a shake below before going back up. We remove one of the positions here, we hold another, okay? Let's see what happens at this level and if not, we attack up here. All right. Well, we take profits and wait for developments. Let's see this area that smells dangerous to me. If the price reaches these levels, we execute, and if not, we would look for new executions below. All right. Well, folks, to end the video. As you can see, they indeed tricked us here. I thought it would go up to this area but from there I planned those sales. But look how they fooled us. Now, I do believe the position that was left took me out. At least, it's going to come to these levels. Here I'm going to try a long position. I'll show you the map I made this morning. This is the map. Every day I reinvent the map, because each day is different. I had planned for the price to reach that zone you saw there for it to then fall to these levels. But, as you see, the price didn’t reach it. It fell earlier. Therefore, now it's this zone we're pending, which is what I am marking here. It's this zone. Pay attention to this area and see what happens. We continue to hold the short positions, but be careful that we might have an extension below or before the extension we could have significant upward movements. As I always say, each day is different and new maps need to be made. Nothing else, you've seen a normal and ordinary intraday operation of any of my days and I hope it has helped you. Nothing more, regards, see you in the next video.

analysis.summary: This video by Joaquín Vega provides a real-time analysis of trading the SP500 using a modified Fibonacci methodology and 15-minute charts. Vega outlines a practical approach to intraday trading, emphasizing the importance of predefined levels of significance and position management, including taking partial exits at risky levels. He illustrates the necessity to adapt trading strategies daily with his concept of a 'daily map,' analyzing the market’s responses against his predictions. This approach highlights the dynamics and adaptability required in day trading to mitigate risks and maximize profits.

title: Deberías incluir a tu trading LAS OPERACIONES NULAS. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: I want you to see this movement, 5 minutes, I’ll make it bigger. What do you think of this movement? Tell me, how is this going up? Is it doing well? Is it doing poorly? Define it for me. Basically what’s happening here is that it’s having a hard time making this move. All this it's doing here is rubbish. But I want you to realize why it's rubbish. Because this happens many times, and your mission is to realize why it’s rubbish. Damn, Joaquín, how can it be rubbish if it’s going up? Yes, it can keep going up, but it will pull back. I don’t know when, but it will. That rise isn’t healthy. You shouldn’t see this fall as it is, damn. You don’t see this fall as it is. And look at that rise. Don’t you see the difference between a movement that has strength and one that doesn’t even though it's going up? It’s very noticeable. And it can continue to rise 100 more pips. Of course, it can do that, without a doubt. But it will pull back. Something is happening here, they’ve had to make a lot of effort to keep pushing the price up. This is basically saying that this is another level of imbalance. Something is happening here. I want you to understand what a level of imbalance means. They’re doing strange things here. They’re forcing the machinery for it to go up very little by little, but they lack strength. If we look at it in a minute, I don’t like it. I don’t like that rise. I don't like it. I don't like it. I'm out right away. I don't like it. Out. I'm out of two positions. Did you see what I just did? I repeat. Did you see what I just did? Do you do this? What I just did is an action. We’ve been talking about this for two days. Actions. I decide. If I say no, it's no. Even going in favor. This is what I've been trying to explain to you for two days. That price doesn’t condition me. I decide based on what it does. And as you see here, it’s not at a loss. It’s protection, but not at a loss. I don’t care. And now I don’t care that it keeps going up. The action means that I have to leave everything. No. But you’re not going up the way I want you to. You’re not doing as I say. And I’m the boss here, in my company I’m in charge. And since you’re not doing well, I decide. That’s it. And now whatever happens, happens, what I’m clear on is that the price will return to my entry points sooner or later. What happens if I take all three positions and put them at break-even? It will take them out, no doubt. All of them. Damn. I’d rather take 8 euros. The timing is horrible. It’s terrible. 8 and 8, 16. Look, I’ve made enough for four beers. Null operations. Actions. What you don’t do. This. You just stare at it. And at most, break-even. And you don't go up as I say. So, who’s in charge here? The chart or me? See how this prevents stress? Damn. You’re all stressed in front of the chart. This is going up badly. Point. There’s no turning back. It goes up badly. I don’t care if you go up 100 pips. You go up badly. It’s all the same to me. And if you go up 100 pips, I’ll leave you one. Go up if you want. And now if you want, fall. I don’t care. Do you get the idea? Is it simple or isn’t it simple? How did I execute? I executed with a first shot. Are you going in my favor? I’ll add two more. Can I add 8? Yes. But I don’t want to add eight. Why? Because the timings are bad. I decide how I’m entering. I decide when I’m getting in. I can add 12 if I want. But I add 3 because I can’t add more due to the timing I’m using. That’s it. It’s easy. I don’t do anything complicated. There’s nothing that’s hard to do. This isn’t a matter of manual skill or anything.

concepts.name: Imbalance Level
concepts.definition: A point where the price is pushed with effort but lacks underlying strength, indicating an unsustainable rise.
concepts.relationship: Related to price momentum and strength; indicates potential reversals.

concepts.name: Null Operations
concepts.definition: Strategic decision to exit positions with minimal gain to avoid stress from unreliable price movements.
concepts.relationship: Connected to emotional control and strategic timing in trading.

concepts.name: Action/Decision
concepts.definition: The trader’s ability to make independent decisions based on price movements rather than being compelled by the chart.
concepts.relationship: Directly influences trade management and risk control.

rules.rule: Exit trades when price movement is weak, even if it means foregoing potential profit.
rules.context: When the price is rising without strength.

rules.rule: Reduce stress by deciding when to enter and exit trades based on personal criteria rather than market pressure.
rules.context: In situations of unstable or unclear price movements.

analysis.summary: This video by Joaquín Vega introduces the concept of 'Null Operations' in trading, emphasizing the importance of stepping away from trades that do not perform as desired, despite potential for profit. Joaquín explains the identification of weak price movements, stressing that an increase in price might still be unsustainable and warrant exiting. He emphasizes the trader's role in making decisions independent of market pressure and highlights strategies to avoid stress while maintaining control over trading decisions. The video reinforces the significance of recognizing imbalance levels and acting swiftly, following personal trading criteria rather than yielding to market movements.

_metadata.title: Deberías incluir a tu trading LAS OPERACIONES NULAS. Joaquín Vega.

title: EL RATIO DE PROFIT POR OPERACIÓN EN TU TRADING. Joaquín Vega.

analysis.translation: Why am I talking to you when we are discussing how to make money? Because I am giving a lot of importance to what we call the time-space-reward relationship. What do you think I mean with this? Notice the example I am going to give you. Imagine you, living in Oviedo, are looking for a job, and they tell you that you need to go to Llanes to work every day and each time you'll be paid 50 euros. For the same job, starting from Oviedo, they tell you, you need to go to León every day, and you'll be paid 80 euros each day you go. Similarly, they tell you in Madrid, here we are going to pay you 140 euros. Exactly the same daily job, you have to go to Madrid every day. And in Valencia, they tell you, look, here we will pay you 200 euros. Exactly the same job but in different places. How would you evaluate which of these jobs or positions would be better for you? Do you understand where I am going with time-space-reward? To decide which is better for you, you have to make many evaluations. Therefore, here there is a completely different time-space-reward relationship. The specific worker, in this example, would have to make a very specific valuation of their personal case. Because look, I can give you some conditioning factors that you would have to evaluate, take into account, for example, gasoline, whether there are tolls or no tolls, tire wear, I don't know, whether I have to eat out or not. And then, for example, the issue of traffic jams, that is, there are a lot of conditioning factors when deciding this that are not only based on the amount of money. To come to the conclusion that one of these positions with the corresponding money they give you is correct for you is absolutely personal. That’s why we can’t say that when you invest in a trade with your 16 euros risk, we cannot say there’s one better than the other. What I do tell you is that for you, not for another, for you there is a relationship that is right. Under your characteristics, which have nothing to do with it, imagine we were here with 20 people, and they would all tell me something different. Because every situation is different, every personality is different, every person has different ways of thinking. So there isn’t one better than another because you could give one person an argument and the other could give you an argument depending on the situation of each one. This is vital because this example, exactly this example, transferred to each operation you will do, is identical. Which are the conditioning factors that affect you in that time-space relationship? There will be people who tell me, look, I prefer to go for an hour there, take my 50 euros, and to hell with it. Because we are saying here is a completely different time-space relationship and especially reward, completely different in each situation. One of the most important mistakes you make is that's where you fail because you think that by default there is a better way of profit, and it is absolutely false. Each one of those exit formulas, each one of those profit formulas, has good and bad things. What would you think if I told you, hey, if you're training me, you should tell me which of the four is better. No, I can tell you which of the four is better for me, but I don’t know you, and I don’t know the other person either. I don’t know each one’s situation. I am not inside your head, I don’t know your situation. What I do tell you is that we have to find which is good for you, and when I say the good for you, it’s that, hey, I’m going to Llanes with that time-space and those conditions of gasoline, traffic, whatever, delighted with life or to León or to Madrid or Valencia and I am capable of fulfilling it every day each time I go to that job or whether it be Valencia, Madrid, León or Llanes and the reward they will give me I go delighted. This is what we have to find, and this is one of the most difficult things for you to find. It is one of the things that will take you the longest time. Why does the error come? And I'll tell you here, most people fail. Because when I explain this to you in such a silly example like this, but in the end, it is exactly what will happen to you on the chart, if you are not in agreement with your time-space-reward and you find yourself uncomfortable, you will screw it up. It is the moment when you can skip all the rules. But not because you do not know them, but because mentally you have chosen a job that does not suit you. I can tell you, look, I make money and I go delighted with the example of Madrid, and therefore, since I go delighted every day with the example of Madrid, you all will go to Madrid. This is what people want. Hey, Joaquín, tell me which one I should go to, since you are the one with the experience in this. No, man, no. I have to make you understand this. I cannot give you the solution by definition because each of them I can tell you good things about each one and vice versa, or about León or Madrid. Each one has its good and bad things. I need us to know the good and bad things that Llanes, León, Madrid, and Valencia have and when we have evaluated the good and bad that it has, because here people beware, they tend to think about the good. I only think about the good that each of these forms has and stick with that. No, my friend, the one you choose will surely have bad things, and the chart is going to make you suffer them. So be very careful not to make a mistake here or think, no, León’s is better than Madrid's, because it will have to be seen. The typical error. I think Madrid is the best option. How do you mean I think? You think you can go there? Do you think you have contracted, taken, signed that job without knowing 100% that Madrid is yours? Are we crazy? How is that going to be? No, it’s just that I think so, but do you think so? Have you tried it? Have you done it? Have you experienced it? Have you experienced the traffic jams, the tolls, the tires? Have you experienced all this? Then how can you tell me that Madrid is yours without having done it? Don’t screw with me. This is what people do when going there. I consider this form of profit is mine. See, guys, you'll have to start somewhere, of course. You will have to start with León if you want. Very good, but you will have to experience what it produces to go to León every day. Or I realized that in León, perfectly, I might even be able to go to Madrid. Great, we try it again, but do not take it for granted now that there is one that is that. Because you all usually make mistakes. What is the only way to know which of those jobs is yours? Try them all, damn it. And that’s why this takes so much time. With the proper profit exit. Look, you have to understand something. This time space, if we transfer it to the chart, that chart can do things here in this time space. In this time space, it can do others. But here, it can do many more. It can do many more. And you have to tolerate it. Logically, for greater reward, more time space. You have to tolerate everything that happens in this time space. Both gasoline and tolls, as if there are traffic jams, you suck it up. You should have chosen a shorter job. Then don’t complain about the traffic jams. Don’t complain. It's that it takes a long time to get there. Normal. And do you want to take the same time to León as to Madrid or what? Do you expect the expenses to be the same or what? That is to say, it's common sense. I'm not saying anything strange, but people believe that there is a common way of profit for everyone. Because since the method earns... No, guys, I am offering you the same work but different conditions adapted to you. That is, there are a number of conditions. And in this time space is where you run the risk of that price altering you. If you make a mistake in the time space, what that price is going to do, because the price, in the end, does things as it pleases and for as long as it pleases. Remember that when you enter the market, you, with that price, control nothing of it. You only control time, space, reward. Period. But what that price can do in that period, you control nothing. Then what am I capable of enduring? What time space am I capable of enduring for whatever happens and lasts as long as it lasts my operation? I am calm.

decision_points.condition: The market presents a profit opportunity similar to traveling to a specific city
decision_points.if_true: Consider personal factors like time and cost involved before making a decision
decision_points.if_false: You might find a seemingly appealing option is not suitable due to overlooked factors
decision_points.quote_es: El error típico. Yo creo que Madrid es la mejor opción.
decision_points.quote_en: The typical error. I think Madrid is the best option.

concepts.name: time-space-reward relationship
concepts.definition: It's an analogy comparing trading decisions to deciding on a job based on travel distance, time, and salary to evaluate the personal fit of a trade.
concepts.relationship: Relates personal conditions to the profitability of trades, adjusting strategy accordingly.

rules.rule: Evaluate each trade based on your personal time, and cost aspects.
rules.context: When considering new trade opportunities.

rules.rule: Test different trading strategies to find the best personal fit.
rules.context: When unsure about optimal trading strategy.

analysis.summary: Joaquín Vega emphasizes the importance of evaluating trades not just on potential profit but on personal factors such as time and cost commitments, using the time-space-reward relationship analogy to highlight this. He argues that just as jobs closer at lower pay could be more preferable, trading conditions need personal assessment. Mistakes happen when traders assume one-size-fits-all strategies without testing and evaluating based on individual circumstances. He insists the only way to find the right method is through trial and adjusting to what its implications mean personally. Ultimately, the method's success lies in aligning it with one's risk tolerance and lifestyle requirements.
